sn.sn1.50: Ghaṭīkāra, a disciple of the former Buddha Kassapa, comes to the Buddha and speaks of his past life, and of the attainments of six friends.
sn.sn1.51: Morality is good even in old age.
sn.sn1.52: Morality is good when it doesn’t decay.
sn.sn1.53: Things that are friends in this life and the next.
sn.sn1.54: What is it that sustains various beings? Unusually, this verse lacks a “Dhamma” counterpart.
sn.sn1.55: A person is created by craving and fears suffering.
sn.sn1.56: A person is created by craving and is not freed from suffering
sn.sn1.57: A person is created by craving and their destiny is shaped by their deeds.
sn.sn1.59: A person’s true companion is their faith.
sn.sn1.60: A pair of verses on the nature of poetry, and lacking a Dhamma counterpart.
sn.sn1.62: The mind leads the world around and controls it all.
sn.sn1.63: The mind leads the world around and craving controls it.
sn.sn1.64: The world is fettered by craving.
sn.sn1.65: The world is bound by craving.
sn.sn1.66: The world is afflicted with death and old age, and burning with desire.
sn.sn1.67: The world is caught by craving and built on suffering.
sn.sn1.68: The world is shut in by death.
sn.sn1.69: The world is bound by desire.
sn.sn1.70: A Dhamma riddle whose answer, enigmatically, is “six”.
sn.sn1.71: The killing of anger is the only killing praised by the noble ones.
sn.sn1.72: What is the sign or token of a chariot, a fire, a nation, and a woman?
sn.sn1.73: A series of questions on what is best.
sn.sn1.74: A series of questions asked by one deity, answered by another, and then given a better answer by the Buddha.
sn.sn1.75: Why is it that, though the path has been taught, people still fear?
sn.sn1.76: A series of questions on the path.
sn.sn1.77: A series of questions on diverse matters.
sn.sn1.78: What is it that one should not give away?
sn.sn1.79: A series of questions on diverse topics.
sn.sn1.80: A series of questions on diverse topics.
sn.sn1.81: A series of questions on diverse kinds of people
sn.sn2.1: A deity named Kassapa comes to the Buddha and speaks of the training of a mendicant in seclusion and right speech.
sn.sn2.2: The deity Kassapa speaks of how a mendicant should be a meditator, peaceful and free.
sn.sn2.3: The god Māgha asks the Buddha about what one should slay in order to sleep well and be without sorrow.
sn.sn2.4: The deity Māgadha asks the Buddha how many sources of light there are in the world. The Buddha speaks of five lights, but the Buddha is the best of them.
sn.sn2.5: Dāmali the god suggests that a true brahmin must strive to abandon desire. The Buddha disagrees, saying that a true holy one has already completed their work.
sn.sn2.6: The deity Kāmada addresses the Buddha with a series of cryptic statements lamenting the difficulty of spiritual practice. The Buddha agrees, but points out that true practitioners do it even though it’s hard.
sn.sn2.7: Pañcālacaṇḍa praises the Buddha for finding the opening amid the confinement of the world. But the Buddha affirms that anyone with mindfulness and stillness may find such an escape.
sn.sn2.8: Tāyana, a deity who was in a past life was a leader of a non-Buddhist sect, speaks a series of verses in praise of strenuous exertion and discipline. These famous verses are commonly recited by Theravadin monks.
sn.sn2.9: In a parable of a lunar eclipse, the moon god Candimā is swallowed by the demon lord Rāhu. Candimā appeals to the Buddha, who tells Rāhu to let go. This sutta is recited as a protection verse.
sn.sn2.10: In a parable of a solar eclipse, the sun god Suriya is swallowed by the demon lord Rāhu. Suriya appeals to the Buddha, who tells Rāhu to let go. This sutta is recited as a protection verse.
sn.sn2.11: The deity Candimasa says that those who practice absorption will surely find escape. The Buddha adds that they must also be diligent and discard flaws.
sn.sn2.12: The deity Veṇhu celebrates the joy of those who follow the Buddha’s teaching. The Buddha affirms that such will escape death. Veṇhu is the Pali spelling of Sanskrit Viṣṇu, and this marks a rare appearance of a god of this name in the early texts.
sn.sn2.13: Dīghalaṭṭhi the god comes to the Buddha at Rājagaha and praises a mendicant who is a meditator.
sn.sn2.14: The deity Nandana asks the Buddha who is virtuous, wise, beyond suffering, worshiped by the gods themselves. The Buddha replies that such a person is an arahant.
sn.sn2.15: Candana asks who crosses the flood. The Buddha replies that it is one who is virtuous , wise, peaceful, and beyond attachment to rebirth.
sn.sn2.16: The deity Vasudatta says that a mendicant should live like their hair is on fire so as to give up lust. The Buddha changes his verse to emphasize giving up attachment to self.
sn.sn2.17: Subrahmā the god asks for the escape from fear. The Buddha says there is no escape from fear without letting go of everything.
sn.sn2.18: At Sāketa the god Kakudha asks the Buddha if he delights or sorrows. The Buddha replies that since he has no attachments he neither delights nor sorrows.
sn.sn2.19: The god Uttara speaks of the transience of life, saying one should do good to be reborn in a happy future life. The Buddha replies that one should let go attachment.
sn.sn2.20: A deity who had been the Buddha’s supporter Anāthapiṇḍika in his former life comes to Buddha and speaks verses in celebration of the Jeta’s Grove monastery—which he had offered for the Buddha’s use—good deeds, the Dhamma, and Venerable Sāriputta.
sn.sn2.21: The deity Siva says one should associate only with the good, and this will lead to happiness. The Buddha adds that associating with the good leads to the end of suffering. Siva is the Pali spelling of Sanskrit Śiva, and this marks a rare appearance of a god of this name in the early texts.
sn.sn2.22: The deity Khema utters a series of verses in praise of good deeds. The Buddha responds with a simile for someone who departs the path of the good.
sn.sn2.23: The deity Serī speaks of how everyone loves food., to which the Buddha responds with verses in praise of giving. Serī speaks of his own generosity in a past life.
sn.sn2.24: The deity Ghaṭīkāra speaks of the seven mendicants reborn in the Aviha realm. The sutta is similar to SN 1.50.
sn.sn2.25: Some monks in Kosala fell into negligence, and were admonished by the deity Jantu.
sn.sn2.26: Rohitassa asks the Buddha if it is possible to reach the end of the world by traveling. The Buddha says no; and Rohitassa tells of how in a past life as a seer he had tried to accomplish this very feat and failed. The Buddha says the end of the world is found in this body.
sn.sn2.27: Nanda speaks of the transience of life, saying one should do good to be reborn in a happy future life. The Buddha replies that one should let go attachment.
sn.sn2.28: The god Nandivisāla gives an elaborate metaphor for the body, and asks how to escape from it.
sn.sn2.29: The Buddha asks Ānanda if he likes Sāriputta, and when he replies that he does, the god Susīma and his assembly appear, rejoicing in Sāriputta’s praises, and radiating in lustrous colors.
sn.sn2.30: A series of deities who had formerly been ascetics in the non-Buddhist sects came to the Buddha, speaking verses in praise—or occasional criticism—of their former teachers
sn.sn3.1: King Pasenadi meets the Buddha for the first time. He wonders how the Buddha can claim to be awakened when he is still so young. The Buddha teaches him four things that should not be looked down on for their youth.
sn.sn3.2: Pasenadi asks of the things that cause suffering when they arise in oneself.
sn.sn3.3: Pasenadi asks if anything that is born can escape from old age and death.
sn.sn3.4: Reporting on a reflection that arose while on retreat, Pasenadi says that those who do bad deeds treat themselves as enemy. The Buddha expresses his agreement in verse.
sn.sn3.5: Even if protected by an entire army, one who does bad deeds is still unprotected.
sn.sn3.6: There are few in the world who do not become negligent and complacent once they obtain material luxuries.
sn.sn3.7: Pasenadi laments how in his judgment hall he sees people lying all the time for the sake of sensual pleasures.
sn.sn3.8: Pasandi asks Queen Mallikā who is most dear. They both agree that the one most dear is oneself, and the Buddha agrees.
sn.sn3.9: A great sacrifice involving the slaughter of many animals was being prepared for King Pasenadi. The Buddha condemns such sacrifices and says a fruitful sacrifice involves a blameless and harmless offering.
sn.sn3.10: When many people are put in chains by Pasenadi, the matter is reported to the Buddha.
sn.sn3.11: A diverse group of ascetics passes by, and Pasenadi asks the Buddha if any of them are perfected ones. The Buddha says it is not easy for one such as Pasenadi to judge the spiritual achievements of others. Pasenadi reveals that the men are, in fact, his spies.
sn.sn3.12: Five kings including Pasenadi are enjoying themselves and wonder which of the senses affords the highest pleasure. They ask the Buddha, who replies that it is subjective, depending on a persons preferences. Inspired, the laymen Candanaṅgalika offers a verse in praise of the Buddha.
sn.sn3.13: In what is probably the world’s first weight loss diet, when Pasenadi shows up overweight and out of breath, the Buddha advises him to cut down his eating. He gives a verse to one of the king’s attendants, and asks him to recite it whenever the king is eating.
sn.sn3.14: Pasenadi loses a battle against his nephew King Ajātasattu of Magadha.
sn.sn3.15: In a battle subsequent to SN 3.14, Pasenadi defeats Ajātasattu and takes him prisoner. Acting compassionately, he confiscates Ajātasattu’s military assets but releases him alive.
sn.sn3.16: Pasenadi is disappointed to hear that Queen Mallikā has given birth to a daughter. But the Buddha consoles him, saying a woman may turn out better than a man.
sn.sn3.17: Pasenadi asks the Buddha if there is one thing that secures benefit both in this life and the next.
sn.sn3.18: In answer to Pasenadi’s praise of good friendship, the Buddha recounts an earlier conversation with Ānanda on the topic. He then goes on to say that when one has good friends, it is important to develop diligence.
sn.sn3.19: A wealthy man dies childless, having not enjoyed his riches. The Buddha says that wealth should be properly enjoyed and shared.
sn.sn3.20: A wealthy man dies childless, having not enjoyed his riches. The Buddha tells of how in the time of a solitary Buddha of the past named Tagarasikhī, a householder made an offering but later regretted it.
sn.sn3.21: The Buddha teaches Pasenadi of four kinds of person, going from dark to dark, dark to light, light to dark, and light to light.
sn.sn3.22: Pasenadi laments the death of his aged grandmother.
sn.sn3.23: How many things give rise to suffering in oneself?
sn.sn3.24: “Where should I give” and “Where is a gift is most fruitful” are two different questions.
sn.sn3.25: Old age and death roll in upon all like mountains approaching from the four directions, crushing all in their path
sn.sn4.1: Māra accuses the Buddha of having abandoned the path of true austerity.
sn.sn4.2: Māra manifests before the Buddha in the form of a ferocious elephant in order to scare him.
sn.sn4.3: Māra tries to scare the Buddha by taking on shifting forms both beautiful and hideous.
sn.sn4.4: When the Buddha explains to the mendicants how he realized freedom, Māra claims he is still trapped.
sn.sn4.5: When the Buddha explains to the mendicants how he has realized freedom, and so have his mendicant followers, Māra claims he is still trapped.
sn.sn4.6: Māra manifests as a huge serpent, but the Buddha is unshaken.
sn.sn4.7: After meditating all night, the Buddha lies down to sleep at dawn, and Māra scolds him for being lazy.
sn.sn4.8: The Buddha and Māra exchange verses on whether attachments are a source of delight or suffering.
sn.sn4.9: Though the Buddha says that life is short, Māra says it is long.
sn.sn4.10: Though the Buddha says that life is short, Māra says it is long.
sn.sn4.11: Māra smashes boulders in an attempt to scare the Buddha.
sn.sn4.12: Māra criticizes the Buddha for his lion’s roar, asserting that the Buddha is not in fact peerless.
sn.sn4.13: The Buddha rests after being struck by stone splinters, and Māra criticizes him for being lazy.
sn.sn4.14: Māra discourages the Buddha from teaching, warning him that he will become corrupted by favoritism.
sn.sn4.15: Māra threatens the Buddha with a “mental snare” in the sky.
sn.sn4.16: While the mendicants are listening to the teachings, Māra takes the form of an ox and looks as if he will break their almsbowls.
sn.sn4.17: While the mendicants are listening to the teachings, Māra makes an awful roar to distract them.
sn.sn4.18: Māra ensures that the Buddha fails to get alms, but the Buddha is happy to feed on joy.
sn.sn4.19: While the mendicants are listening to the teachings, Māra takes the form of a farmer looking for lost oxen and addresses the Buddha.
sn.sn4.20: The Buddha wonders whether it is possible to rule justly, without violence. Māra appears and encourages the Buddha to purse such a path.
sn.sn4.21: Māra approaches some young mendicants as an old brahmin, and tries to tempt them with talk of the pleasures of youth.
sn.sn4.22: Māra repeatedly pesters the monk Samiddhi when he is on retreat. The Buddha encourages him, until eventually Samiddhi is able to recognize Māra for himself.
sn.sn4.23: Venerable Godhika finds himself repeatedly falling away from his meditation attainments due to severe illness. Eventually he considers suicide, and Māra tries to get the Buddha to deter him. But the Buddha says Godhika has already attained awakening and has died blamelessly.
sn.sn4.24: Māra has tried to distract the Buddha for seven years without success. He laments his failure with the similes of a crab whose limbs are smashed by a group of children, and a crow who tried to eat a stone.
sn.sn4.25: Depressed, Māra laments to his three daughters of his failure to distract the Buddha. So they take on the task themselves, and assume a variety of sensuous forms to tempt him. But they fail too, and Māra castigates them for being so presumptuous
sn.sn5.1: The nun Āḷavikā has entered the Dark Wood seeking seclusion when Māra comes to threaten her, claiming there is no escape and no point in seclusion. She recognizes him instantly and dismisses his taunts, asserting that she is beyond his control.
sn.sn5.2: When meditating in the Dark Wood, the nun Somā is taunted by Māra, who claims that a mere woman can never see the subtle truth. She rejects him, stating that gender does not matter when one is perceiving deep truths, and telling Māra to go see those still attached to gender.
sn.sn5.3: Māra taunts the nun Kisāgotamī, alleging she is mourning sons and longing for a man. She rejects him, stating that she has no need for men, as she has destroyed the mass of darkness and conquered the army of Death.
sn.sn5.4: Māra comes to the nun Vijayā in the form of a handsome youth and tries to tempt her from her path. But she rejects sensual pleasures, as she delights in subtle meditation and has ended ignorance.
sn.sn5.5: Uppalavaṇṇā is rebuked by Māra, who says a beautiful woman like her should fear rogues when alone in the forest. However, she dismisses such fears, saying she can use her psychic powers to defeat thousands of rogues like him.
sn.sn5.6: Māra asks the nun Cālā why she disapproves of rebith. She replies that it necessarily entails suffering.
sn.sn5.7: Māra asks the nun Upacālā where she wishes to be reborn. But as the world everywhere is burning, she rejects all forms of rebirth.
sn.sn5.8: Māra asks the nun Sīsupacālā whose teaching she believes in. She replies that she rejects the various sectarians and follows the Buddha, as his teachings lead to freedom.
sn.sn5.9: Māra asks the nun Selā about who has created this “puppet”, i.e. the form that has been reincarnated. She replies that there is no creator, but it arises as a result of conditions, like the growing of a seed in a field.
sn.sn5.10: Māra asks the nun about who has created this being. Recognizing him, she points out that the word “being” is nothing more than a convention used to designate the aggregates, just as the word “cart” is used when the parts are assembled
sn.sn6.1: After his awakening, the Buddha hesitated to teach, thinking that the Dhamma is too subtle for people to understand. But the high divinity Brahmā Sahampati appears and encourages him to teach, pointing out that there are some with “little dust in their eyes” who will understand.
sn.sn6.2: After his awakening, the Buddha reflects that one should live with reverence; but who is he to revere, since he is fully awakened? He realizes that he should live revering the Dhamma. Brahmā Sahampati appears and agrees with him, saying that this is how all Buddhas of past and future live too.
sn.sn6.3: Brahmā Sahampati appears before a woman who is a devotee of his, and tells her to offer food instead to her son, a Buddhist monk, as Brahmās don’t eat the food she offers.
sn.sn6.4: Baka the Brahmā conceives the wrong view that his status is permanent and imperishable. The Buddha goes to dissuade him, and they have an exchange in verse, with the Buddha telling Baka of his past lives.
sn.sn6.5: An unnamed brahmā god thinks to himself that he is so powerful no asctic can approach him. The Buddha goes straight to his realm and appears wrapped in flame above his head. Mahāmoggallāna and several other disciples follow him. The brahmā and his retinue are sutiably impressed.
sn.sn6.6: The brahmās Subrahmā and Suddhāvāsa note that a fellow-brahmā is living in negligence, overly impressed with his own glory, so they go to shake him from his complacence.
sn.sn6.7: The brahmās Subrahmā and Suddhāvāsa come to the Buddha’s hut and speak on the monk Kokālika, a follower of Devadatta.
sn.sn6.8: The brahmās Subrahmā and Suddhāvāsa come to the Buddha’s hut and speak on the monk Katamorakatissaka, a follower of Devadatta.
sn.sn6.9: The brahmā Tudu tries to persuade Kokālika to have faith in Sāriputta and Moggallāna, but Kokālika wants none of it.
sn.sn6.10: Kokālika goes to the Buddha and criticizes Sāriputta and Moggallāna. But having deliberately slandered such great monks, he dies and Brahmā Sahampati informs the Buddha he has been reborn in hell. The Buddha gives a memorable simile of the length of life in hell.
sn.sn6.11: Brahmā Sanaṅkumāra appears to the Buddha and asserts that the aristocrat or khattiya is the best caste, but the Buddha is the best of people.
sn.sn6.12: Brahmā Sahampati, referring to Devadatta, points out that honors destroy a scoundrel.
sn.sn6.13: Brahmā Sahampati appears to the Buddha and speaks in praise of the renunciates staying fearless in the deep forest, and celebrates the many who have found freedom.
sn.sn6.14: The Buddha tells a story of the past Buddha Sikhī and his disciple Abhibhū. They visit a brahmā realm where they perform many astounding feats and give teachings.
sn.sn6.15: After the Buddha became finally extinguished, Brahmā Sahampati led a series of distinguished beings who uttered verses in commemoration
sn.sn7.1: When a brahmin lady expresses her confidence in the Triple Gem, her husband is annoyed. She encourages him to visit the Buddha, who soothes his anger.
sn.sn7.2: A brahmin visits the Buddha and unleashes a tirade of abuse, but the Buddha refuses to accept it, showing that he remains free of anger.
sn.sn7.3: A brahmin visits the Buddha and abuses him, but the Buddha responds only with patience.
sn.sn7.4: Hearing that a brahmin had gone forth under the Buddha, another brahmin was upset. But once again the Buddha calms him down, pointing out that anger only harms oneself.
sn.sn7.5: A brahmin called “Harmless” visits the Buddha, who teaches him the true meaning of harmlessness.
sn.sn7.6: A brahmin with matted hair asks the Buddha how we can become disentangled. This short set of verses became one of the most important in all of Theravāda Buddhism when it was used as the cornerstone of the commentarial treatise Visuddhimagga (Path of Purification).
sn.sn7.7: The brahmin Suddhika makes the strikingly Buddhist assertion that mere austerities don’t lead to purity; only knowledge and conduct do.
sn.sn7.8: A brahmin conducting a fire sacrifice invites the Buddha to accept the blessed milk-rice, claiming that the Buddha is a true brahmin.
sn.sn7.9: A brahmin conducting a fire sacrifice wishes to offer the sacrificial cake. He sees the Buddha meditating and wants to give it to him, but hesitates when he realizes he is a shaven-headed ascetic. He asks the Buddha’s caste, but the Buddha argues that conduct is the important thing, not caste. The Buddha gives a metaphorical reinterpretation of the elements of brahmanical ritual.
sn.sn7.10: A brahmin is searching for his lost oxen when he sees the Buddha meditating peacefully in the forest. He laments the many sorrows of his life, celebrating the Buddha’s happiness and freedom from such sorrows.
sn.sn7.11: A brahmin farmer criticizes the Buddha for failing to produce food, merely living off the work of others. But the Buddha shows that his true work is spiritual.
sn.sn7.12: A brahmin complains when the Buddha visits for alms again and again. The Buddha takes the chance to point out that all natural phenomena repeat in cycles, and only an awakened one escapes the cycle.
sn.sn7.13: The Buddha is ill and sends his attendant monk Upavāṇa to fetch some hot water. A brahmin gives him not just water, but also molasses to ease his stomach. Later the brahmin visits the Buddha to discuss generosity.
sn.sn7.14: A brahmin is shabby clothes has been kicked out of his home by ungrateful sons. The Buddha gives him a verse to recite in the village council, comparing his faithless sons to his trusty wooden staff. Ashamed, the sons take back their father, bathe and dress him.
sn.sn7.15: A stuck-up brahmin listening to the Buddha teach is awestruck when the Buddha appears to read his mind. To the surprise of the crowd, he bows and kisses the Buddha’s feet. The Buddha tells him to take his seat, and they exchange verses on the topic of conceit.
sn.sn7.16: A brahmin who loves to contradict everyone approaches the Buddha thinking to challenge him. But when he hears the Buddha speak, he cannot find anything to contradict.
sn.sn7.17: A brahmin is enjoying his work in the woods. Seeing the Buddha in meditation, he wonders what sort of work the Buddha enjoys.
sn.sn7.18: Some brahmin students are collecting firewood when they see the Buddha in meditation. They return and inform their teacher, who visits the Buddha to ask him how he is so peaceful in the wild forest.
sn.sn7.19: A brahmin wonders whether the legitimate seeking of alms is a proper way to support his parents.
sn.sn7.20: The Buddha explains that a true mendicant is one who has gone beyond evil.
sn.sn7.21: A brahmin believes that by bathing he can wash away his sins. But the Buddha speaks of the Dhamma as a lake for true purification.
sn.sn7.22: When the Buddha approaches a brahmin council in session, they complain that he is out of order.
sn.sn8.1: Enticed by the sight of beautiful women, the newly ordained monk Vaṅgīsa dispels desire and celebrates his commitment to the spiritual path in verse.
sn.sn8.2: Vaṅgīsa is troubled again by lust, but manages to dispel it through his own efforts. His verse speak of the way of the renunciate, letting go of desire and wrong views, and dedicated to ethical conduct and seclusion.
sn.sn8.3: As a renowned poet, Vaṅgīsa looked down on less skilled mendicants. Ashamed of his conceit, he exhorted himself in verse to be humble and at peace.
sn.sn8.4: Troubled once more by lust, Vaṅgīsa turned to Ānanda for support. Ānanda tells him to shift his perception so that beautiful things no longer seem so.
sn.sn8.5: The Buddha gives a simple teaching on four qualities of good speech. Vaṅgīsa is inspired to utter a more elaborate set of verses on the topic, praising especially the speech of the Buddha that leads to the Deathless.
sn.sn8.6: Seeing Sāriputta speak on the Dhamma, and the rapt attention of the Saṅgha, Vaṅgīsa comes out with verses in his praise.
sn.sn8.7: On the Pavāraṇā day at the end of the rains retreat, the Buddha invites the Saṅgha to admonish him. But not only is the Buddha faultless, so are all the 500 monks present. Vaṅgīsa is inspired to utter a elaborate praise of the Buddha.
sn.sn8.8: Seeing the Buddha speak on the Dhamma, and the rapt attention of the Saṅgha, Vaṅgīsa comes out with verses in his praise. When asked if the verses were spontaneous, he replies that they were, and the Buddha invites him to speak further.
sn.sn8.9: Aññā Koṇḍañña, the very first disciple to realize the Dhamma, comes to visit the Buddha after long in seclusion. Inspired, Vaṅgīsa speaks verses in his praise.
sn.sn8.10: Vaṅgīsa speaks in praise of Moggallāna and the Saṅgha.
sn.sn8.11: Vaṅgīsa says the Buddha, like the moon or the sun, outshines the whole world.
sn.sn8.12: Remembering his past as a wandering poet, Vaṅgīsa celebrates the freedom he has found in the Dhamma
sn.sn9.1: A monk in the forest lets his mind drift to thoughts of the lay life, but is warned by a local deity.
sn.sn9.2: When a mendicant falls asleep in the middle of the day, a deity tries to rouse them up. But not all is at it seems.
sn.sn9.3: A monk named Kassapagotta encounters a hunter in the forest and tries to dissuade him from his violent purpose. But a deity warns him not to waste his time.
sn.sn9.4: When a group of mendicants leave the forest in which they had been staying, the local deities lament their absence.
sn.sn9.5: A deity warns Ānanda about getting too involved with teaching lay folk.
sn.sn9.6: A former partner of Venerable Anuruddha, now a deity named Jālinī, tries to tempt him with heavenly pleasures. But he has seen a higher happiness.
sn.sn9.7: When Venerable Nāgadatta spends too much time in the village, a deity admonishes him.
sn.sn9.8: A deity becomes concerned of the gossip about a certain monk who had become close with a family in the village. Taking the form of one of the women of the family, she tries to warn him; but he says a true practitioner is not concerned with gossip.
sn.sn9.9: Hearing the sounds of a city festival, a mendicant feels lonely in the forest. A deity comes to give them solace and support.
sn.sn9.10: When a mendicant gives up their habit of reciting the texts, a deity questions them. But it seems they have now found peace.
sn.sn9.11: A mendicant plagued by bad thoughts is encouraged by a deity.
sn.sn9.12: A deity speaks of the fearfulness of the murmuring forest. But to a mendicant it seems delightful.
sn.sn9.13: A group of mendicants in the forest had fallen into bad ways, becoming conceited and confused. A deity came to admonish them, making clear that they were only speaking of the badly behaved, not all mendicants.
sn.sn9.14: A mendicant takes a bath in a pond and sniffs a lotus. A deity accuses him of being a “thief of scent”. For a person living a life of purity, even such a small matter is a cause for concern
sn.sn10.1: A local spirit asks the Buddha how a body is produced if there is no soul.
sn.sn10.2: A spirit tells the Buddha that if he is truly free he should not be instructing others.
sn.sn10.3: The spirits Khara and Sūciloma argue about whether the Buddha is a true ascetic or not. They approach him initially with threats, but then ask as to the origin of greed and hate.
sn.sn10.4: The spirit Maṇibhadda speaks in praise of mindfulness, opining that a mindful one is free of hate. The Buddha responds that yes, mindfulness is wonderful, but only through developing love is one free of hate.
sn.sn10.5: It seems that the novice Sānu had returned to his home intending to disrobe. To prevent him, a spirit possessed him, encouraging him to pursue the path of good. Sānu’s mother, weeping for her son, also tries to make him stay in robes.
sn.sn10.6: A female spirit hushes her son Piyaṅkara so she can hear the teaching and pursue harmlessness.
sn.sn10.7: A female spirit hushes her children as she listens to the teaching. But her son Punabbasu says that he had not been talking, as he too wants to learn.
sn.sn10.8: When Anāthapiṇḍika heard that a Buddha had arisen in the world, he rose first thing in the morning to go and visit him. But a mysterious darkness caused him to hesitate, so a spirit repeatedly encouraged him to step forward. Finally he reached the Buddha, and asked if he had slept well.
sn.sn10.9: A spirit was full of faith in the nun Sukkā, so he went about the towns and villages encouraging people to listen to her teaching.
sn.sn10.10: A spirit was full of faith in the nun Sukkā, so he went about the towns and villages singing the benefits of giving her offerings.
sn.sn10.11: A spirit was full of faith in the nun Cirā, so he went about the towns and villages singing the benefits of giving her offerings.
sn.sn10.12: The famous story of the spirit Āḷavaka, who tries to bully the Buddha, but is soon persuaded through a surprisingly insightful series of questions and answers. This discourse provided the background for several elaborate legends in the later traditions
sn.sn11.1: When Sakka, the Lord of Gods, tries to organize a counterattack against the demons, he is frustrated by his lazy general Suvīra. Sakka asks Suvīra how one might get what one wants without effort; but Suvīra apparently believes Sakka can grant any wish he wants. The Buddha emphasizes that if effort is valuable among the gods, how much more so for mendicants.
sn.sn11.2: When Sakka, the Lord of Gods, tries to organize a conterattack against the demons, he is frustrated by his lazy general Susīma. Sakka asks Suvīra how one might get what one wants without effort; but Suvīra apparently believes Sakka can grant any wish he wants. The Buddha emphasizes that if effort is valuable among the gods, how much more so for mendicants.
sn.sn11.3: Sakka rallies his troops with the sight of his banner. But the Buddha points out that the deities, powerful as they are, are not free of fear, but he is. He encourages the mendicants to recollect the Triple Gem to abandon fear.
sn.sn11.4: In a battle between the gods and the demons, and the demon lord Vepacitti is captured and brought in chains to Sakka’s hall. Vepacitti abuses Sakka, who endures his harsh words in patience. The charioteer Mātali asks whether he is silent out of weakness or fear, but Sakka says there is no point is wasting words arguing with a fool.
sn.sn11.5: The demon lord Vepacitti proposes to Sakka that they engage in a battle of wits in debate rather than war. Vepacitti speaks in praise of forceful punishment, while Sakka stands up for patience and forgiveness.
sn.sn11.6: Fleeing the demon host, Sakka’s chariot risks endangering the nests of little birds in the forest. Rather than render the birds homeless, Sakka instructs his charioteer to turn back, even at the cost of his life.
sn.sn11.7: Sakka reflects that one should not harm even one’s enemy. Knowing this, Vepacitti immediately takes advantage of it.
sn.sn11.8: Sakka, lord of gods, and Verocana, lord of demons, approach the Buddha’s hut and speak in praise of effort.
sn.sn11.9: In days gone by, Sakka, lord of gods, and Vepacitti, lord of demons, visited a hermitage of seers. But Vepacitti behaves rudely, while Sakka honors them. However, the seers beg Sakka to leave, on account of the stink of their unwashed bodies. But he says he loves their smell.
sn.sn11.10: In the past, when battle between the gods and demons loomed, some seers sought out the demon lord Sambara to beg for protection. But due to their devotion to Sakka, he rejected them, so they cursed him.
sn.sn11.11: Sakka achieved his status because of seven vows he kept in the past.
sn.sn11.12: Sakka’s many names arose due to the diverse good deeds he did in the past.
sn.sn11.13: Mahāli the Licchavi is skeptical as to whether the Buddha has really seen Sakka.
sn.sn11.14: The gods complain when a poor man is reborn in heaven. But Sakka points out that even though poor, he did many good deeds.
sn.sn11.15: When Sakka asks what place is truly delightful, the Buddha replies that it is wherever the perfected ones dwell.
sn.sn11.16: When Sakka asks where a gift is most fruitful, the Buddha replies that it is the Saṅgha.
sn.sn11.17: Sakka and Brahmā Sahampati come to the Buddha’s hut and speak in his praise.
sn.sn11.18: When Sakka sets out on a pleasure jaunt, he begins by lifting his joined palms to the four quarters . His charioteer Mātali points out that Sakka is venerated by gods and men, and asks who he is venerating. Sakka replies that he venerates both well-practiced mendicants as well as virtuous lay folk.
sn.sn11.19: When Sakka sets out on a pleasure jaunt, he begins by lifting his joined palms to the Buddha. His charioteer Mātali points out that Sakka is venerated by gods and men, and asks who he is venerating. Sakka replies that he venerates the Buddha, the perfected mendicants as well as trainees on the path.
sn.sn11.20: When Sakka sets out on a pleasure jaunt, he begins by lifting his joined palms to the Saṅgha of mendicants. His charioteer Mātal asks why Sakka venerates smelly mendicants. Sakka replies that he venerates them for their renunciation and peacefulness.
sn.sn11.21: Anger is the only thing whose slaying the Buddha commends.
sn.sn11.22: When an ugly spirit takes Sakka’s throne, the gods were outraged. But the more they complained, the prettier he became. Sakka realized this was the so-called “anger eating spirit”, and treated him with kindness and respect.
sn.sn11.23: When Vepacitti fell ill, Sakka visited his old adversary, who begged to be cured. But Sakka demanded to be taught a powerful magic spell first.
sn.sn11.24: When two mendicants have a falling out, the Buddha recalls the wise words of Sakka on not letting anger ruin friendship.
sn.sn11.25: The Buddha recalls the words of Sakka warning of how anger crushes people like an avalanche
sn.sn12.1: The famous twelve links of dependent origination are spelled out, showing the origin and cessation of suffering dependent on ignorance.
sn.sn12.2: The Buddha gives definitions for each of the twelve links. These are general definitions that apply wherever the twelve links are mentioned.
sn.sn12.3: The origin of suffering is the wrong way, the end is the right way.
sn.sn12.4: In the far past, the Buddha Vipassī reflected on how the world had fallen into suffering, and became awakened by understanding dependent origination.
sn.sn12.5: In the far past, the Buddha Sikhī reflected on how the world had fallen into suffering, and became awakened by understanding dependent origination.
sn.sn12.6: In the far past, the Buddha Vessabhū reflected on how the world had fallen into suffering, and became awakened by understanding dependent origination.
sn.sn12.7: In the far past, the Buddha Kakusandha reflected on how the world had fallen into suffering, and became awakened by understanding dependent origination.
sn.sn12.8: In the far past, the Buddha Koṇāgamana reflected on how the world had fallen into suffering, and became awakened by understanding dependent origination.
sn.sn12.9: In the far past, the Buddha Kassapa reflected on how the world had fallen into suffering, and became awakened by understanding dependent origination.
sn.sn12.10: The current Buddha Gotama, reflecting on how the world had fallen into suffering, became awakened by understanding dependent origination.
sn.sn12.11: The Buddha defines the four kinds of “food” or “nutriment”, which include edible food, contact, intention, and consciousness. These are all produced by craving, and hence connect with dependent origination.
sn.sn12.12: Venerable Moḷiyaphagguna asks who eats the consciousness food. The Buddha says the question is improper, as it assumes a self as agent. Rather, all the factors of dependent origination are simply natural conditions and have nothing to do with a “self”.
sn.sn12.13: One who does not understand dependent origination is no true ascetic.
sn.sn12.14: One who does not understand dependent origination is no true ascetic.
sn.sn12.15: Venerable Kaccānagotta asks the Buddha about right view, and the Buddha answers that right view arises when one sees the origin and cessation of the world and is free of attachments. This sutta, brief but profound and difficult, became renowned as the only canonical reference named in Nāgārjuna’s Mūlamadhyamakakārikā, perhaps the most famous philosophical treatise in all Buddhism.
sn.sn12.16: One is qualified to be called a “Dhamma speaker” if one teaches for the ending of suffering.
sn.sn12.17: A naked ascetic named Kassapa approaches the Buddha while he is on alms round and asks whether suffering is created by oneself, by another, by both, or by chance. Explaining why he rejects all these options, the Buddha asserts that suffering arises due to conditions.
sn.sn12.18: A wanderer named Timbaruka approaches the Buddha while he is on alms round and asks whether pleasure and pain are created by oneself, by another, by both, or by chance. Explaining why he rejects all these options, the Buddha asserts that suffering arises due to conditions.
sn.sn12.19: Both the wise and the foolish have been reborn in this life due to their deeds conditioned by ignorance in past lives. But a fool continues to make the same mistakes and is reborn yet again, whereas a wise person does not.
sn.sn12.20: The Buddha distinguishes between “dependently originated phenomena”—the twelve factors—and “dependent origination”—the principle of conditionality. Someone who understands these things no longer worries about the past or future.
sn.sn12.21: The Buddha’s teaching rests on his possession of ten powers and four grounds for self-confidence.
sn.sn12.22: The Buddha’s teaching rests on his possession of ten powers and four grounds for self-confidence. When hearing such an open teaching, a mendicant puts forth great effort, considering the good for both themselves and for others.
sn.sn12.23: The ending of defilements comes only when the truth is seen. But seeing the truth comes about due to a vital condition. In this way, twelve factors leading to freedom are united with the twelve factors leading to suffering.
sn.sn12.24: Sāriputta is asked by various ascetics as to the origin of suffering. He replies that the Buddha teaches that suffering originates by conditions. Moreover, all those who offer opinions as to the source of suffering are themselves part of the web of conditions, as they cannot state their views without contact. Ānanda reports the exchange to the Buddha, who praises Sāriputta’s answer.
sn.sn12.25: Sāriputta is asked by Venerable Bhūmija as to the origin of pleasure and pain. He replies that the Buddha teaches that pleasure and pain originate by conditions. Moreover, all those who offer opinions as to the source of suffering are themselves part of the web of conditions, as they cannot state their views without contact. Ānanda reports the exchange to the Buddha, who praises Sāriputta’s answer.
sn.sn12.26: The Buddha is asked by Venerable Upavāṇa as to the origin of suffering. He replies that suffering originates by conditions. Moreover, all those who offer opinions as to the source of suffering are themselves part of the web of conditions, as they cannot state their views without contact.
sn.sn12.27: Dependent origination is framed within the four noble truths.
sn.sn12.28: A mendicant who understands dependent origination is a trainee who is accomplished in view.
sn.sn12.29: An ascetic who understands dependent origination will realize the goal of the ascetic life.
sn.sn12.30: An ascetic who understands dependent origination may well escape those conditions.
sn.sn12.31: The Buddha asks Sāriputta to explain a verse from “The Questions of Ajita” in the Parāyana (Snp 5.2). At first, Sāriputta hesitates, but proceeds when the Buddha indicates he is looking for an answer in terms of conditionality.
sn.sn12.32: A mendicant named Kaḷāra the Khattiya informs Sāriputta that the mendicant Moḷiyaphagguna had disrobed. Overinterpreting Sāriputta’s reply, Kaḷāra reports to the Buddha that Sāriputta had claimed to have ended all defilements. The Buddha calls Sāriputta to clarify his statements, and Sāriputta explains in terms of dependent origination.
sn.sn12.33: An analysis of 44 contexts for developing insight with regard to dependent origination. This includes an important distinction between knowledge arising from direct vision of the present, and that derived from inference as to the past and future.
sn.sn12.34: An analysis of 77 contexts for developing insight with regard to dependent origination.
sn.sn12.35: A mendicant asks who possesses old and death, and the other factors. The Buddha says the question is improper, as it assumes a self as agent. Rather, dependent origination is the teaching “by the middle”, explaining phenomena according to natural conditions.
sn.sn12.36: The content of this discourse is identical with SN 12.35, except presented as a general teaching by the Buddha, without an questioner.
sn.sn12.37: The body is not yours, but is old kamma, generated by choices in past lives.
sn.sn12.38: Intentions or choices are the force that propels consciousness from one life to the next.
sn.sn12.39: Intentions or choices are the force that propels consciousness from one life to the next.
sn.sn12.40: Intentions or choices are the force that propels consciousness from one life to the next.
sn.sn12.41: A noble disciple who is a layperson has eliminated the fear that comes from breaking precepts, possesses the four factors of stream-entry, and understands dependent origination.
sn.sn12.42: A noble disciple who is a layperson has eliminated the fear that comes from breaking precepts, possesses the four factors of stream-entry, and understands dependent origination.
sn.sn12.43: The origin and ending of suffering are explained in terms of sense experience giving rise to craving.
sn.sn12.44: The origin and ending of the world are explained in terms of sense experience giving rise to craving and suffering.
sn.sn12.45: While on retreat, the Buddha exclaims how the origin and ending of the world are explained in terms of sense experience giving rise to craving and suffering. A mendicant overhears him, and the Buddha urges him to remember that teaching.
sn.sn12.46: A brahmin asks whether the person who acts is the same or different to the person who receives the result. The Buddha rejects both views as extreme.
sn.sn12.47: The brahmin Jāṇussoṇi asks the Buddha whether all exists or nothing exists. The Buddha rejects both views as extreme.
sn.sn12.48: A brahmin cosmologist asks the Buddha whether all exists or nothing exists. The Buddha rejects both views as extreme.
sn.sn12.49: A noble disciple does not wonder about the links of dependent origination, as they see it for themselves, independent of others.
sn.sn12.50: A noble disciple does not wonder about the links of dependent origination, as they see it for themselves, independent of others.
sn.sn12.51: A mendicant should thoroughly investigate the causes of suffering in accordance with dependent origination. If someone who still has ignorance makes a choice, their consciousness fares on to a suitable state of existence. But one who has eradicated ignorance is detached and is not reborn anywhere.
sn.sn12.52: Craving increases when you linger on pleasing things that stimulate grasping, illustrated with the simile of a bonfire.
sn.sn12.53: Craving increases when you linger on pleasing things that stimulate fetters, illustrated with the simile of a lamp.
sn.sn12.54: Craving increases when you linger on pleasing things that stimulate fetters, illustrated with the simile of a lamp.
sn.sn12.55: Craving increases when you linger on pleasing things that stimulate grasping, illustrated with the simile of a tree.
sn.sn12.56: Craving increases when you linger on pleasing things that stimulate grasping, illustrated with the simile of a tree.
sn.sn12.57: Craving increases when you linger on pleasing things that stimulate fetters, illustrated with the simile of a sapling.
sn.sn12.58: The mental and physical organism is reborn when you linger on pleasing things that stimulate fetters, illustrated with the simile of a tree.
sn.sn12.59: Consciousness is reborn when you linger on pleasing things that stimulate fetters, illustrated with the simile of a tree.
sn.sn12.60: When Ānanda suggests that dependent origination is simple, the Buddha rebukes him. The opening of this is similar to DN 14 Mahānidāna.
sn.sn12.61: An ignorant person might become free of attachment to their body, but not their mind. Still, it would be better to attach to the body, as it is less changeable than the mind, which jumps about like a monkey.
sn.sn12.62: An ignorant person might become free of attachment to their body, but not their mind. Still, it would be better to attach to the body, as it is less changeable than the mind. But a noble disciple reflects on dependent origination.
sn.sn12.63: The Buddha defines the four kinds of “food” or “nutriment”, which include edible food, contact, intention, and consciousness. He illustrates them with a series of powerful and horrifying similes.
sn.sn12.64: The Buddha defines the four kinds of “food” or “nutriment”, which include edible food, contact, intention, and consciousness, showing how they lead to suffering according to dependent origination.
sn.sn12.65: The Buddha the story of how his awakening came about through investigation into dependent origination. He compares it to man discovering and ancient city, lost and overgrown with weeds.
sn.sn12.66: The right way to investigate inside oneself is to see how suffering is created craving and attachment, stimulated by pleasant experiences.
sn.sn12.67: Venerables Mahākoṭṭhita and Sāriputta discuss whether the factors of dependent origination are created by oneself, another, both, or by chance.
sn.sn12.68: Venerable Saviṭṭha questions Venerable Musīla about his attainments, and concludes he is an arahant. But Venerable Nārada offers an explanation showing that it is possible to see the Dhamma without having fully realized arahantship.
sn.sn12.69: Like rivers flowing to the ocean, the factors of dependent origination lead to suffering.
sn.sn12.70: The wanderer Susı̄ma fraudulently enters the Sangha so that the wanderers can learn the secret to the Buddha’s fame and success. Hearing that some mendicants claimed to be perfected, Susīma approaches and asks them if they have developed psychic powers or the formless states, to which they say no. Perplexed, he asks the Buddha, who explains that awakening follows insight into the principles of impermanence and causality. Eventually Susı̄ma confesses his misdeed.
sn.sn12.71: One who does not understand aging and death is no true ascetic.
sn.sn12.72-81: One who does not understand the various factors of dependent origination is no true ascetic.
sn.sn12.82: One who does not understand the various factors of dependent origination should seek a teacher.
sn.sn13.1: For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the great earth; what remains is like the dirt under a fingernail.
sn.sn13.2: For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the water in a massive dam; what remains is like a few drops on a blade of grass.
sn.sn13.3: For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the water at the confluence of great rivers; what remains is like a few drops.
sn.sn13.4: For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the water at the confluence of great rivers; what remains is like a few drops.
sn.sn13.5: For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the great earth; what remains is like seven balls of clay.
sn.sn13.6: For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the great earth; what remains is like seven balls of clay.
sn.sn13.7: For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the water in the ocean; what remains is like a few drops.
sn.sn13.8: For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the water in the ocean; what remains is like a few drops.
sn.sn13.9: For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the Himalayas; what remains is like seven bits of gravel.
sn.sn13.10: For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the Himalayas; what remains is like seven bits of gravel.
sn.sn13.11: For someone who has seen the truth, the suffering eliminated is like the Sineru, king of mountains; what remains is like seven bits of gravel
sn.sn14.1: The senses function due to the various different elements of sense experience, namely, the internal sense organ, the external sense stimulus, and consciousness.
sn.sn14.2: The diverse internal elements of sense experience give rise to diverse contacts.
sn.sn14.3: It is not the case that diverse contacts give rise to the diverse elements of sense experience.
sn.sn14.4: Diverse contacts give rise to diverse feelings.
sn.sn14.5: It is not the case that diverse feelings give rise to diverse contacts.
sn.sn14.6: The senses function due to the various different external elements of sense experience, namely, the various sense stimuli.
sn.sn14.7: The diverse external elements of sense experience give rise to diverse perceptions, intentions, desires, passions, and quests.
sn.sn14.8: It is not the case that diverse perceptions, intentions, desires, passions, and quests give rise to diverse external elements of sense experience.
sn.sn14.9: The diverse external elements of sense experience give rise to diverse perceptions, intentions, desires, passions, quests, and material possessions.
sn.sn14.10: It is not the case that diverse perceptions, intentions, desires, passions, quests, and material possessions give rise to diverse external elements of sense experience.
sn.sn14.11: A rare group of seven elements: light, beauty, the four formless states, and the attainment of cessation. Each of these is known due to the negation of something: light vs. darkness, beauty vs. ugliness, and so on.
sn.sn14.12: Thoughts of sensuality, ill-will, and delusion arise due to a series of causes.
sn.sn14.13: When unenlightened people have the view that certain people are Buddhas, this is due to ignorance.
sn.sn14.14: People of poor character associate together, while people of good character associate together.
sn.sn14.15: The Buddha points out that each of the great disciples has a retinue of students of a similar character. And the monks in Devadattas’s retinue all have evil wishes.
sn.sn14.16: People of poor character associate together, while people of good character associate together. Illustrated with similes and verses.
sn.sn14.17: The faithless and those of other bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
sn.sn14.18: Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
sn.sn14.19: Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
sn.sn14.20: Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
sn.sn14.21: Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
sn.sn14.22: Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
sn.sn14.23: Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
sn.sn14.24: Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
sn.sn14.25: Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
sn.sn14.26: Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
sn.sn14.27: Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
sn.sn14.28: Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
sn.sn14.29: Those of bad qualities associate together, while those of good qualities associate together.
sn.sn14.30: The four material elements of earth, water, heat, and air. Note that “air” is close in meaning to “wind”.
sn.sn14.31: Before his awakening the Buddha saw the gratification, the drawback, and the escape in the four material elements.
sn.sn14.32: The Buddha set out to discover the gratification, the drawback, and the escape in the four material elements, and found it.
sn.sn14.33: Each of the three aspects of the four material elements performs its own function. Gratification stimulates desire; drawbacks lead to disillusionment, while escape opens the possibility of freedom.
sn.sn14.34: If the material elements were solely painful, beings would not get attached. If they were solely pleasurable, it would be impossible to become detached.
sn.sn14.35: When you seek pleasure in the material elements, you seek pleasure in suffering.
sn.sn14.36: The arising of the material elements is the arising of suffering.
sn.sn14.37: One who does not understand the four material elements is no true ascetic.
sn.sn14.38: One who does not understand the four material elements is no true ascetic.
sn.sn14.39: One who does not understand the four material elements is no true ascetic.
sn.sn15.1: Transmigration is endless, like the grass and twigs in India.
sn.sn15.2: Transmigration is endless, like the great earth.
sn.sn15.3: The tears you have shed in transmigration are greater than the waters in the oceans.
sn.sn15.4: The mother’s milk you have drunk in transmigration is greater than the waters in the oceans.
sn.sn15.5: A great mountain would erode before the end of the eon.
sn.sn15.6: A city filled with mustard seeds might be emptied before the end of an eon.
sn.sn15.7: Even recollecting 100,000 eons per day you’ll never remember the beginning of transmigration.
sn.sn15.8: There have been more eons than the sands in the Ganges river.
sn.sn15.9: Like a stick falling on this side or that, beings are reborn in different realms.
sn.sn15.10: The bones you’ve left behind in transmigration are greater than a mountain.
sn.sn15.11: When you see someone suffer, know that you too have experienced that.
sn.sn15.12: When you see someone happy, know that you too have experienced that.
sn.sn15.13: The blood you have shed from being slaughtered or beheaded in transmigration is greater than the waters in the oceans.
sn.sn15.14: It is not easy to find a being who has not been your mother.
sn.sn15.15: It is not easy to find a being who has not been your father.
sn.sn15.16: It is not easy to find a being who has not been your brother.
sn.sn15.17: It is not easy to find a being who has not been your sister.
sn.sn15.18: It is not easy to find a being who has not been your son.
sn.sn15.19: It is not easy to find a being who has not been your daughter.
sn.sn15.20: The Buddha recounts how peoples of the past had different names for the mountains of Rājagaha. Yet now they have all gone
sn.sn16.1: Kassapa is content with robes, alms-food, lodging, and medicines.
sn.sn16.2: Sāriputta approaches Kassapa and asks how it is that only someone who is keen and conscientious can realize freedom.
sn.sn16.3: Kassapa approaches families like the moon, with humility, keeping his distance, and not getting involved. So when he teaches, it is with pure intentions.
sn.sn16.4: Some mendicants approach families in the hope of receiving fine gifts or respect—but not Kassapa.
sn.sn16.5: The Buddha points out that Kassapa has grown old, and urges him to give up his ascetic life and stay in a comfortable monastery.
sn.sn16.6: The Buddha invites Kassapa to teach the mendicants, but he is reluctant, since certain students of Anuruddha and Ānanda have been competing to see who can teach better.
sn.sn16.7: The Buddha invites Kassapa to teach the mendicants, but he is reluctant, saying that the mendicants have become stubborn and their good qualities are declining.
sn.sn16.8: The Buddha invites Kassapa to teach the mendicants, but he is reluctant, saying that the senior mendicants used to set a good example, but now instead of respecting good practice, they respect fame and fortune.
sn.sn16.9: The Buddha asserts that just as he has full mastery of all the meditation attainments and higher spiritual realizations, so does Kassapa.
sn.sn16.10: When Kassapa is persuaded by Ānanda to go with him to teach the nuns, the nun Thullatissā compares him unfavorably to Ānanda, prompting Kassapa to issue a warning and make a bold claim of his spiritual mastery. This discourse appears to be set after the Buddha’s passing.
sn.sn16.11: When several of Ānanda’s students disrobe, Kassapa admonishes him, calling him “boy”. The nun Thullanandā hears of this and criticizes Kassapa, claiming he formerly followed another teacher. But Kassapa refutes this, and gives an account of his going forth and first encounter with the Buddha.
sn.sn16.12: Sāriputta asks Kassapa about whether a Realized One survives death.
sn.sn16.13: Kassapa asks the Buddha why there are now more rules but fewer awakened mendicants. The Buddha replies that it is due to the arising of the counterfeit Dhamma, giving five factors that lead to decline
sn.sn17.1: Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, obstructing spiritual progress.
sn.sn17.2: Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, which catch you like fish on a hook.
sn.sn17.3: Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, which hit you like a harpoon hits a careless turtle.
sn.sn17.4: Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, which snare you like a long-haired goat in a briar patch.
sn.sn17.5: A mendicant who is proud on account of their material possessions, honor, and praise is like a dung beetle proud of their ball of dung.
sn.sn17.6: Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, like a lightning strike.
sn.sn17.7: Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, like a poison dart.
sn.sn17.8: A mendicant who is proud on account of their material possessions, honor, and praise is never at peace, like a mangy jackal.
sn.sn17.9: A mendicant who is proud on account of their material possessions, honor, and praise is never at peace, like a bird in a gale.
sn.sn17.10: Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, and attachment to them leads to a bad rebirth.
sn.sn17.11: Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, which can corrupt the mind even of a pure mendicant.
sn.sn17.12: Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, which can corrupt the mind even of a pure mendicant.
sn.sn17.13-20: Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, which can corrupt the mind even of a pure mendicant.
sn.sn17.21: Material possessions, honor, and praise can be even more tempting than a woman.
sn.sn17.22: Material possessions, honor, and praise can be even more tempting than the finest lady in the land.
sn.sn17.23: A laywoman should wish that if her son remains in the household life, he should be like Citta and Hatthaka. But if he becomes a monk, may material possessions, honor, and praise not come to him!
sn.sn17.24: A laywoman should wish that if her daughter remains in the household life, she should be like Khujjuttarā and Veḷukaṇḍakiyā. But if she becomes a nun, may material possessions, honor, and praise not come to her!
sn.sn17.25: Someone who doesn’t fully understand material possessions, honor, and praise is no true ascetic.
sn.sn17.26: Someone who doesn’t fully understand material possessions, honor, and praise is no true ascetic.
sn.sn17.27: Someone who doesn’t fully understand material possessions, honor, and praise is no true ascetic.
sn.sn17.28: Material possessions, honor, and praise cut to the bone.
sn.sn17.29: Material possessions, honor, and praise cut to the bone, like a rope.
sn.sn17.30: Material possessions, honor, and praise are even a problem for a perfected one, as they interfere with their meditation.
sn.sn17.31: Devadatta provoked a schism due to material possessions, honor, and praise.
sn.sn17.32: Devadatta’s wholesome root was cut off due to material possessions, honor, and praise.
sn.sn17.33: Devadatta’s wholesome nature was cut off due to material possessions, honor, and praise.
sn.sn17.34: Devadatta’s bright nature was cut off due to material possessions, honor, and praise.
sn.sn17.35: Material possessions, honor, and praise led to Devadatta’s downfall, like the fruit of a plantain.
sn.sn17.36: Prince Ajātasattu supplied devadatta with 500 carts of offerings, leading to his downfall.
sn.sn17.37-43: Material possessions, honor, and praise are terrible things, which can corrupt the mind even of the pure
sn.sn18.1: The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on the internal sense organs in light of the three characteristics.
sn.sn18.2: The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on the external sense objects in light of the three characteristics.
sn.sn18.3: The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on sense consciousness in light of the three characteristics.
sn.sn18.4: The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on sense contact in light of the three characteristics.
sn.sn18.5: The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on feelings in light of the three characteristics.
sn.sn18.6: The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on perceptions in light of the three characteristics.
sn.sn18.7: The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on intentions in light of the three characteristics.
sn.sn18.8: The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on cravings in light of the three characteristics.
sn.sn18.9: The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on the four material elements in light of the three characteristics.
sn.sn18.10: The Buddha answers Rāhula’s request by teaching on the five aggregates in light of the three characteristics.
sn.sn18.11: The Buddha teaches Rāhula about the internal sense organs in light of the three characteristics.
sn.sn18.12-20: The Buddha teaches Rāhula about the senses, aggregates, and elements in light of the three characteristics.
sn.sn18.21: Rāhula asks how to see so that conceit no longer occurs. The Buddha teaches him to investigate the five aggregates in terms of not-self.
sn.sn18.22: Rāhula asks how to see so conceit no longer occurs and one is peaceful. The Buddha teaches him to investigate the five aggregates in terms of not-self
sn.sn19.1: While walking for alms down Vulture’s Peak, Venerable Moggallāna smiled at something invisible. Later, he told the Buddha it was a skeleton flying through the air, being pecked at by vultures. The Buddha confirmed that the man he had seen had been a butcher in his past life
sn.sn20.1: As rafters depend on the roof-peak, unwholesome qualities depend on ignorance.
sn.sn20.2: As the dirt in a fingernail is smaller than the great earth, the beings reborn as humans are few.
sn.sn20.3: As a family with few men and many women is easily attacked, non-human beings may attack a mendicant without love.
sn.sn20.4: Love is more beneficial than generosity.
sn.sn20.5: As it is not possible to bend back a spear, it is not possible to overthrow a mendicant who has developed love.
sn.sn20.6: Only a speedster could catch arrows in flight, yet conditioned phenomena perish faster than that.
sn.sn20.7: As an ancient drum has disintegrated, so too will the true teachings disappear.
sn.sn20.8: Warriors who sleep on wooden pillows remain vigilant, and so it is for the spiritual seeker.
sn.sn20.9: A mendicant who overly associates with the laity is like an elephant calf who tries to copy the great bull elephants.
sn.sn20.10: As a cat may suffer from eating too hastily, so a mendicant may suffer by not restraining senses.
sn.sn20.11: A mangy jackal howls in discomfort, but even that would be a good rebirth for some.
sn.sn20.12: An old jackal howls at dawn, but even they have more gratitude than some
sn.sn21.1: Moggallāna reflects that second absorption is the true noble silence, and the Buddha encourages him to develop it.
sn.sn21.2: Sāriputta says that there is nothing whose change, even the Buddha, would cause him sorrow.
sn.sn21.3: Sāriputta and Moggallāna come together for a discussion, which touches on the use of psychic powers and energy. The two great monks end up warmly praising each other.
sn.sn21.4: When a certain monk neglects his duties in favor of solitude, other monks complain. The Buddha questions him, and finds that he is awakened.
sn.sn21.5: The Buddha praises Venerable Sujāta as beautiful both inside and out.
sn.sn21.6: Venerable Lakuṇṭaka Bhaddiya is a dwarf, considered to be ugly and unsightly. The Buddha warns the monks not to despise him as he had realized full awakening.
sn.sn21.7: The Buddha praises Venerable Visākha Pañcāliputta for teaching the Dhamma.
sn.sn21.8: Venerable Nanda wore pretty robes, a fancy bowl, and makeup, so the Buddha encouraged him to embrace simplicity.
sn.sn21.9: Venerable Tissa admonished others but got upset when he was admonished. The Buddha encourages him to let go of his anger.
sn.sn21.10: A monk named “Senior” likes to live alone, but the Buddha questions whether it is the true solitude.
sn.sn21.11: The Buddha describes Venerable Mahākappina as thin, fair-skinned, with a big nose—and as awakened.
sn.sn21.12: The Buddha praises two friends who are students of Venerable Mahākappina
sn.sn22.1: The householder Nakulapitā asks the Buddha for help in coping with old age. The Buddha says to reflect: “Even though I am afflicted in body, my mind will be unafflicted.” Later Sāriputta explains this in terms of the five aggregates.
sn.sn22.2: A number of mendicants are heading for lands west, but the Buddha advises them to speak with Sāriputta before they go. Sāriputta reminds them that in foreign lands they will be scrutinized for their understanding, so they need to be able to answer questions on the teaching. He goes on to explain that the Dhamma is for the removal of desire  for the five aggregates.
sn.sn22.3: The householder Hāliddakāni approaches the Venerable Mahākaccāna in the Avanti country and asks how to understand a verse from “The Questions of Māgandiya” of the Aṭṭhakavagga (Snp 4.9). Though the verse appears to be pitched at an ethical level, describing a sage intimate with none in the village, Mahākaccāna explains it in philosophical terms as non-attachment to the aggregates.
sn.sn22.4: The householder Hāliddakāni approaches the Venerable Mahākaccāna in the Avanti country and asks how to understand a passage on liberation from “The Questions of Sakka” (see MN 37 and DN 21). Mahākaccāna explains it in terms of freedom from attachment to the aggregates.
sn.sn22.5: A mendicant should develop immersion (samādhi) in order to truly understand the origin and ending of the five aggregates.
sn.sn22.6: A mendicant should make an effort in seclusion in order to truly understand the origin and ending of the five aggregates.
sn.sn22.7: An ordinary person identifies their self with the five aggregates and suffers anxiety when the aggregates change. But a noble disciple, free of such identification, does not suffer.
sn.sn22.8: An ordinary person identifies their self with the five aggregates and suffers anxiety when the aggregates change. But a noble disciple, free of such identification, does not suffer.
sn.sn22.9: The aggregates are impermanent in the past and future as in the present.
sn.sn22.10: The aggregates are suffering in the past and future as in the present.
sn.sn22.11: The aggregates are not-self in the past and future as in the present.
sn.sn22.12: Because the aggregates are impermanent, a noble disciple becomes disillusioned with them.
sn.sn22.13: Because the aggregates are suffering, a noble disciple becomes disillusioned with them.
sn.sn22.14: Because the aggregates are not-self, a noble disciple becomes disillusioned with them.
sn.sn22.15: One should truly understand the five aggregates as impermanent, etc.
sn.sn22.16: One should truly understand the five aggregates as suffering, etc.
sn.sn22.17: One should truly understand the five aggregates as not-self.
sn.sn22.18: Since the causes of the aggregates are impermanent, how can the aggregates be permanent?
sn.sn22.19: Since the causes of the aggregates are suffering, how can the aggregates be free of suffering?
sn.sn22.20: Since the causes of the aggregates are not-self, how can the aggregates be self?
sn.sn22.21: Ānanda asks the Buddha what exactly is meant when we say that things cease. The Buddha explains it as the cessation of the aggregates.
sn.sn22.22: The aggregates are the burden, a person carries that burden, craving takes up the burden, and letting go puts down the burden.
sn.sn22.23: The aggregates are to be fully understood, and the full understanding is the ending of defilements.
sn.sn22.24: Only by directly knowing the aggregates can one end suffering.
sn.sn22.25: By letting go desire, the aggregates come to an end.
sn.sn22.26: Before his awakening, the Buddha investigated the aggregates in terms of their gratification, drawback, and escape.
sn.sn22.27: When the Buddha fully knew the gratification, drawback, and escape regarding the five aggregates he became awakened.
sn.sn22.28: Beings are attached to the five aggregates due to gratification, repelled due to drawbacks, and find escape because there is an escape.
sn.sn22.29: If you enjoy the aggregates, you enjoy suffering.
sn.sn22.30: The arising of the aggregates is the arising of suffering.
sn.sn22.31: The aggregates are misery, desire for them is the root of misery.
sn.sn22.32: The aggregates are fragile and their passing is not fragile.
sn.sn22.33: Let go of what is not yours: the five aggregates. You wouldn’t be upset if someone took the grass and sticks from the monastery grounds, so why worry over the aggregates?
sn.sn22.34: Let go of what is not yours: the five aggregates.
sn.sn22.35: The Buddha teaches a mendicant who wants to go on retreat that one is reckoned by what one has an underlying tendency for. The mendicant gives a full explanation.
sn.sn22.36: The Buddha teaches a mendicant who wants to go on retreat that one is measured by what one has an underlying tendency for. The mendicant gives a full explanation.
sn.sn22.37: The Buddha speaks to Ānanda on what at AN 3.47 described as the “characteristics of conditioned phenomena”: arising, ceasing, and change while persisting. This was to become a critical aspect of later theories on the nature of change. Ānanda explains in terms of the aggregates.
sn.sn22.38: The Buddha speaks to Ānanda on what at AN 3.47 described as the “characteristics of conditioned phenomena”: arising, ceasing, and change while persisting, as applied to past, future, and present. Ānanda explains in terms of the aggregates.
sn.sn22.39: To practice in line with the teachings a mendicant should meditate on disillusionment with the aggregates.
sn.sn22.40: To practice in line with the teachings a mendicant should meditate on the aggregates as impermanent.
sn.sn22.41: To practice in line with the teachings a mendicant should meditate on the aggregates as suffering.
sn.sn22.42: To practice in line with the teachings a mendicant should meditate on the aggregates as not-self.
sn.sn22.43: Dwell with yourself as an island and refuge, with the Dhamma as an island and refuge. How? By investigating how suffering arises from identification with the aggregates.
sn.sn22.44: Contemplation of the five aggregates as not-self is the path to the end of identity.
sn.sn22.45: Seeing the five aggregates as impermanent, etc., leads to freedom.
sn.sn22.46: Seeing the five aggregates as impermanent, etc., leads to letting go of views and ultimately to freedom.
sn.sn22.47: When you identify anything as self, you always identify one or other of the five aggregates.
sn.sn22.48: The distinction between “five aggregates” and “five grasping aggregates”.
sn.sn22.49: The Buddha teaches a householder named Soṇa not to be conceited about the five aggregates.
sn.sn22.50: The Buddha teaches a householder named Soṇa that any true ascetic understands the five aggregates.
sn.sn22.51: Right view is seeing the aggregates as they are, impermanent, and this leads to freedom.
sn.sn22.52: Focusing properly on the five aggregates you see them are they are and become free.
sn.sn22.53: Consciousness stands dependent on the other four aggregates, and this attachment is what fuels the cycle of rebirth.
sn.sn22.54: Consciousness is like a seed that is planted in the soil of the other four aggregates and watered with craving.
sn.sn22.55: The Buddha utters an enigmatic saying that non-identification leads to cutting off the fetters. A mendicant asks how to achieve this.
sn.sn22.56: The Buddha did not claim to be awakened until he had fully understood each of the five aggregates in the light of each of the four noble truths. This discourse includes definitions of each of the aggregates.
sn.sn22.57: To be fully accomplished, a mendicant should investigate the five aggregates in light of the four noble truths, as well as their gratification, drawback, and escape. In addition, they should investigate the elements, sense fields, and dependent origination.
sn.sn22.58: The Buddha declares that a mendicant is freed by wisdom by non-attachment to the aggregates, in just the same way as he himself. He then explains that the difference between himself and another awakened mendicant is simply that he was the first to discover the path and teach it to others.
sn.sn22.59: In the Deer Park at Varanasi the Buddha teaches the famous second discourse, on not-self with regard to the aggregates, to the group of five monks. At the conclusion, they become perfected ones.
sn.sn22.60: Mahāli the Licchavi reports to the Buddha that the rival teacher Pūraṇa Kassapa asserts that there is no reason for beings to be either defiled or pure. The Buddha denies this, and goes on to explain how it happens.
sn.sn22.62: All philosophers must accept that the five aggregates are described in language that refers to either the past, future, or present.
sn.sn22.63: A mendicant comes to the Buddha to ask for instructions before going on retreat. The Buddha teaches them that in clinging to the aggregates one is bound by Māra.
sn.sn22.64: In conceiving regarding the aggregates one is bound by Māra.
sn.sn22.65: In seeking enjoyment in the aggregates one is bound by Māra.
sn.sn22.66: One should let go of desire for what is impermanent, namely the five aggregates.
sn.sn22.67: One should let go of desire for what is suffering, namely the five aggregates.
sn.sn22.68: One should let go of desire for what is not-self, namely the five aggregates.
sn.sn22.69: One should let go of desire for what does not belong to self, namely the five aggregates.
sn.sn22.70: One should let go of desire for what appears tantalizing, namely the five aggregates.
sn.sn22.71: Venerable Rādha asks the Buddha how to see so as to let go of conceit. The Buddha tells him to contemplate the aggregates in terms of not-self.
sn.sn22.72: Venerable Surādha asks the Buddha how to see so as to let go of conceit and be freed. The Buddha tells him to contemplate the aggregates in terms of not-self.
sn.sn22.73: Only a noble disciple truly understand the five aggregates’ gratification, drawback, and escape.
sn.sn22.74: Only a noble disciple truly understand the five aggregates’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.
sn.sn22.75: Only a noble disciple truly understand the five aggregates’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.
sn.sn22.76: One who is freed after truly understanding the aggregates is a perfected one. They are the best of beings, even up to the pinnacle of existence. A set of verses extols the perfected ones.
sn.sn22.77: One who is freed after truly understanding the aggregates is a perfected one. They are the best of beings, even up to the pinnacle of existence.
sn.sn22.78: When a lion emerges from its lair and roars, animals are terrified. Similarly, when the Buddha teaches of the impermanence of the aggregates, even the gods are filled with fear. This is illustrated with a set of verses.
sn.sn22.79: One of the most extensive discourses in this collection begins with the Buddha saying that when anyone recollects a past life, all they are recollecting is the five aggregates. He then gives a distinctive set of definitions of the aggregates in terms of their functions, and discusses them from various aspects.
sn.sn22.80: While staying at Kapilavatthu the Buddha dismissed the the Sangha for misbehaving. Later he decided to support them for the sake of the young mendicants. He reminds them that their livelihood is considered a lowly one, and that one should let go of bad thoughts and wrong views, and see the aggregates as impermanent.
sn.sn22.81: Leaving behind the quarreling monks at Kosambi, the Buddha went to stay in the empty forest at Pārileyyaka. Ānanda brings some mendicants to receive a teaching, and one of them wonders how to see so as to end defilements in this very life. The Buddha teaches the 37 practices that lead to awakening, and then goes on to show that various ways of regarding the aggregates are conditioned phenomena.
sn.sn22.82: On a sabbath day with the Sangha at Sāvatthi, the Buddha answers a series of ten questions on the aggregates.
sn.sn22.83: Ānanda praises Venerable Puṇṇa Mantāniputta, and says that it was when hearing his teaching on the aggregates that he understood the Dhamma.
sn.sn22.84: Venerable Tissa, the Blessed One’s paternal cousin, tells the monks that he is dissatisfied as a monk. When the Buddha hears of this, he calls Tissa to him, and questions him on the aggregates. As Tissa showed his understanding of each question, the Buddha praised him, lifting his spirits.
sn.sn22.85: Venerable Yamaka had the wrong view that one whose defilements have ended is annihilated at death. The monks ask Sāriputta to help, and he asks Yamaka whether the Realized One in this very life may be identified as one of the aggregates, or apart from them. Convinced, Yamaka lets go of his view and sees the Dhamma.
sn.sn22.86: Venerable Anurādha is questioned by a number of ascetics, and ends up by saying that the Realized One is described in terms other than “existing after death” and so on. The wanderers say he’s a fool, so he checks with the Buddha, who says that a Realized One is not even apprehended in this life, so how can he be described after death?
sn.sn22.87: Venerable Vakkali is ill, and asks the Buddha to visit him. The Buddha does so, but says there is no point in seeing his physical body, as one who sees the Dhamma sees him. Later, Vakkali is taken to the Black Rock on Isigili, where he declares that he has no attachment to the aggregates, and takes his own life. The Buddha says that he had attained final extinguishment.
sn.sn22.88: Venerable Assaji is ill, and asks the Buddha to visit him. The Buddha does so, and learns that Assaji has difficulty maintaining his meditation. The Buddha encourages him to contemplate the impermanence of the aggregates.
sn.sn22.89: Venerable Khemaka is ill, and some senior mendicants ask Dāsaka to convey their concern to him. There follows a series of exchanges mediated by Dāsaka until eventually Khemaka, despite his illness, goes to see the other mendicants himself.
