The seniors are asking to determine Khemaka’s understanding of the Dhamma, and he says that although he has let go of the five lower fetters, he still has a residual attachment to the five aggregates.
sn.sn22.90: Remorseful after being admonished by the Buddha on his deathbed, Venerable Channa asks for teachings from the mendicants. Unsatisfied, he seeks out Ānanda, who teaches him the address to Kaccāyana (SN 12.15).
sn.sn22.91: Rāhula asks how to contemplate to let go of conceit. The Buddha urges him to see the aggregates as not-self.
sn.sn22.92: Rāhula asks how to contemplate to let go of conceit and be free. The Buddha urges him to see the aggregates as not-self.
sn.sn22.93: If you grasp at the aggregates as a self, you will meet with calamity, like a man swept down by a mountain river, grasping at grass or rushes.
sn.sn22.94: The Buddha doesn’t dispute with the world; the world disputes with him. He has understood the five aggregates and explains them. Like a lotus, he was born in the swamp, but rises above it.
sn.sn22.95: The Buddha gives a series of similes for the aggregates: physical form is like foam, feeling is like a bubble, perception is like a mirage, choices are like a coreless tree, and consciousness is like an illusion.
sn.sn22.96: Nothing in the aggregates has even the tiniest bit of stability or permanence. In a past life, the Buddha was a great king with vast properties, but all those conditions have passed away.
sn.sn22.97: A mendicant asks whether anything in the aggregates has even the tiniest bit of stability or permanence. The Buddha answers using the simile of a little dirt under his fingernail.
sn.sn22.98: A mendicant asks whether anything in the aggregates has even the tiniest bit of stability or permanence.
sn.sn22.99: Transmigration has no knowable beginning; even the oceans, mountains, and this great earth will perish. But like a dog on a leash running around a post, beings remain attached to the aggregates.
sn.sn22.100: A dog leashed to a post will always remain close to that post. In the same way, beings remain close to aggregates in this endless cycle of transmigration. The Buddha refers to a well-known painting called “Conduct”, and says the mind is even more diverse than that; and indeed, the animal realm is the most diverse of them all, and it is produced by the mind.
sn.sn22.101: Contemplating the aggregates leads to liberation, but this may not be immediately apparent. The Buddha illustrates this with similes of a chook sitting on eggs, the wearing away of an axe handle, and the rotting of a ship’s rigging.
sn.sn22.102: The perception of impermanence eliminates lust, ignorance, and conceit. Illustrated with a long series of similes.

sn.sn22.121: The aggregates are the things that are graspable, the craving is the grasping.

sn.sn23.159: sn24.1: The Buddha mentions a strange view to the effect that all changing phenomena of the world are really still and motionless. Such a view arises from grasping to the five aggregates. But by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent, such a view is given up and one becomes a stream-enterer.
sn.sn24.2: The view of me and mine is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.
sn.sn24.3: The view that the self is identical with the cosmos is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.
sn.sn24.4: The view that “I might not be” is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.
sn.sn24.5: The view of annihilationism is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.

sn.sn24.14: The view that the soul and the body are different things is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.
sn.sn24.15: The view that the Realized One exists after death is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.
sn.sn24.16: The view that the Realized One does not exist after death is given up by seeing the aggregates, as well as what is seen, heard, thought, and known, as impermanent.

sn.sn24.19: The Buddha mentions a strange view to the effect that all changing phenomena of the world are really still and motionless. Such a view arises from grasping to the five aggregates, which are suffering. But by seeing the aggregates as impermanent, such a view is given up.
sn.sn24.20-35: The various views arise from grasping to the five aggregates, which are suffering. But by seeing the aggregates as impermanent, these views are given up.
sn.sn24.36: The view that the Realized One neither exists nor does not exist after death arises from grasping to the five aggregates, which are suffering. But by seeing the aggregates as impermanent, this views is given up

sn.sn33.46-50: The wanderer Vacchagotta asks the Buddha why the various speculative views come to be. The Buddha replies that it is because of not closely examining the five aggregates.
sn.sn33.51-55: The wanderer Vacchagotta asks the Buddha why the various speculative views come to be. The Buddha replies that it is because of not directly cognizing the five aggregates
sn.sn35.1: The six interior sense fields are impermanent, suffering, and not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.
sn.sn35.2: The six interior sense fields are suffering and not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.
sn.sn35.3: The six interior sense fields are not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.
sn.sn35.4: The six exterior sense fields are impermanent, suffering, and not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.
sn.sn35.5: The six exterior sense fields are suffering and not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.
sn.sn35.6: The six exterior sense fields are not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.
sn.sn35.7: In the past, future, and present, the six interior sense fields are impermanent, suffering, and not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.
sn.sn35.8: In the past, future, and present, the six interior sense fields are suffering and not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.
sn.sn35.9: In the past, future, and present, the six interior sense fields are not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.
sn.sn35.10: In the past, future, and present, the six exterior sense fields are impermanent, suffering, and not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.
sn.sn35.11: In the past, future, and present, the six exterior sense fields are suffering and not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.
sn.sn35.12: In the past, future, and present, the six exterior sense fields are not-self. When a noble disciple truly sees them like this, they become disillusioned and liberated.
sn.sn35.13: The Buddha did not claim to be awakened until he had fully understood the gratification, drawback, and escape regarding the six interior sense fields.
sn.sn35.14: The Buddha did not claim to be awakened until he had fully understood the gratification, drawback, and escape regarding the six exterior sense fields.
sn.sn35.15: The Buddha set out to find the gratification, drawback, and escape regarding the six interior sense fields.
sn.sn35.16: The Buddha set out to find the gratification, drawback, and escape regarding the six exterior sense fields.
sn.sn35.17: Beings are attached to the six interior sense fields due to gratification, repelled due to drawbacks, and find escape because there is an escape.
sn.sn35.18: Beings are attached to the six exterior sense fields due to gratification, repelled due to drawbacks, and find escape because there is an escape.
sn.sn35.19: If you enjoy the six interior sense fields, you enjoy suffering.
sn.sn35.20: If you enjoy the six exterior sense fields, you enjoy suffering.
sn.sn35.21: The arising of the six interior sense fields is the arising of suffering.
sn.sn35.22: The arising of the six exterior sense fields is the arising of suffering.
sn.sn35.23: The “all” consists of the six interior and exterior sense fields.
sn.sn35.24: The “all” consisting of the six interior and exterior sense fields should be given up.
sn.sn35.25: The “all” consisting of the six interior and exterior sense fields should be given up by understanding.
sn.sn35.26: Without understanding the “all” consisting of the six interior and exterior sense fields and becoming dispassionate towards it, it is impossible to be free of suffering.
sn.sn35.27: Without understanding the “all” consisting of the six interior and exterior sense fields and the associated consciousness and becoming dispassionate towards it, it is impossible to be free of suffering.
sn.sn35.28: The “all” consisting of the six interior and exterior sense fields is burning. This is the famous “third sermon” taught at Gayā’s Head to the followers of the three Kassapa brothers.
sn.sn35.29: The “all” consisting of the six interior and exterior sense fields, and the phenomena they condition, is weighed down.
sn.sn35.30: The way to uproot all conceivings is to not conceive in relation to the six sense fields.
sn.sn35.31: The way to uproot all conceivings is to not conceive in relation to the six sense fields.
sn.sn35.32: The way to uproot all conceivings is to investigate the six sense fields as impermanent, etc.
sn.sn35.33-42: The “all” consisting of the six interior and exterior sense fields is liable to be reborn, to age, etc.
sn.sn35.43-51: The “all” consisting of the six interior and exterior sense fields is impermanent, etc.
sn.sn35.52: The “all” consisting of the six interior and exterior sense fields is afflicted.
sn.sn35.53: A mendicant asks the Buddha how to see so as to give up ignorance. The Buddha says one should see the six interior and exterior sense fields as impermanent.
sn.sn35.54: A mendicant asks the Buddha how to see so as to give up the fetters. The Buddha says one should see the six interior and exterior sense fields as impermanent.
sn.sn35.55: A mendicant asks the Buddha how to see so as to uproot the fetters. The Buddha says one should see the six interior and exterior sense fields as not-self.
sn.sn35.56: A mendicant asks the Buddha how to see so as to give up the defilements. The Buddha says one should see the six interior and exterior sense fields as impermanent.
sn.sn35.57: A mendicant asks the Buddha how to see so as to uproot the defilements. The Buddha says one should see the six interior and exterior sense fields as not-self.
sn.sn35.58: A mendicant asks the Buddha how to see so as to give up the underlying tendencies. The Buddha says one should see the six interior and exterior sense fields as impermanent.
sn.sn35.59: A mendicant asks the Buddha how to see so as to uproot the underlying tendencies. The Buddha says one should see the six interior and exterior sense fields as not-self.
sn.sn35.60: To fully understand grasping, see how sense experience gives rise to feeling.
sn.sn35.61: To end grasping, see how sense experience gives rise to feeling.
sn.sn35.62: To end grasping, investigate the six sense fields as impermanent, etc.
sn.sn35.63: Venerable Migajāla asks how one lives alone, and how with a partner. The Buddha says that so long as one is bound by desire to the senses, one lives with a partner. A mendicant free of such desire dwells alone, even if they live in close association with worldly people.
sn.sn35.64: Venerable Migajāla asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha teaches him that the senses are delightful, but if you hold to them you will suffer. Meditating on this while on retreat, Migajāla became awakened.
sn.sn35.65: Venerable Samiddhi asks the Buddha what Māra is. The Buddha says that that Māra is present so long as the senses exist.
sn.sn35.66: Venerable Samiddhi asks the Buddha what a “sentient being” is. The Buddha says that that Māra is present so long as the senses exist.
sn.sn35.67: Venerable Samiddhi asks the Buddha what suffering is. The Buddha says that that Māra is present so long as the senses exist.
sn.sn35.68: Venerable Samiddhi asks the Buddha what the world is. The Buddha says that that Māra is present so long as the senses exist.
sn.sn35.69: A viper bit Venerable Upasena, but he remained poised, declaring that he had no identification with the six senses.
sn.sn35.70: The teaching that can be realized in this very life is the desire for the senses, and letting go of that desire.
sn.sn35.71: One who does not understand the six senses’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape is no true mendicant. A mendicant speaks up, saying that he does not truly understand these things, so the Buddha teaches him further.
sn.sn35.72: One who does not understand the six senses’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape is no true mendicant. A mendicant speaks up, saying that he does not truly understand these things, so the Buddha teaches him further.
sn.sn35.73: One who does not understand the six senses’ origin, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape is no true mendicant. A mendicant speaks up, saying that he does not truly understand these things, so the Buddha teaches him further.
sn.sn35.74: Hearing that a newly-ordained mendicant was sick, the Buddha visited him to offer support and Dhamma encouragement.
sn.sn35.75: Hearing that a newly-ordained mendicant was sick, the Buddha visited him to offer support and Dhamma encouragement.
sn.sn35.76: Venerable Rādha asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha told him to abandon desire for sense experience, which is impermanent.
sn.sn35.77: Venerable Rādha asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha told him to abandon desire for sense experience, which is suffering.
sn.sn35.78: Venerable Rādha asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha told him to abandon desire for sense experience, which is not-self.
sn.sn35.79: Through giving up ignorance, knowledge arises. To do this, contemplate the six senses as impermanent.
sn.sn35.80: Through giving up ignorance, knowledge arises. To do this, contemplate the six senses as impermanent. Then a mendicant truly understands, and sees everything differently.
sn.sn35.81: Some mendicants check with the Buddha that it’s correct to say that the spiritual life is lived to end suffering. The Buddha answers that it is, and explains what that suffering is: the process of sense experience.
sn.sn35.82: The “world” consisting of six sense experience is said to be falling apart.
sn.sn35.83: The Buddhas of the past cannot be described in terms of the six senses.
sn.sn35.84: The Buddha tells Ānanda that in the training of the noble one the “world” consisting of six sense experience is liable fall apart.
sn.sn35.85: The Buddha tells Ānanda that the “world” consisting of six sense experience is empty because it is empty of self and what belongs to self.
sn.sn35.86: Ānanda asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha teaches him that the senses are impermanent, etc.
sn.sn35.87: Sāriputta and Mahācunda visit Channa, who is ill. Channa says that he lacks for no care, but is in such great pain that he wishes to take his own life, insisting that he will do so blamelessly. Sāriputta tries to dissuade him, and questions him closely about attachment to the six senses. Later Channa does take his own life, and the Buddha confirmed that, despite Sāriputta’s doubts, he was indeed blameless.
sn.sn35.88: Venerable Puṇṇa goes to the Buddha and asks for a teaching before he departs to the foreign land of Sunāparanta. The Buddha warns him that folk there are fierce, and questions whether he is ready for such a difficult assignment.
sn.sn35.89: Venerable Bāhiya asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha teaches him that the senses are impermanent, etc.
sn.sn35.90: Being stirred by craving is painful, so the Realized One lives unstirred, not identifying with any aspect of sense experience.
sn.sn35.91: Being stirred by craving is painful, so the Realized One lives unstirred, not identifying with any aspect of sense experience, or indeed, with the entire scope of the aggregates, elements, and senses.
sn.sn35.92: The dyad is the interior sense organ with its corresponding exterior sense stimulus.
sn.sn35.93: Consciousness arises from the dyad of the interior sense organ with its corresponding exterior sense stimulus. All these things are conditioned, impermanent, and constantly falling apart.
sn.sn35.94: The six fields of contact lead to suffering if left unguarded, but if guarded lead to happiness. A lengthy set of verses illustrate this.
sn.sn35.95: Venerable Māluṅkyaputta asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha wonders how to teach an old monk like him, then questions him on his desire for sense experience that has been or might be, and encourages him to simply let sense experience be. Māluṅkyaputta says he understands, and expands the Buddha’s teaching in a series of verses.
sn.sn35.96: When a mendicant tolerates evil thoughts that arise from the senses, they are liable to decline. If they don’t tolerate them, they’re not liable to decline. When such thoughts not longer arise, they have mastered the senses.
sn.sn35.97: When a mendicant lives without restraint regarding the senses, they are negligent. If they have restraint, they are diligent.
sn.sn35.98: Non-restraint is delighting in the senses, restraint is not delighting in them.
sn.sn35.99: Develop meditative immersion so as to truly understand the process of sense experience.
sn.sn35.100: Develop seclusion so as to truly understand the process of sense experience.
sn.sn35.101: Let go of what is not yours: the process of sense experience. You wouldn’t be upset if someone took the grass and sticks from the monastery grounds, so why worry over the aggregates?
sn.sn35.102: Let go of what is not yours: the process of sense experience.
sn.sn35.103: The Buddha’s former teacher Uddaka Rāmaputta claimed to be a knowledge master, a universal victor, how had excised the tumor. But a true knowledge master understands the senses, a victor is freed from them, and excising the tumor is being free from attachment to the body.
sn.sn35.104: Someone who has given up attraction to the senses has arrived at the sanctuary.
sn.sn35.105: Pleasure and pain arise inside oneself due to grasping the senses.
sn.sn35.106: The origin and ending of suffering are explained in terms of sense experience giving rise to craving.
sn.sn35.107: The origin and ending of the world are explained in terms of sense experience giving rise to craving and suffering.
sn.sn35.108: Conceit stems from clinging to the senses.
sn.sn35.109: The interior sense fields are the things that fetter, the craving is the fetter.
sn.sn35.110: The interior sense fields are the things that are graspable, the craving is the grasping.
sn.sn35.111: Without understanding the six interior sense fields and becoming dispassionate towards them, it is impossible to be free of suffering.
sn.sn35.112: Without understanding the six exterior sense fields and becoming dispassionate towards them, it is impossible to be free of suffering.
sn.sn35.113: While on retreat, the Buddha exclaims how the origin and ending of the world are explained in terms of sense experience giving rise to craving and suffering. A mendicant overhears him, and the Buddha urges him to remember that teaching.
sn.sn35.114: A mendicant who craves the senses is under the sway of Māra.
sn.sn35.115: A mendicant who craves the senses is under the sway of Māra.
sn.sn35.116: The Buddha states that the end of the world cannot be reached by traveling, yet it is impossible to end suffering without reaching the end of the world. The mendicants ask Ānanda to explain this enigmatic statement.
sn.sn35.117: While practicing for awakening, the Buddha reflected that he should be diligent when his mind strayed to sense pleasures of the past, future, or present. He urges the mendicants to realize that place where the senses completely cease, and they ask Ānanda to explain this to them.
sn.sn35.118: Sakka asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.
sn.sn35.119: The fairy Pañcasikha asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.
sn.sn35.120: A mendicant informs Sāriputta that one of his friends had disrobed. Sāriputta attributes this to lack of sense restraint, eating too much, and not being wakeful.
sn.sn35.121: Realizing that his son Rāhula was ripe for awakening, the Buddha takes him for a personal teaching. He questions Rāhula on the impermanence of all the factors of sense experience, leading Rāhula to realize full freedom.
sn.sn35.122: The exterior sense fields are the things that fetter, the craving is the fetter.
sn.sn35.123: The exterior sense fields are the things that are graspable, the craving is the grasping.
sn.sn35.124: At the Great Wood, the householder Ugga of Vesālī asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.
sn.sn35.125: At Hatthigāma, the householder Ugga of Hatthigāma asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.
sn.sn35.126: At Nālandā, the householder Upāli asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.
sn.sn35.127: King Udena of Kosambi asks Venerable Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja how even young monks can maintain the celibate life. Piṇḍola says it’s because they see women as their sisters, mothers, or daughters. If this doesn’t work, they meditate on the ugliness of the body. Finally they exercise sense restraint.
sn.sn35.128: At Rājagaha, the householder Soṇa asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.
sn.sn35.129: The householder Ghosita asks Ānanda about the diversity of elements, and he answers in terms of the elements of sense experience.
sn.sn35.130: The householder Hāliddakāni asks Mahākaccāna about the relation between the diversity of elements and the diveristy of contacts, and he answers in terms of the elements of sense experience.
sn.sn35.131: At Suṁsumāragira, the householder Nakulapitā asks the Buddha why some become awakened in this very life, while others do not.
sn.sn35.132: Students of the brahmin Lohicca make a racket while collecting firewood near Mahākaccāna’s hut. Mahākaccāna hushes them and recites a series of verses contrasting the virtuous brahmins of old with those of today. Taking umbrage, they tell Lohicca, who goes to Mahākaccāna to ascertain the truth. But when Lohicca hears what Mahākaccāna teach on the six senses, he is so impressed he goes for refuge.
sn.sn35.133: A student of the brahmin lady of the Verahaccāni clan recommends to her the teaching of  Venerable Udāyı̄, so she invites him for a meal. But when she displays a conceited attitude, he leaves without teaching. However, she corrects herself so he teaches her that pleasure and pain depend on the senses.
sn.sn35.134: Not all mendicants have completed their work with regards to the six senses, but some of them have.
sn.sn35.135: The Buddha speaks of the hell named the “six senses” where all one experiences is sheer pain and unpleasantness.
sn.sn35.136: Gods and humans take delight in the six sense, but the Realized One does not. This teaching is illustrated with a long series of verses.
sn.sn35.137: Gods and humans take delight in the six sense, but the Realized One does not.
sn.sn35.138: Let go of what is not yours: the six interior sense fields. You wouldn’t be upset if someone took the grass and sticks from the monastery grounds, so why worry over the senses?
sn.sn35.139: Let go of what is not yours: the six exterior sense fields. You wouldn’t be upset if someone took the grass and sticks from the monastery grounds, so why worry over the senses?
sn.sn35.140: Since the causes of the six interior sense fields are impermanent, how can the senses be permanent?
sn.sn35.141: Since the causes of the six interior sense fields are suffering, how can the senses be free of suffering?
sn.sn35.142: Since the causes of the six interior sense fields are not-self, how can the senses be self?
sn.sn35.143: Since the causes of the six exterior sense fields are impermanent, how can the senses be permanent?
sn.sn35.144: Since the causes of the six exterior sense fields are suffering, how can the senses be free of suffering?
sn.sn35.145: Since the causes of the six exterior sense fields are not-self, how can the senses be self?
sn.sn35.146: The six interior sense fields are not yours, but are old kamma, generated by choices in past lives. This is explained in terms of the four noble truths.
sn.sn35.147: The way suitable for realizing extinguishment is to contemplate the process of sense experience as impermanent.
sn.sn35.148: The way suitable for realizing extinguishment is to contemplate the process of sense experience as suffering.
sn.sn35.149: The way suitable for realizing extinguishment is to contemplate the process of sense experience as not-self.
sn.sn35.150: The way suitable for realizing extinguishment is to contemplate the process of sense experience as impermanent, suffering, and not-self.
sn.sn35.151: One with no “student” and no “teacher” dwells in suffering. Here the Buddha plays with the Pali words such that “student” means “one who dwells within” and “teacher” means “one who assails”.
sn.sn35.152: If anyone asks why we live the holy life, it is for the ending of suffering.
sn.sn35.153: How is it that a mendicant can declare their awakening? By understanding whether any desire arises from sense stimuli.
sn.sn35.154: One is accomplished in the sense faculties by being freed from attachment to them.
sn.sn35.155: A speaker on the Dhamma is someone who teaches for letting go of the senses.
sn.sn35.156: Right view is seeing the interior sense fields as they are, impermanent, and this leads to freedom.
sn.sn35.157: Right view is seeing the exterior sense fields as they are, impermanent, and this leads to freedom.
sn.sn35.158: Focusing properly on the  interior sense fields you see them are they are and become free.
sn.sn35.159: Focusing properly on the  exterior sense fields you see them are they are and become free.
sn.sn35.160: A mendicant should develop immersion (samādhi) in order to truly understand the origin and ending of the process of sense experience.
sn.sn35.161: A mendicant should make an effort in seclusion in order to truly understand the origin and ending of the process of sense experience.
sn.sn35.162: Mahākoṭṭhita asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha says to give up desire for what is impermanent, i.e. the process of sense experience.
sn.sn35.163: Mahākoṭṭhita asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha says to give up desire for what is suffering, i.e. the process of sense experience.
sn.sn35.164: Mahākoṭṭhita asks for a teaching to take on retreat. The Buddha says to give up desire for what is not-self, i.e. the process of sense experience.
sn.sn35.165: Wrong view arises due to grasping the process of sense experience.
sn.sn35.166: Identity view arises due to grasping the process of sense experience.
sn.sn35.167: View of self arises due to grasping the process of sense experience.
sn.sn35.228: In the Buddha’s teaching the “ocean” is the sense organs, the current is the sense objects.
sn.sn35.229: In the Buddha’s teaching the “ocean” is the delights of sense stimuli.
sn.sn35.230: Sense pleasures are like a baited hook.
sn.sn35.231: Like a tree that yields sap when cut, so long as desire is present it will be activated by the senses.
sn.sn35.232: Mahākoṭṭhita asks Sāriputta whether the interior and exterior sense fields are the fetters of each other. No; it is desire that is the fetter, like the yoke that binds two oxen. One with no desire still experiences the senses but without fetters.
sn.sn35.233: Kāmabhū asks Ānanda whether the interior and exterior sense fields are the fetters of each other. No; it is desire that is the fetter. One with no desire still experiences the senses but without fetters.
sn.sn35.234: Udāyı̄ notes to Ānanda that the Buddha has taught the body as not-self; what then of consciousness? Ānanda then explains how consciousness arises dependent on conditions.
sn.sn35.235: It would be better for the sense organs to be pierced with red-hot spikes than to get attached to a pleasant sense experience.
sn.sn35.236: So long as this body exists there is suffering due to the senses.
sn.sn35.237: So long as this body exists there is suffering due to the senses.
sn.sn35.238: The Buddha strings a series of powerful similes—vipers, murderers, an empty village, and more—into an extended parable of the dangers of existence and the way of escape.
sn.sn35.239: When a mendicant has three qualities they live happily: sense restraint, moderation in eating, and wakefulness.
sn.sn35.240: A parable of a jackal who fails to eat a tortoise who stays still, with limbs retracted, like a mendicant guarding the senses.
sn.sn35.241: The Buddha gives a parable of a large log floating downstream, which, if it steers clear of the many obstacles, will eventually reach the ocean. A mendicant asks for an explanation, and the Buddha clarifies each item. A cowherd named Nanda was listening, and determined to go forth.
sn.sn35.242: The Buddha gives a parable of a large log floating downstream, which, if it steers clear of the many obstacles, will eventually reach the ocean. Venerable Kimbila asks for an explanation, and the Buddha clarifies each item.
sn.sn35.243: The Buddha is invited to teach in a new hall in Kapilavatthu. Late at night, after teaching the Sakyans, the Buddha invites Moggallāna to teach. He speaks on the mental corruption that flows from attachment to the senses.
sn.sn35.244: The Buddha defines the things that entail suffering as the five aggregates, and urges mendicants to be free of desire for the six senses, giving a series of vivid similes. He then speaks of how even for a mendicant practicing restraint a lapse of mindfulness might occur from time to time.
sn.sn35.245: A mendicant goes to a series of teachers and asks how vision is purified. Dissatisfied with all their answers, he complains to the Buddha, who illustrates his quandary  with the famous simile of the Kiṁsuka tree. Just as the same Kiṁsuka tree might be described differently by people focusing on the leaves, or the fruit, or the bark, etc., so too the various teachers each speak of the aspect of Dhamma most meaningful to them.
sn.sn35.246: One should restrain the senses like a farmer watching over a field. The Buddha gives the parable of a man bewitched when he first hears a lute. He takes apart the instrument in search of the sound, but is disillusioned when no sound is found.
sn.sn35.247: The senses are like a snake, a crocodile, a bird, a dog, a jackal, and a monkey all tied up together, pulling this way and that. Mindfulness is like a post that keeps them grounded.
sn.sn35.248: The six senses are like a sheaf of barley struck with six flails; and the desire for rebirth is a seventh flail. The Buddha goes on to speak of the cunning trap of the gods; but the trap of Māra, conceit, is even more subtle.
sn.sn36.1: There are three feelings, and a meditator practicing immersion can understand them.
sn.sn36.2: There are three feelings, and all of them are suffering.
sn.sn36.3: One should give up desire for pleasant feeling, aversion for painful feeling, and ignorance regarding neutral feeling.
sn.sn36.4: Ordinary people think the ocean is a bottomless abyss; but really, it is the three feelings.
sn.sn36.5: See pleasant feeling as painful, painful feeling as a dart, and neutral  feeling as impermanent.
sn.sn36.6: Both ordinary and awakened people experience the three feelings. The difference is that when an ordinary person is stricken with feeling, they react, creating more suffering, whereas an awakened person responds with equanimity.
sn.sn36.7: A mendicant should await their death mindful and aware. They should bear the feelings of approaching death with wisdom and equanimity.
sn.sn36.8: A mendicant should await their death mindful and aware. They should bear the feelings of approaching death with wisdom and equanimity.
sn.sn36.10: The three feelings are each produced by the appropriate contact.
sn.sn36.11: A mendicant wonders how there can be three kinds of feeling, yet all of them are suffering.
sn.sn36.12: Feelings arise in the body like winds blowing in the sky. With illustrative verses.
sn.sn36.13: Feelings arise in the body like winds blowing in the sky.
sn.sn36.14: Feelings arise in the body like guests in a hotel.
sn.sn36.15: The Buddha explains the feelings to Ānanda in terms of arising, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.
sn.sn36.16: The Buddha asks about the feelings to Ānanda in terms of arising, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.
sn.sn36.17: The Buddha explains the feelings to several mendicants in terms of arising, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.
sn.sn36.18: The Buddha asks about the feelings to several mendicants in terms of arising, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.
sn.sn36.19: The carpenter Pañcakaṅga disagreed with Venerable Udāyī about how many kinds of feeling the Buddha taught. The Buddha affirms that each is a genuine teaching, valid in different contexts.
sn.sn36.20: The Buddha has taught many different kinds of feeling, valid in different contexts.
sn.sn36.21: When the wanderer Moḷiyasīvaka asks if all feelings are caused by karma in past lives. The Buddha denies this, asserting that feelings have many different causes.
sn.sn36.22: The Buddha explains the different kinds of feelings analyzed into 108 aspects.
sn.sn36.23: A mendicant asks the Buddha to explain the feelings in terms of the four noble truths.
sn.sn36.24: Before his awakening the Buddha reflected on feeling in terms of arising, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.
sn.sn36.25: At his awakening, the Buddha saw feeling in terms of arising, ending, gratification, drawback, and escape.
sn.sn36.26: Several mendicants ask the Buddha to explain the feelings in terms of the four noble truths.
sn.sn36.27: One who does not truly understand feeling is no true ascetic.
sn.sn36.28: One who does not truly understand feeling is no true ascetic.
sn.sn36.29: One who does not truly understand feeling is no true ascetic.
sn.sn36.30: There are three feelings: painful, pleasant, neutral.
sn.sn36.31: The Buddha explains feelings as spiritual and carnal, associated with worldly states and with deep meditation.
sn.sn37.1: Five things that make a woman either agreeable or disagreeable to men.
sn.sn37.2: Five things that make a man either agreeable or disagreeable to women.
sn.sn37.3: Five kinds of suffering that only women are subject to, not men.

sn.sn40.1: Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the first absorption was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.
sn.sn40.2: Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the second absorption was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.
sn.sn40.3: Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the third absorption was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.
sn.sn40.4: Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the fourth absorption was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.
sn.sn40.5: Moggallāna speaks to the mendicants of a time when his practice of the dimension of infinite space was faltering. He expresses his gratitude for the Buddha, who urged him to stabilize that attainment.

sn.sn40.10: Moggallāna ascended to the heaven of the Thirty-Three to address Sakka, the lord of gods, and his extensive retinue. He spoke in praise of going for refuge, as it leads to heaven. Sakka affirmed this on multiple occasions, adding that gods who had gone for refuge and kept ethics surpassed the other deities in the heavens.
sn.sn40.11: The dialogue in SN 40.10 is repeated with a series of other deities.
sn.sn41.1: Citta the householder hears of a conversation among the monks regarding the distinction between the fetters and the things that are fettered. He goes to ask them on this topic, but they are unable to give a satisfactory answer, so he explained it to them. It is desire that is the fetter, like the yoke that binds two oxen.
sn.sn41.2: Citta the householder invites some mendicants to his home for a meal. He asks them about the diversity of the elements, but only the junior monk, Isidatta, is able to answer.
sn.sn41.3: Citta the householder invites some mendicants to his home for a meal. He asks them what is the cause of the ten metaphysical questions and the 62 views of the Brahmajala Sutta, but only the junior monk, Isidatta, is able to answer. Citta realizes that Isidatta is in fact an unseen friend of his from Avantī. He offers to support him with requisites, but Isidatta left, never to return.
sn.sn41.4: Citta the householder invites some mendicants to his home for a meal. When they left he followed them, and witnessed the junior monk Venerable Mahaka performing a psychic feat. Citta approached Mahaka in his hut and asked him to demonstrate his skills, and Mahaka obliged. Citta offers to support him with requisites, but Mahaka left, never to return.
sn.sn41.5: Venerable Kāmabhū asks Citta to explain an enigmatic verse on a “one-spoked chariot”. After a brief consideration, Citta is able to explain it in detail.
sn.sn41.6: Citta asks Kāmabhū about the different kinds of processes (saṅkhāra) in a series of questions that lead to the most profound of meditation experiences.
sn.sn41.7: Venerable Godatta asks Citta whether the liberations of measurelessness, nothingness, emptiness, and signlessness are different states, or just different words for the same thing. Citta explains that they are both: they are terms for different meditation experiences, but may also be used of perfection or arahantship.
sn.sn41.8: The Jain leader Mahāvīra, known as Nigaṇṭha Nātaputa in the Buddhist tradition, is visited by Citta. Mahāvīra asks him whether he believes in a certain state of immersion. When Citta replies that he doesn’t go by faith in the Buddha on this point, Mahāvīra is delighted. But it turns out Citta doesn’t need faith, as he experiences such a state for himself.
sn.sn41.9: Citta meets with the naked ascetic Kassapa, an old friend of his, and asks what gains he has realized from the spiritual life. Kassapa admits he has realized no higher attainments, whereupon Citta reveals he has realized many such attainments. Kassapa decides to ordain as a Buddhist mendicant.
sn.sn41.10: When Citta was on his deathbed, rather than receiving comfort, he gave comfort and teaching to those present.
sn.sn42.1: A headman known for his aggressive nature approaches the Buddha and asks how to give up irritability. The Buddha points out that such reactions are fueled by greed, hate, and delusion.
sn.sn42.2: Talapuṭa the head of a troupe of performers asks the Buddha whether the belief that performers have a good rebirth is correct. The Buddha tries to dissuade him, but ultimately reveals that by inciting lust they head to a bad rebirth. Talapuṭa is distressed and asks to ordain.
sn.sn42.3: Yodhājı̄va the professional warrior asks the Buddha whether the belief that warriors have a good rebirth is correct. The Buddha tries to dissuade him, but ultimately reveals that by following the way of violence they head to a bad rebirth. Yodhājı̄va is distressed and takes refuge.
sn.sn42.4: Hatthāroha the elephant warrior asks the Buddha whether the belief that warriors have a good rebirth is correct. The Buddha tries to dissuade him, but ultimately reveals that by following the way of violence they head to a bad rebirth. Hatthāroha is distressed and takes refuge.
sn.sn42.5: Assāroha the cavalry warrior asks the Buddha whether the belief that warriors have a good rebirth is correct. The Buddha tries to dissuade him, but ultimately reveals that by following the way of violence they head to a bad rebirth. Yodhājı̄va is distressed and asks to ordain.
sn.sn42.6: The chief Asibandhakaputta asks whether the rituals advocated by the western brahmins can bring a person to heaven. The Buddha asserts that only good deeds can take you to a good rebirth, and rituals have no effect.
sn.sn42.7: The chief Asibandhakaputta asks the Buddha why, if he has equal compassion for all, he teaches some more than others. The Buddha answers with a simile of a field: a farmer knows to put most of their effort into the fertile land.
sn.sn42.8: The Buddha asks the chief Asibandhakaputta, a Jain, how Mahāvīra the Jain leader teaches his followers. He replies that you go to a rebirth depending on what you usually do. But the Buddha points out that even a killer only spends a small amount of time actually killing. The Buddha’s approach is to point out that deeds have results, and to encourage the abandoing of bad deeds and the adoption of good deeds.
sn.sn42.9: Mahāvīra asks Asibandhakaputta to refute the Buddha on behalf of the Jains. He suggests to try to trap the Buddha with a dilemma: he claims to have compassion for householders, yet visits them with a large Saṅgha in a time of scarcity. But the Buddha says no family has been harmed from this.
sn.sn42.10: Several members of the king’s retinue criticize the Buddhist mendicants for accepting offerings of money. Chief Maṇicūḷaka is among them, and he visits the Buddha to find out the truth. The Buddha categorically denies the accusation.
sn.sn42.11: The chief Bhadraka asks the Buddha about the origin and ending of suffering, and the Buddha points out that a loss among Bhadraka’s own community would cause him suffering, due to his attachment.
sn.sn42.12: The chief Rāsiya asks whether the Buddha completely rejects all forms of asceticism. The Buddha denies that this is the case, and explains what he means by the middle way in a lengthy disquisition, covering useful and useless forms of asceticism.
sn.sn42.13: The chief Pāṭaliya asks whether the Buddha the Buddha knows magic. He says he does—but that does not make him a magician.
sn.sn44.1: While staying in Toraṇavatthu, King Pasenadi wishes to visit a spiritual teacher, and the nun Khemā is highly recommended to him. He asks her about whether a realized One exists after death, and she says this is not answerable. Later he visits the Buddha, who replies in exactly the same way.
sn.sn44.2: Venerable Anurādha is questioned by a number of ascetics, and ends up by saying that the Realized One is described in terms other than “existing after death” and so on. The wanderers say he’s a fool, so he checks with the Buddha, who says that a Realized One is not even apprehended in this life, so how can he be described after death?
sn.sn44.3: Mahākoṭṭhita asks Sāriputta whether a Realized One exists after death. Sāriputta says that to answer this would be to get involved in the five aggregates, something that a Realized One is free from.
sn.sn44.4: Mahākoṭṭhita asks Sāriputta whether a Realized One exists after death. Sāriputta says that one who understands the five aggregates would not think in such terms.
sn.sn44.5: Mahākoṭṭhita asks Sāriputta whether a Realized One exists after death. Sāriputta says that only someone who has desire for the five aggregates would think in such terms.
sn.sn44.6: Sāriputta asks Mahākoṭṭhita whether a Realized One exists after death. Mahākoṭṭhita says that only someone who delights in the five aggregates would think in such terms, and offers a variety of further explanations of the same point.
sn.sn44.7: The wanderer Vacchagotta asks Moggallāna the ten metaphysical questions, starting with whether the cosmos is eternal. Moggallāna says such questions would only be answered by someone who identifies with the six senses. Vacchagotta then asks the Buddha the same questions.
sn.sn44.8: The wanderer Vacchagotta asks the Buddha the ten metaphysical questions, starting with whether the cosmos is eternal. He says such questions would only be answered by someone who identifies with the five aggregates.
sn.sn44.9: The wanderer Vacchagotta reports to the Buddha a conversation among ascetics on the views of the six heretical teachers as to where a perfected one is reborn. Unsure of what the Buddha’s position was, he asks how it is to be understood. The Buddha says it is like a flame that burns dependent on fuel, and goes out when that fuel is extinguished.
sn.sn44.10: Vacchagotta asks the Buddha whether a self exists, but the Buddha is silent. When Ānanda later asks him why he didn’t answer, the Buddha replied that it was to avoid misunderstanding.
sn.sn44.11: The wanderer Vacchagotta asks Venerable Sabhiya Kaccāna whether a Realized One exists after death. He answers that the basis for describing a Realized One no longer applies. Vacchagotta is impressed that such a junior monk understands this subtle matter.
sn.sn45.1: Following ignorance comes the wrong eightfold path. But the right eightfold path follows true knowledge.
sn.sn45.2: When Ānanda says that good friendship is half the spiritual path, the Buddha rebukes him, saying that it is in fact the whole of the spiritual path. Based on good friendship, the eightfold path is fulfilled.
sn.sn45.3: When Sāriputta says that good friendship is the whole of the spiritual path, the Buddha praises him. Based on good friendship, the eightfold path is fulfilled.
sn.sn45.4: Ānanda  sees the brahmin Jāṇussoṇi resplendent on his all-white chariot. He asks the Buddha whether there is a similarly divine vehicle in Buddhism. The Buddha responds by drawing a detailed set of analogies between the eightfold path and a chariot.
sn.sn45.5: When asked what is the purpose of the spiritual path, you should answer that it is the ending of suffering.
sn.sn45.6: A mendicant asks what is the purpose of the spiritual path, and the Buddha answers that it is the ending of suffering.
sn.sn45.7: A mendicant asks about Nibbāna and the deathless.
sn.sn45.8: The Buddha presents the eightfold path together with a detailed analysis of each factor. It should be assumed that these explanations apply wherever the eightfold path is taught.
sn.sn45.9: A mendicant with wrong view will develop the path in the wrong way, harming themselves as if grabbing a sharp spike the wrong way.
sn.sn45.10: The wanderer Nandiya asks how many things lead to extinguishment.
sn.sn45.11: The Buddha goes on retreat for a fortnight. When he emerges, he describes his meditation on the conditionality of the eightfold path, which was similar to a practice he did shortly after awakening.
sn.sn45.12: The Buddha goes on retreat for a fortnight. When he emerges, he describes his meditation on the conditionality of the eightfold path, which was similar to a practice he did shortly after awakening.
sn.sn45.13: A mendicant asks how a person is a “trainee”.
sn.sn45.14: The eightfold path does not rise apart from a Realized One.
sn.sn45.15: The eightfold path does not rise apart from a Holy One’s training.
sn.sn45.16: The eight pure factors of the path do not rise apart from a Realized One.
sn.sn45.17: The eight pure factors of the path do not rise apart from a Holy One’s training.
sn.sn45.18: In a short discourse evidently set shortly after the Buddha’s passing, Venerable Bhadda asks Ānanda about the unholy life, or the unspiritual path. It is the wrong eightfold path.
sn.sn45.19: In a short discourse evidently set shortly after the Buddha’s passing, Venerable Bhadda asks Ānanda about the holy life, or the spiritual path. It is the right eightfold path.
sn.sn45.20: In a short discourse evidently set shortly after the Buddha’s passing, Venerable Bhadda asks Ānanda about the spiritual path, one who follows the spiritual path, and the goal of the spiritual path.
sn.sn45.21: The wrong eightfold path is a wrong state; the right eightfold path is a right state.
sn.sn45.22: The factors of the wrong eightfold path are unskillful qualities; those of the right eightfold path are skillful qualities.
sn.sn45.23: The wrong eightfold path is the wrong way; the right eightfold path is the right way.
sn.sn45.24: Regardless of whether one is a lay person or a renunciate, the Buddha praises the right way, not the wrong way. The wrong eightfold path is the wrong way; the right eightfold path is the right way.
sn.sn45.25: A bad person practices wrong eightfold path; a good person practices the right eightfold path.
sn.sn45.26: A bad person practices wrong eightfold path, and a worse person has wrong knowledge and wrong liberation, too; a good person is the opposite.
sn.sn45.27: Someone without the eightfold path is easily knocked over, like a pot without a stand.
sn.sn45.28: The eightfold path is the necessary prerequisite for right immersion (samādhi).
sn.sn45.29: The eightfold path is developed to understand the three feelings.
sn.sn45.30: The Buddha taught the eightfold path in order to give up the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
sn.sn45.31: The wrong eightfold path is wrong practice; the right eightfold path is right practice.
sn.sn45.32: Practicing the wrong eightfold path is wrong; practicing the right awakening path is right.
sn.sn45.33: Neglecting the eightfold path you neglect the path to the end of suffering.
sn.sn45.34: The eightfold path leads from the near to the far shore. With a long set of verses.
sn.sn45.35: The eightfold path is the ascetic life. Its fruits are stream-entry, once-return, non-return, and perfection.
sn.sn45.36: The eightfold path is the ascetic life. Its fruits are the end of greed, hate, and delusion.
sn.sn45.37: The eightfold path is brahminhood. Its fruits are stream-entry, once-return, non-return, and perfection.
sn.sn45.38: The eightfold path is brahminhood. Its fruits are the end of greed, hate, and delusion.
sn.sn45.39: The eightfold path is the spiritual path. Its fruits are stream-entry, once-return, non-return, and perfection.
sn.sn45.40: The eightfold path is the spiritual path. Its fruits are the end of greed, hate, and delusion.
sn.sn45.41: If others ask why you follow the spiritual path, say it’s for the fading away of lust.
sn.sn45.42-47: If others ask why you follow the spiritual path, say it’s for giving up fetters, etc.
sn.sn45.48: If others ask why you follow the spiritual path, say it’s for final extinguishment without anything left over.
sn.sn45.49: As the dawn precedes the sun, good friendship precedes the eightfold path.
sn.sn45.50-54: As the dawn precedes the sun, ethics, enthusiasm, confidence, right view, and diligence precede the eightfold path.
sn.sn45.55: As the dawn precedes the sun, proper attention precedes the eightfold path.
sn.sn45.170: This sutta contains the same subtance twice, substituting the variant form tasina for taṇhā. The repeated material is not found in all editions.
sn.sn46.1: Dragons nurture their strength in the Himalayas, then enter the rivers and reach the ocean. So too, a mendicant nurtures ethics and then develops the seven awakening factors.
sn.sn46.2: Just as the body depends on food, the awakening factors depend on nutriment. The Buddha gives specific conditions for each of the factors.
sn.sn46.3: Here the awakening factors are described in the context of hearing the teachings and reflecting on them. This leads to full enlightenment, or at least to some lesser attainment.
sn.sn46.4: The various awakening factors can be donned at different times of the day, like a man who puts on bright colored clothes whenever he wants.
sn.sn46.5: They’re called awakening factors because they lead to awakening.
sn.sn46.6: The wanderer Kuṇḍaliya points out that some ascetics argue for the sake of winning debates. But the Buddha says his path is for the sake of liberation. Kuṇḍaliya asks what leads to liberation, and the Buddha traces a sequence of conditions back to sense restraint.
sn.sn46.7: The awakening factors lead to extinguishment, like rafters holding up the roof peak.
sn.sn46.8: Sāriputta asks Upavāṇa how one can reflect and see the awakening factors in oneself.
sn.sn46.9: The eightfold path does not rise apart from a Realized One.
sn.sn46.10: The eightfold path does not rise apart from a Holy One’s training.
sn.sn46.11: Just as living creatures are based on the earth, the awakening factors are based on ethics.
sn.sn46.12: Just as the dawn precedes the sun, good friendship precedes the awakening factors.
sn.sn46.13: Just as the dawn precedes the sun, proper attention precedes the awakening factors.
sn.sn46.14: When Mahākassapa was sick, the Buddha taught him the awakening factors, inspiring him to a swift recovery.
sn.sn46.15: When Mahāmoggallāna was sick, the Buddha taught him the awakening factors, inspiring him to a swift recovery.
sn.sn46.16: When the Buddha was sick, Mahācunda taught him the awakening factors, inspiring him to a swift recovery.
sn.sn46.17: The awakening factors lead from the near to the far shore.
sn.sn46.18: Those who neglect the awakening factors neglect the path to the end of suffering.
sn.sn46.19: The awakening factors are noble and emancipating.
sn.sn46.20: The awakening factors lead to disenchantment.
sn.sn46.21: They’re called awakening factors because they lead to awakening.
sn.sn46.22: A simple statement on the awakening factors.
sn.sn46.23: Frequently focusing on things tends to promote similar qualities, whether good (awakening factors) or bad (hindrances).
sn.sn46.24: Improper attention grows the hindrances, proper attention grows the awakening factors.
sn.sn46.25: The awakening factors lead to non-decline.
sn.sn46.26: The awakening factors lead to the ending of craving.
sn.sn46.27: The awakening factors lead to the cessation of craving.
sn.sn46.28: The awakening factors partake of penetration.
sn.sn46.29: Nothing is as effective as getting rid of fetters as the awakening factors.
sn.sn46.30: Venerable Udāyı̄ celebrates his progress on the path, gaining faith as a householder, going forth, and realizing the Dhamma. Now he develops the awakening factors for the end of suffering.
sn.sn46.31: Skillful qualities are rooted in diligence, which promotes the awakening factors.
sn.sn46.32: Skillful qualities are rooted in proper attention, which promotes the awakening factors.
sn.sn46.33: Hindrances sully the mind like impurities in gold.
sn.sn46.34: Awakening factors purify the mind and lead to liberation.
sn.sn46.35: Improper attention promotes the hindrances; proper attention promotes the awakening factors.
sn.sn46.36: The awakening factors lead to growth and non-decline.
sn.sn46.37: Hindrances sully the mind, awakening factors purify it.
sn.sn46.38: Listening to the teaching, the hindrances are given up and the awakening factors developed.
sn.sn46.39: As some large trees with small seeds will overgrow and ruin other trees, so the hindrances overgrow and ruin the mind.
sn.sn46.40: The hindrances cause blindness, the awakening factors cause vision.
sn.sn46.41: Anyone who abandons the three kinds of discrimination does so due to the awakening factors.
sn.sn46.42: As the Wheel-turning Monarch manifests seven treasures, the Realized One manifests the seven awakening factors.
sn.sn46.43: The awakening factors crush Māra’s army.
sn.sn46.44: A stupid person has not developed the awakening factors.
sn.sn46.45: A wise person has developed the awakening factors.
sn.sn46.46: A person who has not developed the awakening factors is called “poor”.
sn.sn46.47: A person who has developed the awakening factors is called “prosperous”.
sn.sn46.48: As the dawn precedes the sunrise, so too good friendship precedes the awakening factors.
sn.sn46.49: No internal factor helps the awakening factors so much as proper attention.
sn.sn46.50: No external factor helps the awakening factors so much as good friendship.
sn.sn46.51: The Buddha spells out in detail the factors that nourish the hindrances, and those that nourish the awakening factors.
sn.sn46.52: Some wanderers tell some Buddhist mendicants that they, too, teach the five hindrances and the seven awakening factors, so what is the difference? The Buddha explains by giving a detailed analytical treatment that he says is beyond the scope of the wanderers.
sn.sn46.53: Which awakening factors should be developed when the mind is tired, and which when it is energetic? And what is always useful?
sn.sn46.54: Some wanderers tell some Buddhist mendicants that they, too, teach the five hindrances and the four Brahmā meditations, so what is the difference? The Buddha explains the detailed connection between the Brahmā meditations and the awakening factors, which taken together lead to liberation.
sn.sn46.55: The brahmin Saṅgārava asks why sometimes verses stay in memory while other times they don’t. The Buddha replies that it is due to the presence of either the hindrances of awakening factors. He gives a set of similes illustrating each of the hindrances with different bowls of water.
sn.sn46.56: Prince Abhaya reports Pūraṇa Kassapa’s view that there is no cause for ignorance or knowledge, and asks the Buddha’s opinion. The Buddha replies that the cause of ignorance is the hindrances, and the cause of knowledge is the awakening factors.
sn.sn46.57: A series of passages on the benefits of meditating on a skeleton. Some editions treat the sections as separate suttas.
sn.sn47.1: At Ambapālī’s mango grove, the Buddha teaches the mendicants about the “way to convergence”, the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn.sn47.2: At Ambapālī’s mango grove, the Buddha teaches the mendicants about the four kinds of mindfulness meditation and the practice of situational awareness.
sn.sn47.3: When a mendicant asks for a teaching to take on retreat, the Buddha issues an unexpected rebuke. Evidently the mendicant had been badly behaved; but now, he insists, he is sincere. The Buddha relents, and teaches the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, well grounded on ethics.
sn.sn47.4: Newly ordained mendicants should practice the four kinds of mindfulness meditation; trainees are practicing them, and perfected ones have perfected the practice.
sn.sn47.5: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are a complete heap of what is skillful.
sn.sn47.6: The parable of the quail and the hawk. When the quail ventured outside her ancestral territory, she became vulnerable. And what is a mendicant’s ancestral territory? The four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn.sn47.7: The parable of the foolish monkey who gets trapped in tar when it ventures outside its ancestral territory. And what is a mendicant’s ancestral territory? The four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn.sn47.8: The parable of the cook. They present different kinds of dishes to the king, and observe which the king likes. In the same way, a mendicant observes why their meditation succeeds or fails. When the four kinds of mindfulness meditation succeeds it leads to giving up hindrances and entering immersion.
sn.sn47.9: The Buddha decides to spend his final rains retreat at Vesālī in Beluvagāmaka. During the retreat he becomes very ill, but later recovers. Ānanda wonders who will guide the Saṅgha when the Buddha dies, but the Buddha says they should be their own refuge, grounded on the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn.sn47.10: When Ānanda visits the nuns’s quarters they tell him that their meditation is prospering to higher and higher levels. Ānanda reporrts the good news to the Buddha, who speaks of two ways of developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation: directed and undirected.
sn.sn47.11: Sāriputta asks the Buddha what is a great man, and the Buddha says it is someone whose mind has been freed by developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn.sn47.12: Sāriputta boldly claims that no-one has ever, or will ever, be more enlightened than the Buddha. He admits that he can read the minds of all the Buddhas, but he understands a principle of the Dhamma: all those who become awakened do so by giving up the five hindrances, practicing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, and developing the seven awakening factors.
sn.sn47.13: Sāriputta dies of illness, and the novice Cunda together with Ānanda take his bowl and robes and report the sad news to the Buddha. The Buddha dispels Ānanda’s sadness by speaking of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn.sn47.14: After the passing of Sāriputta and Moggallāna (whose actual death is unrecorded in the canon), the Buddha says the Saṅgha looks empty; yet he is not sad.
sn.sn47.15: When Venerable Bāhiya asks for a teaching to take on retreat, the Buddha teaches the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, well grounded on ethics.
sn.sn47.16: When Venerable Uttiya asks for a teaching to take on retreat, the Buddha teaches the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, well grounded on ethics.
sn.sn47.17: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation lead to the end of suffering.
sn.sn47.18: Just after the Buddha’s awakening, Brahmā Sahampati supports the Buddha’s reflection that the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the way to convergence.
sn.sn47.19: Two acrobats discuss whether one should support the other, or the other way around. The Buddha says they should support each other. In the same way we should practice the four kinds of mindfulness meditation both for one’s own benefit and to protect others.
sn.sn47.20: A parable that sets up an impossible challenge: to walk between a popular performer and the crowd jostling to see her, carrying a bowl of oil filled to the brim, while a man with a drawn sword waits to chop off your head if you spill a drop. That’s mindfulness!
sn.sn47.21: Venerable Bhadda asks Ānanda about the ethical virtues encouraged by the Buddha—what is their purpose? To develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn.sn47.22: Venerable Bhadda asks Ānanda about the conditions under which the true teaching lasts long or does not last long after the Buddha’s passing. Ānanda says it depends on whether the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are practiced.
sn.sn47.23: Venerable Bhadda asks Ānanda about the conditions under which the true teaching declines. Ānanda says it depends on whether the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are practiced.
sn.sn47.24: A simple teaching on the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn.sn47.25: A brahmin asks the Buddha about the conditions under which the true teaching lasts long or does not last long after the Buddha’s passing. The Buddha says it depends on whether the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are practiced.
sn.sn47.26: Sāriputta asks Anuruddha what makes someone a trainee. It is someone who has partly developed the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn.sn47.27: Sāriputta asks Anuruddha what makes someone an adept. It is someone who has fully developed the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn.sn47.28: Anuruddha claims to have developed the various direct knowledges by practicing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn.sn47.29: When the householder Sirivaḍḍha is sick, Ānanda visits him and encourages him to practice mindfulness meditation. But he has already developed them, and abandoned the five lower fetters.
sn.sn47.30: When the householder Mānadinna is sick, Ānanda visits him and encourages him to practice mindfulness meditation. But he has already developed them, and abandoned the five lower fetters.
sn.sn47.31: The full knowledge of mindfulness meditation was not learned before the Buddha.
sn.sn47.32: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation lead to peace.
sn.sn47.33: Someone who has neglected the four kinds of mindfulness meditation has neglected the noble path.
sn.sn47.34: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation lead from the near to the far shore.
sn.sn47.35: Mindfulness is the four kinds of mindfulness meditation. Situational awareness is watching the arising and passing of feelings, thoughts, and perceptions.
sn.sn47.36: When the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are developed, perfection or non-return may be expected.
sn.sn47.37: Developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, desire is abandoned.
sn.sn47.38: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation lead to realizing the deathless.
sn.sn47.39: The development of the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn.sn47.40: The Buddha teaches the simple passage on the four kinds of mindfulness meditation and an advanced analysis, which involves contemplating them as impermanent.
sn.sn47.41: Develop the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, don’t let the deathless be lost.
sn.sn47.42: The causes for the origination and cessation of the phenomena upon which the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are grounded.
sn.sn47.43: The Buddha tells the mendicants how, just after his awakening, Brahmā Sahampati supported the Buddha’s reflection that the four kinds of mindfulness meditation are the way to convergence
sn.sn47.44: Be mindful by developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn.sn47.45: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation are a heap of the skillful.
sn.sn47.46: When a mendicant asks for a teaching to take on retreat, the Buddha teaches the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, well grounded on restraint in the code of monastic rules.
sn.sn47.47: When a mendicant asks for a teaching to take on retreat, the Buddha teaches the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, well grounded on good bodily, verbal, and mental conduct.
sn.sn47.48: You should encourage your friends to practice the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn.sn47.49: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation help to understand the three feelings.
sn.sn47.50: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation help to give up the defilements.
sn.sn48.1: The five faculties are faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom.
sn.sn48.2: One who understands the gratification, the drawback, and the escape regarding the five faculties is a stream-enterer.
sn.sn48.3: One who understands the origin, the passing, the gratification, the drawback, and the escape regarding the five faculties is a stream-enterer.
sn.sn48.4: One who is freed after understanding the gratification, the drawback, and the escape regarding the five faculties is a perfected one.
sn.sn48.5: One who is freed after understanding the origin, the passing, the gratification, the drawback, and the escape regarding the five faculties is a perfected one.
sn.sn48.6: A true ascetic understands the five faculties in terms of the four noble truths.
sn.sn48.7: A true ascetic understands the five faculties in terms of the four noble truths.
sn.sn48.8: Each of the five faculties should be seen in a particular set of teachings.
sn.sn48.9: The Buddha gives a short explanation of each of the five faculties.
sn.sn48.10: The Buddha gives a detailed explanation of each of the five faculties.
sn.sn48.11: The Buddha explains the five faculties in terms of how they are obtained.
sn.sn48.12: One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments.
sn.sn48.13: One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments. A difference in faculties leads to a difference in fruits.
sn.sn48.14: One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments. The faculties are not barren.
