sn.sn48.17: One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments. The faculties are not barren.
sn.sn48.18: One who has developed the five faculties fully is a perfected one. Developing them to a lesser degree, one reaches lesser attainments. One who has none of them at all is an outsider.
sn.sn48.19: Someone who develops the faculties is said to be equipped with faculties.
sn.sn48.20: The five faculties lead to the ending of defilements in this very life.
sn.sn48.21: The Buddha did not claim to be awakened until he realized the five faculties.
sn.sn48.22: Three faculties: femininity, masculinity, and vitality.
sn.sn48.23: Three faculties relating to stages in the realization of awakening.
sn.sn48.24: Depending on the strength of the five faculties, one is perfected, or reaches a lesser attainment.
sn.sn48.25: Six faculties: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
sn.sn48.26: Six faculties: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind. One who understand these is a stream-enterer.
sn.sn48.27: Six faculties: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind. One who is freed by understanding these is perfected.
sn.sn48.28: The Buddha did not claim to be awakened until he realized the origin, the passing, the gratification, the drawback, and the escape regarding the six faculties.
sn.sn48.29: A true ascetic understands the six faculties in terms of the four noble truths.
sn.sn48.30: A true ascetic understands the six faculties in terms of the four noble truths.
sn.sn48.31: Five faculties: pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity.
sn.sn48.32: One who understands the gratification, the drawback, and the escape regarding the five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity is a stream-enterer.
sn.sn48.33: One who is freed after understanding the gratification, the drawback, and the escape regarding the five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity is a perfected one.
sn.sn48.34: A true ascetic understands the five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity in terms of the four noble truths.
sn.sn48.35: A true ascetic understands the five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity in terms of the four noble truths.
sn.sn48.36: The five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity are analyzed in detail.
sn.sn48.37: The five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity are analyzed in detail. In addition, each is to be seen in one of the three feelings.
sn.sn48.38: The five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity are analyzed in detail. In addition, each is to be seen in one of the three feelings.
sn.sn48.39: The five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity arise dependent on the appropriate contact, like sticks making fire.
sn.sn48.40: The five faculties of pleasure, pain, happiness, sadness, and equanimity are taught in a detailed exposition that treats them in an unusual order. The abandoning of each is related to the attainment of a particular meditative absorption.
sn.sn48.41: When Ānanda sees the Buddha’s sense faculties fading, the Buddha speaks on the decrepitude of old age, including verses.
sn.sn48.42: The brahmin Uṇṇābha points out that the five physical sense faculties do not share a common domain, so where do they come together? In the mind. Uṇṇābha pursues the teaching all the way to Nibbāna.
sn.sn48.43: The Buddha discusses the five faculties and the five powers. They are like a river that flows around a central island. From one point of view they can be considered different, but from another they are just the same stream.
sn.sn48.44: Sāriputta does not rely on faith in saying that the five faculties lead to the deathless, for he has seen this for himself.
sn.sn48.45: Having developed wisdom a mendicant may declare their awakening, as wisdom fulfills the other faculties.
sn.sn48.46: Having developed wisdom and immersion a mendicant may declare their awakening.
sn.sn48.47: Having developed energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom a mendicant may declare their awakening.
sn.sn48.48: Having developed faith, energy, mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom a mendicant may declare their awakening.
sn.sn48.49: Having developed mindfulness, immersion, and wisdom the mendicant Piṇḍola Bhāradvāja declared his awakening.
sn.sn48.50: The Buddha asks Sāriputta whether a noble disciple doubts the Buddha. Not only does he have faith, replies Sāriputta, but the other faculties each come to be developed in turn.
sn.sn48.51: Just as the lion is the king of beasts, wisdom is the chief of qualities that lead to awakening.
sn.sn48.52: Only when noble wisdom arises do the other four faculties become stable.
sn.sn48.53: How does someone recognize that they are a trainee? By understanding the four noble truths and the five faculties. But only a perfected one fully embodies these qualities.
sn.sn48.54: Just as all footprints fit into that of an elephant, wisdom is the chief of qualities that lead to awakening.
sn.sn48.55: Just as red sandalwood is the best of fragrances, wisdom is the chief of qualities that lead to awakening.
sn.sn48.56: When established in diligence, the five faculties come to be developed.
sn.sn48.57: Just after the Buddha’s awakening, Brahmā Sahampati supports the Buddha’s reflection that the five faculties lead to the deathless.
sn.sn48.58: A mendicant honors the Realized One and his teaching for the sake of the supreme sanctuary.
sn.sn48.59: The five faculties only arise in the dispensation of a Realized One.
sn.sn48.60: The five faculties only arise in the training of a Holy One.
sn.sn51.1: The four bases of psychic power lead from the near to the far shore.
sn.sn51.2: One who has neglected the four bases of psychic power has neglected the path to the end of suffering.
sn.sn51.3: The four bases of psychic power are noble and emancipating.
sn.sn51.4: The four bases of psychic power lead to dispassion.
sn.sn51.5: Those who have developed psychic powers in part have developed the four bases of psychic power in part.
sn.sn51.6: Those who have developed psychic powers in full have developed the four bases of psychic power in full.
sn.sn51.7: Whatever mendicants realize perfection do so by developing the four bases of psychic power.
sn.sn51.8: It is because of developing the four bases of psychic power that the Realized One is called a Buddha.
sn.sn51.9: On the night of his awakening, understanding and vision came to the Buddha regarding the four bases of psychic power.
sn.sn51.10: The Buddha says he could live to the end of the eon due to developing the four bases of psychic power. But Ānanda doesn’t get the hint.
sn.sn51.11: The Buddha recounts the process of inquiry that lead to him fully understanding the four bases of psychic power, as well as the powers that result from that.
sn.sn51.12: The four bases of psychic power are very beneficial.
sn.sn51.13: An analysis of the four bases of psychic power showing how enthusiasm, energy, higher consciousness, and inquiry work in the context of advanced meditation.
sn.sn51.14: When lazy monks were wasting time, the Buddha asks Moggallāna to stir them up. He shakes with his toe the large building in which they were staying, terrifying the monks. They sought refuge in the Buddha, and he taught them the four bases of psychic power.
sn.sn51.15: Ānanda explains to the brahmin Uṇṇābha that the spiritual path is lived to give up desire through the the four bases of psychic power. But Uṇṇābha says this is a contradiction, as desire is itself one of the four bases. Ānanda resolves the contradiction with the simile of a man walking to a park.
sn.sn51.16: Whatever ascetics are of great spiritual power have developed the four bases of psychic power.
sn.sn51.17: Whatever ascetics are of great spiritual power have developed the four bases of psychic power.
sn.sn51.18: It is because of developing the four bases of psychic power that a mendicant ends the defilements.
sn.sn51.19: The Buddha distinguishes between psychic powers, the basis for psychic power, and the development of the bases for psychic power.
sn.sn51.20: The Buddha teaches the bases for psychic power and analyzes them in detail.
sn.sn51.21: Before his awakening, the Buddha reflected on the path for developing the bases of psychic power.
sn.sn51.22: Ānanda asks the Buddha whether he travels to the Brahmā realm in a mind-made body or in a physical body.
sn.sn51.23: It is because of developing the four bases of psychic power that a mendicant ends the defilements.
sn.sn51.24: The four bases for psychic power are desire, energy, higher mind, and inquiry.
sn.sn51.25: The four bases for psychic power lead to perfection or once-return.
sn.sn51.26: The four bases for psychic power lead to seven benefits; perfection or one of the lesser attainments.
sn.sn51.27: The Buddha explains to Ānanda the difference between psychic powers, the basis for psychic power, and the development of the bases for psychic power.
sn.sn51.28: The Buddha explains to Ānanda the difference between psychic powers, the basis for psychic power, and the development of the bases for psychic power.
sn.sn51.29: The Buddha explains to several mendicants the difference between psychic powers, the basis for psychic power, and the development of the bases for psychic power.
sn.sn51.30: The Buddha explains to several mendicants the difference between psychic powers, the basis for psychic power, and the development of the bases for psychic power.
sn.sn51.31: Moggallāna is so very powerful due to developing the four bases for psychic power.
sn.sn51.32: The Realized One is so very powerful due to developing the four bases for psychic power.
sn.sn52.1: While meditating alone, Anuruddha reflected that one who has neglected the four kinds of mindfulness meditation has neglected the path to the end of suffering. Moggallāna reads his mind and visits to question him on this. Anuruddha speaks of developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation internally and externally, in terms of origin and cessation, and developing power over perceptions.
sn.sn52.2: While meditating alone, Anuruddha reflected that one who has neglected the four kinds of mindfulness meditation has neglected the path to the end of suffering. Moggallāna reads his mind and visits to question him on this. Anuruddha speaks of developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation internally and externally.
sn.sn52.3: When some mendicants ask Anuruddha how he attained such higher knowledge, he replies it is from developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn.sn52.4: Sāriputta and Moggallāna ask Anuruddha what a trainee mendicant should practice. He replies that it is the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn.sn52.5: Sāriputta and Moggallāna ask Anuruddha what an adept mendicant should practice. He replies that it is the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn.sn52.6: When Sāriputta ask Anuruddha how he attained such higher knowledge, he replies it is from developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn.sn52.7: The four kinds of mindfulness meditation lead to the ending of craving.
sn.sn52.8: Even if kings beg them to disrobe, a mendicant who has developed the four kinds of mindfulness meditation is unmoved. Their mind flows to Nibbāna like the Ganges to the sea.
sn.sn52.9: Sāriputta asks why Anuruddha looks so peaceful, and he replies it is due to developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn.sn52.10: Some mendicants ask Anuruddha how he remains equanimous even though ill. He replies that it is due to the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
sn.sn52.11: By developing the four kinds of mindfulness meditation Anuruddha surveys a thousand world systems.
sn.sn54.1: Breath meditation is very beneficial. It is developed by going into seclusion, establishing mindfulness on the breath, and proceeding through sixteen stages.
sn.sn54.2: Breath meditation is very beneficial. It is developed together with the seven factors of awakening.
sn.sn54.3: Breath meditation is very beneficial. It is developed by going into seclusion, establishing mindfulness on the breath, and proceeding through sixteen stages.
sn.sn54.4: Breath meditation is very beneficial. When developed it leads to perfection or once-return.
sn.sn54.5: Breath meditation is very beneficial. When developed it leads to perfection or one of the lesser attainments.
sn.sn54.6: When the Buddha asks Venerable Ariṭṭha about breath meditation, his answer, while not incorrect, does not do full justice to the practice.
sn.sn54.7: The Buddha sees Venerable Mahākappina meditating nearby and points out that his steadiness and tranquility are due to practicing breath meditation.
sn.sn54.8: Before his awakening the Buddha generally practiced breath meditation, which kept him alert and peaceful and let to the ending of defilements. One who wishes for any of the higher fruits of the renunciate life should practice the same way.
sn.sn54.9: The Buddha taught the meditation on the ugliness of the body, then left to go on retreat. However, many monks, misconstruing the teachings, ending up killing themselves. The Buddha taught breath meditation as a peaceful and pleasant abiding.
sn.sn54.10: When the Buddha asks Venerable Kimbila about breath meditation, he is unable to answer. At Ānanda’s urging, the Buddha explains in detail.
sn.sn54.11: The Buddha goes on a three month retreat, and later says that during that time he mostly practiced breath meditation.
sn.sn54.12: Venerable Lomasavaṅgīsa explains to Mahānāma that the difference between a trainee and the Realized One is that the trainees practice to give up the hindrances, whereas the Realized One has already ended all defilements.
sn.sn54.13: Answering Ānanda, the Buddha explains how one thing fulfills four things, four things fulfill seven things, and seven things fulfill two things.
sn.sn54.14: The Buddha explains to Ānanda how one thing fulfills four things, four things fulfill seven things, and seven things fulfill two things.
sn.sn54.15: Answering some mendicants, the Buddha explains how one thing fulfills four things, four things fulfill seven things, and seven things fulfill two things.

sn.sn55.1: Even a universal monarch may have a bad rebirth, but someone who has the four factors of stream-entry—experiential faith in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and ethical conduct—is freed from such destinies.
sn.sn55.2: Someone who has the four factors of stream-entry—experiential faith in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and ethical conduct—is a stream-enterer, destined for awakening.
sn.sn55.3: The lay follower Dīghāvu is ill and he asks for the Buddha to visit. Dīghāvu confirms that he possesses the four factors of stream-entry and in addition six contemplations leading to insight. Yet he is still worried that his close companion will miss him when he dies.
sn.sn55.4: Sāriputta explains to Ānanda that someone who has the four factors of stream-entry—experiential faith in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and ethical conduct—is a stream-enterer, destined for awakening.
sn.sn55.5: The Buddha asks Sāriputta about the four factors for stream-entry: association with good people, hearing the teaching, proper attention, and right practice. He also defines the “stream” and the “stream-enterer”.
sn.sn55.6: After the rainy season, the chamberlains Isidatta and Purāṇa hear that the Buddha is approaching and go to see him. They describe their joy at knowing when the Buddha is approaching, and speak of their special duties guarding the royal harem. The Buddha says they have four factors of stream-entry—experiential faith in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha; and here generosity rather than ethics as the final factor.
sn.sn55.7: The brahmin householders of Bamboo Gate ask the Buddha how to live well in the home. The Buddha teaches them seven principles they can apply to themselves, which are practical applications of the Golden Rule. Someone with these seven principles and the four factors of stream-entry is a stream-enterer.
sn.sn55.8: Ānanda asks the Buddha about the rebirths of several disciples. The Buddha confirms those details, and proposes a way for people to know for themselves by reflecting on the four factors of stream-entry.
sn.sn55.9: Ānanda asks the Buddha about the rebirths of several disciples. The Buddha confirms those details, and proposes a way for people to know for themselves by reflecting on the four factors of stream-entry.
sn.sn55.10: Ānanda asks the Buddha about the rebirths of several disciples. The Buddha confirms those details, and proposes a way for people to know for themselves by reflecting on the four factors of stream-entry.
sn.sn55.11: The Buddha teaches a thousand nuns the four factors of stream-entry.
sn.sn55.12: The Buddha contrasts a foolish brahmanical ritual called “going upwards” with the four factors of stream-entry.
sn.sn55.13: Sāriputta asks Ānanda how many things are given up and how many things possessed by the stream-enterer.
sn.sn55.14: A noble disciple has transcended fears of a bad rebirth.
sn.sn55.15: A noble disciple has transcended fears of a bad rebirth.
sn.sn55.16: You should encourage your friends in the four factors of stream-entry.
sn.sn55.17: You should encourage your friends in the four factors of stream-entry.
sn.sn55.18: Moggallāna visits the gods of the Thirty-Three and encourages them in the four factors of stream-entry.
sn.sn55.19: Moggallāna visits the gods of the Thirty-Three and encourages them in the four factors of stream-entry.
sn.sn55.20: Moggallāna visits the gods of the Thirty-Three and encourages them in the four factors of stream-entry.
sn.sn55.21: Mahānāma the Sakyan expresses his fear that if he dies unmindful he may go to a bad rebirth. The Buddha tells him not to fear, as he will definitely go to a good place, since he has long practiced the Dhamma.
sn.sn55.22: Mahānāma the Sakyan expresses his fear that if he dies unmindful he may go to a bad rebirth. The Buddha tells him not to fear, as he will definitely go to a good place, since he has the four factors of stream-entry.
sn.sn55.23: Mahānāma and Godhā the Sakyans discuss whether a stream-enterer has three or four factors. They go to the Buddha to settle it, and Mahānāma testifies to his faith.
sn.sn55.24: When Sarakāni the Sakyan died the Buddha declared him a stream-enterer. But others complained, since he was known as a drinker. However, the Buddha confirmed to Mahānāma that Sarakāni had undertaken the precepts on his deathbed.
sn.sn55.25: When Sarakāni the Sakyan died the Buddha declared him a stream-enterer. But others complained, since he was known as a drinker. However, the Buddha confirmed to Mahānāma that Sarakāni had undertaken the precepts on his deathbed.
sn.sn55.26: When the householder Anāthapiṇḍika was sick, Sāriputta reminds him of his considerable accomplishments in the Dhamma, analyzing stream-entry in ten factors, at which Anāthapiṇḍika recovers. Later he invited Sāriputta and Ānanda for a meal, and Sāriputta thanked him with verses.
sn.sn55.27: When the householder Anāthapiṇḍika was sick, Ānanda reminds him of the four factors of stream-entry, which Anāthapiṇḍika claims to possess.
sn.sn55.28: A noble disciple who is a layperson has eliminated the fear that comes from breaking precepts, possesses the four factors of stream-entry, and understands dependent origination.
sn.sn55.29: A noble disciple who is a layperson has eliminated the fear that comes from breaking precepts, possesses the four factors of stream-entry, and understands dependent origination.
sn.sn55.30: The Buddha teaches the four factors of stream-entry to Nandaka, the minister of the Licchavis. When his servant tells him it is time for his ritual bath, he says that the inner bathing of the Dhamma is enough.
sn.sn55.31: The four factors of stream-entry—with ethics as the fourth—are streams of merit.
sn.sn55.32: The four factors of stream-entry—with generosity as the fourth—are streams of merit.
sn.sn55.33: The four factors of stream-entry—with wisdom as the fourth—are streams of merit.
sn.sn55.34: The four factors of stream-entry are footprints of the gods.
sn.sn55.35: The four factors of stream-entry are footprints of the gods, for the gods hold non-violence as supreme.
sn.sn55.36: When a person possesses the four factors of stream-entry, the gods regard them as similar to themselves.
sn.sn55.37: The Buddha explains to Mahānāma what is a lay follower, what is a virtuous lay follower, and a lay follower accomplished in faith, generosity, and wisdom.
sn.sn55.38: Like rain falling on the mountain top, the four factors of stream-entry flow on to the ending of defilements.
sn.sn55.39: Kāḷigodhā the Sakyan lady confirms to the Buddha that she possesses the four factors of stream-entry.
sn.sn55.40: Someone who completely lacks the four factors of stream-entry is an ordinary person. But even a stream-enterer may be negligent if they do not make further effort in meditation.
sn.sn55.41: The four factors of stream-entry—with ethics as the fourth—are streams of merit, and like the ocean cannot be counted. With verses.
sn.sn55.42: The four factors of stream-entry—with generosity as the fourth—are streams of merit, and like the ocean cannot be counted. With verses.
sn.sn55.43: The four factors of stream-entry—with wisdom as the fourth—are streams of merit, and like the ocean cannot be counted. With verses.
sn.sn55.44: A noble disciple with the four factors of stream-entry is said to be prosperous.

an.an: The “Numbered” or “Numerical” Discourses are usually known as Aṅguttara Nikāya in Pali, abbreviated AN. However, the Pali tradition also knows the form Ekottara (“one-up” or “incremental”), and this is the form usually found in the northern collections. These collections organize texts in numbered sets, from one to eleven. Compared to the other nikāyas, they are more oriented to the lay community. The Ekottarikāgama (EA) in Chinese is a highly unusual text, which features a range of variations within itself when it comes even to basic doctrines. It shares considerably less in common with the Pali Aṅguttara than the other collections do with their counterparts. In addition, there is a partial Ekottarikāgama in Chinese, as well as a variety of individual discourses and fragments in Chinese and Sanskrit.

an.an6.96: Things rare to find in the world.
an.an6.98: A mendicant on the path cannot see any condition as permanent.
an.an6.99: A mendicant on the path cannot see any condition as pleasurable.
an.an6.100: A mendicant on the path cannot see any thing as not-self.
an.an6.101: A mendicant on the path cannot see extinguishment as suffering.
an.an6.105: Giving up rebirth in the three realms of existence, and developing the three trainings.
an.an6.107: Antidotes for greed, hate, and delusion.
an.an6.112: Antidotes for views of gratification, self, and wrong views.
an.an6.113: Antidotes for discontent, cruelty, and misconduct.
an.an6.114: Antidotes for discontent, unawareness, and desire.
an.an6.115: Antidotes for being hard to correct, bad friendship, and distraction.
an.an6.116: Antidotes for restlessness, lack of restraint, and heedlessness.
an.an6.117: Things that enable or obstruct meditation on the body.
an.an6.118: Things that enable or obstruct meditation on various things.
an.an6.119: Possessing six qualities, the householder Tapussa sees the Dhamma.
an.an6.120-139: Possessing six qualities, various householders see the Dhamma.
an.an7.1: Seven qualities that make a mendicant either agreeable or disagreeable to their fellow monastics.
an.an7.2: Seven qualities that make a mendicant either agreeable or disagreeable to their fellow monastics.
an.an7.3: The powers of faith, energy, conscience, prudence, mindfulness, samādhi, and wisdom.
an.an7.4: The powers of faith, energy, conscience, prudence, mindfulness, samādhi, and wisdom.
an.an7.5: The wealth of faith, energy, conscience, prudence, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
an.an7.6: The wealth of faith, energy, conscience, prudence, learning, generosity, and wisdom.
an.an7.7: Migāra of Rohaṇa is a wealthy man, but even his riches are vulnerable to the vicissitudes of life, unlike spiritual wealth.
an.an7.8: The fetters of compliance, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
an.an7.9: The purpose of the spiritual life is to give up the fetters of compliance, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
an.an7.10: The fetters of compliance, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, envy, and stinginess.
an.an7.11: The underlying tendencies of sensual desire, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
an.an7.12: The purpose of the spiritual life is to give up the underlying tendencies of sensual desire, repulsion, views, doubt, conceit, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
an.an7.13: Factors that make a family worth visiting.
an.an7.14: Seven persons who are worthy of gifts and veneration.
an.an7.15: Seven people found in the world who are like those in water.
an.an7.16: Seven persons who are worthy of gifts and veneration.
an.an7.17: Seven persons who are worthy of gifts and veneration.
an.an7.18: Seven persons who are worthy of gifts and veneration.
an.an7.19: Seven persons who are worthy of gifts and veneration.
an.an7.20: A mendicant with seven qualities is qualified to graduate.
an.an7.21: The Buddha teaches the seven principles of non-decline to the Licchavis at the Sārandada shrine near Vesālī.
an.an7.22: King Ajātasattu of Magadha wishes to invade the Vajjians, and sends his minister Vassakāra to tell the Buddha of his intentions. The Buddha recalls the time he taught the seven principles of non-decline to the Vajjians.
an.an7.23: The Buddha teaches the seven principles of non-decline to the mendicants.
an.an7.24: The Buddha teaches seven principles of non-decline to the mendicants.
an.an7.25: The Buddha teaches seven principles of non-decline to the mendicants.
an.an7.26: The Buddha teaches seven principles of non-decline to the mendicants.
an.an7.27: The Buddha teaches seven principles of non-decline to the mendicants.
an.an7.28: Seven qualities leading to the decline of a mendicant who is a trainee.
an.an7.29: Seven qualities leading to the decline of a lay follower.
an.an7.30: Seven failures for a lay follower.
an.an7.31: Seven ruins for a lay follower.
an.an7.32: A god speaks of the the seven principles of non-decline to the Buddha, who repeats it to the mendicants.
an.an7.33: The Buddha tells of hearing the seven principles of non-decline from a god.
an.an7.34: The Buddha tells of hearing the seven principles of non-decline from a god.
an.an7.35: The Buddha tells of hearing the seven principles of non-decline from a god. Sāriputta offers additional explanation.
an.an7.36: When a friend has seven factors, one should associate with them.
an.an7.37: When a mendicant has seven factors, one should stay close to them even if they send you away.
an.an7.38: With seven qualities, a mendicant will soon realize the four kinds of textual analysis.
an.an7.39: With seven qualities, Sāriputta realized the four kinds of textual analysis.
an.an7.40: Seven qualities leading to mastery of meditation.
an.an7.41: With seven qualities, Sāriputta became a master of meditation.
an.an7.42: Sāriputta visits a sectarian hermitage and hears them saying that someone who lives the spiritual life for twelve years is fit to graduate. The Buddha rejects this, saying that a mendicant is qualified to graduate not merely by completing a certain number  of years, but because of their spiritual qualities.
an.an7.43: Ānanda visits a sectarian hermitage and hears them saying that someone who lives the spiritual life for twelve years is fit to graduate. The Buddha rejects this, saying that a mendicant is qualified to graduate not merely by completing a certain number  of years, but because of their spiritual qualities.
an.an7.44: Seven planes of consciousness in which beings may be reborn.
an.an7.45: The path factors are the prerequisite for right immersion.
an.an7.46: Seven fires, some physical, some psychological.
an.an7.47: The brahmin Uggatasarīra has arranged a great sacrifice. On Ānanda’s advice, he asks the Buddha how to make a sacrifice beneficial.
an.an7.48: Meditating on seven perceptions leads to the deathless, in brief.
an.an7.49: Meditating on seven perceptions leads to the deathless, in detail.
an.an7.50: The brahmin Jāṇussoṇī asks the Buddha about behaviors that are a blemish to the celibate life.
an.an7.51: By focusing on their own gendered attributes, a man or woman becomes attached to them and develops lust for the opposite sex.
an.an7.52: The lay followers of Campā seek a teaching from the Buddha. Together with Sāriputta, they ask the Buddha about what makes a gift fruitful.
an.an7.53: Sāriputta and Moggallāna are on tour in the southern hills. A deity informs the laywoman Veḷukaṇṭakī that they are approaching. When Sāriputta expresses his amazement that she speaks with the gods, she goes on to list many other of her own amazing qualities.
an.an7.54: The Buddha explains why a noble disciple has no doubt when it comes to the unexplained points.
an.an7.55: Seven kinds of rebirth for non-returners, as well as extinguishment by not grasping.
an.an7.56: Two gods come to the Buddha on Vulture’s Peak and declare that the nuns are liberated. Moggallāna interrogates one of the deities on what he means, and the Buddha adds further explanation.
an.an7.57: The Buddha explains the benefits of giving that are visible in the present life, and one that is only apparent in the next.
an.an7.58: Four areas where the Realized One has nothing to hide, and three ways he is irreproachable.
an.an7.59: Venerable Kimbila asks the Buddha the reasons for the long-lasting of Buddhism after the Buddha’s demise.
an.an7.61: Before his awakening, Moggallāna is struggling with sleepiness in meditation. The Buddha visits him and gives seven ways to dispel drowsiness, and other important teachings.
an.an7.62: The incalculable benefits of merit that last for many aeons.
an.an7.63: Anāthapiṇḍika’s home was in an uproar due to the badly behaved Sujātā, newly wedded to one of his sons. The Buddha speaks to her on the different kinds of wives.
an.an7.64: When someone is angry, they wish ill upon their enemy, and are disappointed if they do well. This sutta includes a powerful set of verses.
an.an7.65: A sense of conscience is the foundation that leads step by step to liberation.
an.an7.66: A rare discourse on cosmic evolution. The Buddha describes the successive appearance of seven suns and how even the earth will be burned up.
an.an7.67: When a king’s fortress is well supplied with seven things and has four kinds of food supplies it is impregnable. Similarly, a noble disciple with seven qualities and the four absorptions is impregnable.
an.an7.68: A mendicant who has seven qualities is worthy, with a special emphasis on listening to and learning the teaching.
an.an7.69: The blossoming of the Shady Orchid Tree delights the gods of the Thirty-Three, and in the same way, the renunciation of a Buddhist ascetic is delightful.
an.an7.70: Sāriputta reflects on what a mendicant should revere in order to develop the wholesome. He reports to the Buddha that these things are indeed found in himself.
an.an7.71: Liberation doesn’t happen because you wish for it, but because you develop the path.
an.an7.72: It would be better for a monk to embrace a blazing fire than to lie with a maiden.
an.an7.73: There have been many great teachers in the past, who should not be reviled. But reviling a single noble disciple is even more serious.
an.an7.74: Araka was a famous teacher long ago, when the life span was much greater than today. Nevertheless, he still taught impermanence; how much more is it relevant today!
an.an7.75: An expert in monastic conduct has seven qualities.
an.an7.76: An expert in monastic conduct has seven qualities.
an.an7.77: An expert in monastic conduct has seven qualities.
an.an7.78: An expert in monastic conduct has seven qualities.
an.an7.79: An expert in monastic conduct shines with seven qualities.
an.an7.80: An expert in monastic conduct shines with seven qualities.
an.an7.81: An expert in monastic conduct shines with seven qualities.
an.an7.82: An expert in monastic conduct shines with seven qualities.
an.an7.83: The Buddha teaches the Vinaya expert Upāli a short summary of the teaching.
an.an7.84: Seven principles for settling issues and disputes that have arisen in the community.
an.an8.1: The eight benefits of practicing the meditation on love.
an.an8.2: Eight conditions that lead to the arising of wisdom, its growth and perfection.
an.an8.3: Due to eight qualities, a mendicant is displeasing to their fellow monastics, but with the opposite qualities is pleasing.
an.an8.4: Due to eight qualities, a mendicant is displeasing to their fellow monastics, but with the opposite qualities is pleasing.
an.an8.5: The eight worldly conditions in brief: pain and loss, fame and disgrace, praise and blame, pleasure and pain.
an.an8.6: The eight worldly conditions in detail: pain and loss, fame and disgrace, praise and blame, pleasure and pain.
an.an8.7: Devadatta’s downfall was the eight worldly conditions.
an.an8.8: In a discourse evidently set some time after the Buddha’s passing, Venerable Uttara, staying in a distant land, teaches that a mendicant should review their own failings and those of others. Questioned by Sakka, the Lord of Gods, Uttara affirms that he learned this from the Buddha.
an.an8.9: The Buddha praises the grace and restraint of Venerable Nanda.
an.an8.10: When a certain monk was admonished, he responded by attacking his reprovers. The Buddha tells the other monks to expel him, explaining that when such a monk lives hidden in the Saṅgha, his corruption can spread to the other monks.
an.an8.11: The brahmin Verañja rebukes the Buddha for his lack of respect for senior brahmins. He levels a series of criticisms, each of which the Buddha deflects by redefining terms. The Buddha affirms that his claim to superiority is because he was the first to achieve awakening.
an.an8.12: General Sīha, a prominent disciple of the Jains, visits the Buddha against the wishes of Mahāvīra, the Jain leader. He challenges the Buddha by bringing up the various ways that people criticize him. Convinced by the Buddha’s response, Sīha wishes to take refuge in the Buddha; but the Buddha urges him to be cautious and to continue supporting the Jains.
an.an8.13: With eight qualities a royal thoroughbred is worthy of a king. Likewise, with eight qualities a mendicant is worthy.
an.an8.14: Eight flaws in wild horses, similar to eight flaws in mendicants.
an.an8.16: A mendicant with eight qualities is worthy of being sent on a mission.
an.an8.17: A woman imprisons a man in eight ways.
an.an8.18: A man imprisons a woman in eight ways.
an.an8.19: Demons delight in the ocean for eight reasons, and likewise the mendicants delight in the Dhamma for eight reasons.
an.an8.20: On a full-moon night, the Buddha was to recite the code of conduct for the monks. However, he remained silent until dawn, due to the presence of a corrupt monk.
an.an8.21: The Buddha celebrates the eight amazing qualities of the householder Ugga of Vesālī. Ugga himself speaks of these qualities.
an.an8.22: The Buddha celebrates the eight amazing qualities of the householder Ugga of Hatthigāma. Ugga himself speaks of these qualities.
an.an8.23: The Buddha celebrates the seven amazing qualities of the householder Hatthaka of Āḷavī. When he hears of this, Hatthaka is anxious to know that no lay people were present. Learning of this, the Buddha adds humility as an eight quality.
an.an8.24: The Buddha learns from Hatthaka of Āḷavī how he maintains a large following. He then celebrates Hatthaka’s eight good qualities.
an.an8.25: Questioned by his relative Mahānāma, the Buddha explains what makes someone a Buddhist lay follower, a virtuous lay follower, and a lay follower practicing for the welfare of all.
an.an8.26: Questioned by Jīvaka Komārabhacca, the Buddha explains what makes someone a Buddhist lay follower, a virtuous lay follower, and a lay follower practicing for the welfare of all.
an.an8.27: Eight very different kinds of powers.
an.an8.28: Eight powers of a perfected one.
an.an8.29: Eight lost opportunities for spiritual practice.
an.an8.30: Venerable Anuruddha reflects that the teachings is for someone who is of few wishes, content, secluded, energetic, mindful, peaceful, and wise. To these seven thoughts, the Buddha adds an eighth: the teaching is for those who delight in non-proliferation. Practicing in line with these eight thoughts of a great man, Venerable Anuruddha achieves perfection.
an.an8.31: Eight ways of giving a gift.
an.an8.32: This verse on qualities of a good person appears to be a fragment of text, perhaps originally part of the previous sutta.
an.an8.34: The rewards of giving are compared to fields of different qualities.
an.an8.35: When giving, if you expect a certain result in the next life, you can get it, if the conditions are right.
an.an8.36: The good deeds of giving, ethics, and meditation lead to good rebirths, depending on the level to which they are developed.
an.an8.37: A good person gives gifts in eight ways.
an.an8.38: When a good person is born, it benefits eight kinds of people, like a rain-cloud showering all over the land.
an.an8.39: Eight streams of merit, consisting in going for refuge and five kinds of gifts.
an.an8.40: Eight kinds of misdeed are conducive to bad outcomes.
an.an8.41: When the sabbath is observed by following the eight precepts, one lives for that day like the perfected ones. Such a sabbath is glorious.
an.an8.42: When the sabbath is observed by following the eight precepts, one lives for that day like the perfected ones. The benefits are explained at length.
an.an8.43: The Buddha teaches the wealthy laywoman Visākhā that when the sabbath is observed by following the eight precepts, one lives for that day like the perfected ones.
an.an8.44: The Buddha teaches the layman Vāseṭṭha that when the sabbath is observed by following the eight precepts, one lives for that day like the perfected ones. Vāseṭṭha exclaims that such a practice would be widely beneficial.
an.an8.45: The Buddha teaches the laywoman Bojjhā that when the sabbath is observed by following the eight precepts, one lives for that day like the perfected ones. Bojjhā exclaims that such a practice would be widely beneficial.
an.an8.46: Some “Agreeable” gods put on a display of music and dance for Venerable Anuruddha, but he is not impressed. He then asks the Buddha how women are reborn in such a heaven.
an.an8.47: The Buddha teaches the laywoman Visākhā eight qualities through which a woman may be reborn among the Agreeable gods.
an.an8.48: The Buddha teaches the housewife Nakulamātā eight qualities through which a woman may be reborn among the Agreeable gods.
an.an8.49: The Buddha teaches the laywoman Visākhā four qualities through which a woman succeeds in this life, and four through which she succeeds in the next.
an.an8.50: The Buddha teaches the mendicants four qualities through which a woman succeeds in this life, and four through which she succeeds in the next.
an.an8.51: Mahāpajāpatī Gotamī, the Buddha’s foster mother, requests ordination from the Buddha. He declines, until urged to relent by Ānanda. He allows Mahāpajāpatī to go forth on eight conditions.
an.an8.52: With eight qualities a monk may be appointed to teach the nuns.
an.an8.53: Mahāpajāpatī wishes to go on retreat, so the Buddha teaches her eight principles that summarize the Dhamma in brief.
an.an8.54: Dīghajāṇu of the Koliyans asks the Buddha to teach in a way suitable for lay people who enjoy life. The Buddha teaches four practical ways to ensure success in this life, and another four ways to ensure success in the next.
an.an8.55: The brahmin Ujjaya is going abroad, and asks the Buddha to teach him. The Buddha teaches four practical ways to ensure success in this life, and another four ways to ensure success in the next.
an.an8.56: The Buddha explains how addiction to sensual pleasures is perilous.
an.an8.57: With eight qualities, a mendicant is worthy.
an.an8.58: With eight qualities, a mendicant is worthy.
an.an8.59: Eight kinds of person are worthy.
an.an8.60: Eight kinds of person are worthy.
an.an8.61: The Buddha describes eight cases where a mendicant has a desire for material things. Sometimes they fall under the sway of that desire, but sometimes they rise above it.
an.an8.62: Eight sets of qualities pertain to benefiting oneself and others.
an.an8.63: A monk asks for teachings before going on retreat, but the Buddha rebukes him, as he has not practiced sincerely. Nevertheless, he persists, and the Buddha teaches him meditation in detail.
an.an8.64: At Gayā, the Buddha describes his meditation before awakening. He was able to see lights and forms, converse with gods, and understand the deeds that made them gods.
an.an8.65: Eight dimensions of meditative mastery, based on the vision of certain shapes and colors.
an.an8.66: Eight meditative liberations, based on the vision of forms and the attainment of the formless.
an.an8.67: Eight kinds of ignoble statement that misrepresent the truth.
an.an8.68: Eight kinds of noble statement that convey the truth.
an.an8.69: Eight kinds of assemblies: aristocrats, brahmins, householders, ascetics, and various deities. The Buddha has visited each of these in disguise.
an.an8.70: When the Buddha gives up his life-force, an earthquake is felt. The Buddha explains to Ānanda the eight causes of earthquakes.
an.an8.71: Beginning with faith, a mendicant completes all good qualities that fulfill liberation.
an.an8.72: Beginning with faith, a mendicant completes all good qualities that fulfill liberation.
an.an8.73: Various mendicants practice mindfulness of death, but do so inadequately. The Buddha explains how to do so with proper urgency,
an.an8.74: A mendicant should reflect each night on the dangers that lie around them, and practice mindfulness of death with urgency to give up the unwholesome.
an.an8.75: Eight accomplishments, both worldly and spiritual.
an.an8.76: Eight accomplishments, both worldly and spiritual, in detail.
an.an8.77: Sāriputta describes eight cases where a mendicant has a desire for material things. Sometimes they fall under the sway of that desire, but sometimes they rise above it.
an.an8.78: Eight sets of qualities pertain to benefiting oneself and others, explained by Sāriputta.
an.an8.79: Eight conditions for the decline or success of a trainee mendicant.
an.an8.80: Eight grounds for laziness, and the corresponding eight grounds for energy.
an.an8.81: Mindfulness and situational awareness are a foundation for developing higher spiritual qualities leading to liberation.
an.an8.82: Venerable Puṇṇiya asks the Buddha why he sometimes feels like teaching and other times doesn’t.
an.an8.83: The root of all things, and other factors that apply to all things.
an.an8.84: The Buddha teaches how to be a success as a master thief. Unusually, this discourse has no “spiritual” counterpart, so it sounds like the Buddha just giving a lesson in thievery!
an.an8.86: When the householders of Icchānaṅgala make a racket in the monastery, the Buddha asks his attendant Nāgita what is going on. The Buddha speaks strongly of his dislike for material gains, and his love of seclusion.
an.an8.87: Eight reasons the Saṅgha may overturn the bowl against a lay follower.
an.an8.88: Eight reasons the lay followers may declare no confidence or confidence regarding a mendicant.
an.an8.89: Eight reasons the lay followers may enjoin an act of reconciliation on a mendicant, or relax said act.
an.an8.90: Eight things a mendicant charged with aggravated misconduct must observe.
an.an9.1: Beginning with good friendship, the Buddha teaches nine things that give rise to the qualities that lead to awakening.
an.an9.2: The things that a mendicant relies on as supports in spiritual practice.
an.an9.3: Venerable Meghiya, while attending on the Buddha, wants to go off and meditate in a forest alone. The Buddha discourages him, but he goes anyway. When his meditation doesn’t go well, he returns chastened to the Buddha, who teaches him about the benefits of good companions and other fundamentals of a balanced spiritual practice.
an.an9.4: Nandaka is teaching the monks when the Buddha arrives. Unbeknown to those inside, the Buddha waits until the talk was finished, then enters. Nandaka is embarrassed at keeping the Buddha waiting, but the Buddha praises him and offers a teaching on the four things a mendicant should complete. Nandaka then teaches five benefits of listening to Dhamma.
an.an9.5: A noble disciple who develops four powers overcomes five fears.
an.an9.6: Four kinds of person who one should or should not associate with. A similar distinction is made regarding robes, almsfood, lodgings, towns, and countries.
an.an9.7: The wanderer Sutavā asks the Buddha about five things a perfected one cannot do; the Buddha expands it to nine.
an.an9.8: The wanderer Sajjha asks the Buddha about five things a perfected one cannot do; the Buddha expands it to nine, which differ slightly from AN 9.7.
an.an9.9: Nine kinds of persons: the eight noble persons and the ordinary person.
an.an9.10: Nine persons are worthy of gifts: the eight noble persons and a member of the spiritual family.
an.an9.11: After the rains season, Sāriputta takes leave of the Buddha. Another monk falsely accuses Sāriputta of hitting him before leaving. The Buddha calls Sāriputta to answer the accusation. Before the Saṅgha, Sāriputta denies it, uttering a powerful statement of spiritual prowess.
an.an9.12: Sāriputta visits some wanderers, who claim that only perfected ones are free from bad rebirth. Sāriputta has no opinion on this, but asks the Buddha, who replies that even stream-enterers are freed from lower rebirth.
an.an9.13: Venerables Mahākoṭṭhita and Sāriputta discuss whether the spiritual path is for the purpose of changing the results of deeds.
an.an9.14: Sāriputta questions Venerable Samiddhi on the basis of intentions and thoughts.
an.an9.15: The body is compared to a boil with nine orifices.
an.an9.16: Nine perceptions to be developed in meditation.
an.an9.17: Nine factors in how a family relates to the Saṅgha.
an.an9.18: Nine factors for a glorious sabbath: the eight precepts and the meditation on love.
an.an9.19: Some deities come to the Buddha and speak of how their practice in their past life was limited and unsatisfactory.
an.an9.20: The wealthy and devoted lay supporter Anāthapiṇḍika rather curiously says that only poor alms are given in his home. The Buddha praises gracious and bounteous generosity. But meditation surpasses even the greatest offering.
an.an9.21: A comparison of the people of India, of Uttarakuru, and of the heaven of the Thirty-Three.
an.an9.22: Nine kinds of horses are compared with nine kinds of monks.
an.an9.23: Nine things that are rooted in craving.
an.an9.24: Nine realms into which sentient beings may be reborn.
an.an9.25: Nine reflections by which a mendicant knows their mind has wisdom.
an.an9.26: Venerables Candikāputta and Sāriputta differ in their interpretation of a teaching proposed by the notorious schismatic Devadatta.
an.an9.27: A householder who has eliminated the perils that come with breaking the five precepts, and possesses the four factors of stream-entry is freed from lower rebirths.
an.an9.28: A householder who has eliminated the perils that come with breaking the five precepts, and possesses the four factors of stream-entry is freed from lower rebirths.
an.an9.31: Nine meditative states, each of which arises from the cessation of something present in the previous state.
an.an9.33: Nine progressive meditation states, explained in detail.
an.an9.34: Sāriputta declares that extinguishment is bliss, precisely because nothing is felt there. He explains this apparent paradox with reference to the nine progressive meditations.
an.an9.35: Just as a foolish cow can get in trouble wandering the mountains, a foolish mendicant can get lost practicing absorption if they do it wrongly.
an.an9.36: The ending of defilements happens due to the practice of absorption meditation.
an.an9.37: Ānanda exclaims how amazing it is that the Buddha has found a way to freedom while still experiencing the world. Questioned by the monk Udāyī, Ānanda recounts a discussion on advanced meditation with the nun Jaṭilagāhiyā.
an.an9.38: Two brahmin cosmologists ask the Buddha to decide between competing claims as to whether the cosmos is infinite. Rejecting metaphysical claims, the Buddha says that there is no end of the world that can be reached by traveling; but without reaching the end of the world you can’t be free of suffering.
an.an9.39: In the wars between gods and demons, they find safety only in their own fortress. Similarly, a mendicant finds safety in absorption.
an.an9.40: A bull elephant, annoyed by living in the herd, goes off by himself. Similarly, a mendicant feeling crowded in a monastery goes off by themselves and happily meditates in seclusion.
an.an9.41: The householder Tapussa reflects that it is renunciation that distinguishes lay from monastic. The Buddha responds by giving a long account of his practice of absorption before awakening.
an.an9.42: At Udāyī’s request, Ānanda explains an obscure verse spoken (in SN 2.7) by a deity. The nine progressive meditations are the escape from confinement.
an.an9.43: The Buddha speaks of a “direct witness’, that is, someone who personally has thorough  and proficient experience of the different meditation states.
an.an9.44: One liberated by wisdom first enters the meditation states, then understands them.
an.an9.45: One freed both ways is both proficient in and understands the meditation states.
an.an9.46: The teaching apparent in the present life is experienced provisionally in deep meditation, and completely when the defilements end.
an.an9.47: Extinguishment apparent in the present life is experienced provisionally in deep meditation, and completely when the defilements end.
an.an10.1: The purpose of ethics, leading step by step to liberation.
an.an10.2: There’s no need to make a wish to get enlightened; it happens naturally when the conditions are there.
an.an10.3: The Buddha teaches how, like a tree that grows due to its leaves, liberation follows when ethics is present.
an.an10.4: Sāriputta teaches how, like a tree that grows due to its leaves, liberation follows when ethics is present.
an.an10.5: Ānanda teaches how, like a tree that grows due to its leaves, liberation follows when ethics is present.
an.an10.6: Ānanda asks the Buddha about a mysterious state of immersion in meditation where there is no normal perception, yet one is still conscious.
an.an10.7: Ānanda asks Sāriputta about a mysterious state of immersion in meditation where there is no normal perception, yet one is still conscious. Sāriputta confirms that there is, and claims to have attained it.
an.an10.8: Ten factors, beginning with faith, that a mendicant should fulfill.
an.an10.9: Ten factors, beginning with faith, that a mendicant should fulfill.
an.an10.10: Ten factors, beginning with faith, that a mendicant should fulfill.
an.an10.11: Five factors that a mendicant should have, and five factors of a lodging that they should occupy.
an.an10.12: A mendicant should abandon the five hindrances and possess the five factors of the adept.
an.an10.13: Five lower and five higher fetters.
an.an10.14: Five kinds of emotional barrenness and five emotional shackles.
an.an10.15: Diligence is the foremost of all good qualities.
an.an10.17: Ten qualities that serve as protector.
an.an10.18: Ten qualities that serve as protector, in detail.
an.an10.19: Ten noble abodes in which the noble ones of the past, present and future abide.
an.an10.20: Ten noble abodes in which the noble ones of the past, present and future abide, in detail.
an.an10.21: Like a lion, a Realized One roars his preeminence based on ten powers.
an.an10.22: The Buddha claims to be assured regarding the various different doctrinal hypotheses, based on the ten powers.
an.an10.23: Some things are to be given by by body, others by speech, and still others by wisdom.
an.an10.24: Venerable Mahācunda teaches that, though a mendicant might claim to be free of greed, hate, and delusion, this is not always the case.
an.an10.25: Ten universal dimensions of meditation, or kasiṇas.
an.an10.26: The female lay follower Kāḷī of Kuraraghara in Avantī asks Venerable Mahākaccāna about a verse spoken by the Buddha in “The Maidens’ Questions” (SN 4.25). He replies in terms of the ten universal dimensions of meditation.
an.an10.27: Some wanderers claim to teach the direct knowledge of all things, just like the Buddha. However the Buddha disputes this by presenting ten “Great Questions” that they cannot answer.
an.an10.28: Some lay people ask the nun from Kajaṅgalā regarding the ten “Great Questions”. Though she has not heard this teaching herself, she explains from her own understanding, and is praised by the Buddha.
an.an10.29: Starting with a comparison with the King of Kosala, the Buddha teaches a series of ten advanced teachings. He culminates by affirming that he teaches the full understanding of sensual pleasures, forms, and feelings.
an.an10.30: King Pasenadi returns victorious from battle and immediately goes to see the Buddha, bowing reverentially to his feet, and declaring ten reasons for his love and devotion to the Buddha.
an.an10.31: The Buddha teaches Venerable Upāli the ten reasons for establishing the training rules.
an.an10.32: Ten reasons for suspending the recitation of the code of conduct.
an.an10.33: Ten qualities a mendicant should have to be appointed to judge a dispute.
an.an10.34: Ten qualities a mendicant should have to give ordination.
an.an10.35: Ten qualities a mendicant should have to give dependence.
an.an10.36: Ten qualities a mendicant should have to be attended by a novice.
an.an10.37: Ten reasons for schism in the Saṅgha.
an.an10.38: Ten reasons for harmony in the Saṅgha.
an.an10.39: The Buddha teaches Ānanda the ten reasons for schism in the Saṅgha, as well as the outcome of causing schism.
an.an10.40: The Buddha teaches Ānanda the ten reasons for harmony in the Saṅgha, as well as the outcome of creating harmony.
an.an10.41: Ten reasons for disputes in the Saṅgha.
an.an10.42: Ten roots for disputes in the Saṅgha.
an.an10.43: Ten roots for disputes in the Saṅgha.
an.an10.44: A mendicant who wishes to admonish another should first reflect on five things in themselves and establish a further five.
an.an10.45: Ten dangers for a monk who enters a royal harem.
an.an10.46: The Sakyans say that they don’t always observe the eight precepts on the sabbath. The Buddha strongly admonishes them to be more consistent.
an.an10.47: Mahāli the Licchavi asks the Buddha for the causes of bad deeds.
an.an10.48: Topics for frequent reflection by one gone forth.
an.an10.49: Ten things that depend on the body.
an.an10.50: Some monks are arguing, so the Buddha teaches them ten warm-hearted principles.
an.an10.51: The Buddha teaches that, if you can’t read anyone else’s mind, read your own by regular self-reflection.
an.an10.52: Sāriputta teaches that, if you can’t read anyone else’s mind, read your own by regular self-reflection.
an.an10.53: The Buddha doesn’t praise stagnation in wholesome qualities, let alone decline.
an.an10.54: The Buddha teaches that, if you can’t read anyone else’s mind, read your own by regular self-reflection. Includes a teaching on various things that should or should not be cultivated.
an.an10.55: Sāriputta explains what the Buddha meant by a mendicant who is in decline.
an.an10.56: Ten meditative perceptions that lead to the deathless.
an.an10.57: Ten meditative perceptions that lead to the deathless.
an.an10.58: The root of all things, and similar principles.
an.an10.59: Ten reflections that strengthen the mind of a renunciate.
an.an10.60: The monk Girimānanda is sick. The Buddha encourages Ānanda to visit him and speak of ten perceptions.
an.an10.61: Even though ignorance has no discernible first point, it still has a cause.
an.an10.62: Even though craving has no discernible first point, it still has a cause.
an.an10.63: Those who have certainty in the Buddha may realize the final goal in this life or the next.
an.an10.64: Stream-enterers may realize the final goal in this life or the next.
an.an10.65: Sāriputta explains to the wanderer Sāmaṇḍakāni that rebirth is suffering, freedom from rebirth is happiness.
an.an10.66: Sāriputta explains to the wanderer Sāmaṇḍakāni that dissatisfaction is suffering, enjoyment is happiness.
an.an10.67: At Naḷakapāna the Buddha invites Sāriputta to teach. He speaks of ten qualities that lead to decline or non-decline.
an.an10.68: At Naḷakapāna the Buddha invites Sāriputta to teach. He speaks of ten qualities that lead to decline or non-decline.
an.an10.69: The monks are sitting around chatting about this and that. The Buddha admonishes them and teaches ten topics of conversation suitable for mendicants.
an.an10.70: The monks are sitting around chatting about this and that. The Buddha admonishes them and teaches ten grounds of praise.
an.an10.71: If a mendicant wishes to attain spiritual heights, they should begin by practicing the code of training rules.
an.an10.72: When the Buddha receives noisy visitors, several monks withdraw to a nearby forest to meditate. The Buddha praises them, saying that noise is a thorn to absorption.
an.an10.73: Ten desirable things that are hard to get.
an.an10.75: The female lay disciple Migasālā questions Ānanda how the Buddha could have declared her father and her uncle had the same level of spiritual attainment, when one was much more strict than the other. Ānanda conveys this to the Buddha, who responds that only such as he can pass judgment, since the spiritual faculties of individuals are complex and hard to understand.
an.an10.76: Without rebirth, old age, and death, there would be no teaching of Dhamma. The Buddha teaches a series of sets of three things leading to liberation.
an.an10.77: A bad monk has ten bad qualities, like a crow.
an.an10.78: Jain ascetics have ten bad qualities.
an.an10.81: Giving up ten things, the Buddha lives free of limits.
an.an10.82: A mendicant cannot achieve progress if they have ten bad qualities starting with lack of faith.
an.an10.83: Venerable Puṇṇiya asks why the Buddha sometimes feels like teaching, other times not.
an.an10.84: When a mendicant declares enlightenment, the Buddha or another accomplished meditator examines them.
an.an10.85: Venerable Mahācunda teaches that when a mendicant boasts about spiritual attainments, the Buddha or another accomplished meditator examines them.
an.an10.86: Venerable Mahākassapa teaches that when a mendicant declares enlightenment, the Buddha or another accomplished meditator examines them.
an.an10.87: The Buddha, speaking in reference to the monk Kalandaka, explains ten qualities that lead to discord or unity.
an.an10.88: A mendicant who insults their spiritual companions incurs ten disasters.
an.an10.89: The monk Kokālika accuses Sāriputta and Moggallāna of having evil wishes. The Buddha defends them. Later, Kokālika suffers calamity and is reborn in hell.
an.an10.90: Ten powers by which a mendicant knows that they have ended the defilements.
an.an10.91: The Buddha teaches Anāthapiṇḍika ten kinds of persons who enjoy sensual pleasures.
an.an10.92: A noble disciple has eliminated five perils, realized the four factors of stream-entry, and seen the noble process.
an.an10.93: Anāthapiṇḍika visits some wanderers, who ask him about the Buddha’s views. Anāthapiṇḍika asks them to explain their own view first. He then declares his own understanding of impermanence, leaving the wanderers speechless.
an.an10.94: The householder Vajjiyamāhita visits some wanderers, who accuse the Buddha of condemning all asceticism. Vajjiyamāhita counters this by saying the Buddha only criticizes what is worthy of criticism. The Buddha praises him, and explains in detail what this means.
an.an10.95: The wanderer Uttiya asks the Buddha a series of ten metaphysical questions as to whether the cosmos is finite, etc. The Buddha responds by saying that he only teaches the end of suffering. Uttiya goes on to ask whether all beings will be liberated. The Buddha is silent, and Ānanda answers on his behalf.
an.an10.96: The wanderer Kokanada meets Ānanda at the baths and engages him on the topic of the ten metaphysical questions.
an.an10.97: With ten qualities, a mendicant is worthy.
an.an10.98: With ten qualities, a senior mendicant is at ease wherever they live.
an.an10.99: When Upāli asks to go into retreat, the Buddha warns him that secluded wilderness dwellings are hard to endure unless one is accomplished in meditation. He gives a long account of the training required before going into solitude, and ends by encouraging Upāli to stay in the Saṅgha.
an.an10.100: Ten things must be given up before attaining perfection.
an.an10.101: Three ascetic perceptions lead to seven results.
an.an10.102: The seven factors of awakening lead to realizing the three knowledges.
an.an10.103: The tenfold wrong path leads to failure, the tenfold right path leads to success.
an.an10.104: When a person has wrong view, all their path development is wrong. But when they have right view, everything good follows.
an.an10.105: Ignorance is the precursor of wrong view and the other bad qualities, while right view is the opposite.
an.an10.106: Each of the ten path factors wears away its opposite.
an.an10.107: The Buddha speaks of a southern land called “Bath”, but says that a spiritual bath is better.
an.an10.108: The Buddha speaks of a purgative for curing ailments, but says that a spiritual purgative is better.
an.an10.109: The Buddha speaks of a emetic for curing ailments, but says that a spiritual emetic is better.
an.an10.110: The ten path factors each expel their opposite.
an.an10.111: An adept has fulfilled the ten path factors.
an.an10.112: An adept has fulfilled the ten path factors.
an.an10.113: One should understand what is the teaching and what is contrary to the teaching, in brief.
an.an10.114: One should understand what is the teaching and what is contrary to the teaching, in detail.
an.an10.115: One should understand what is the teaching and what is contrary to the teaching. After hearing this in brief from the Buddha, the mendicants seek a detailed answer from Ānanda.
an.an10.116: The wanderer Ajita informs the Buddha that a philosopher has proposed 500 cases for knowing that and argument has been won or lost. The Buddha asks the mendicants about these.
an.an10.117: The wrong path is the near shore where most people dwell; the right path is the far shore, where few have crossed over.
an.an10.118: The wrong path is the near shore where most people dwell; the right path is the far shore, where few have crossed over.
an.an10.119: The Buddha sees Jāṇussoṇī observing the brahmanical ceremony of “descent”. The Buddha teaches his revised version.
an.an10.120: The Buddha teaches his revised version of the brahmanical ceremony of “descent” to the mendicants.
an.an10.121: As the dawn is the forerunner of the sunrise, right view is the forerunner of the path.
an.an10.122: The ten path factors lead to the end of the defilements.
an.an10.167: The Buddha sees Jāṇussoṇī observing the brahmanical ceremony of “descent”. The Buddha teaches his revised version.
an.an10.168: The Buddha teaches his revised version of the brahmanical ceremony of “descent” to the mendicants.
an.an10.169: The Buddha teaches the brahmin Saṅgārava that the wrong path is the near shore where most people dwell; the right path is the far shore, where few have crossed over.
an.an10.170: The wrong path is the near shore where most people dwell; the right path is the far shore, where few have crossed over.
an.an10.171: One should understand what is the teaching and what is contrary to the teaching, in brief.
an.an10.172: One should understand what is the teaching and what is contrary to the teaching. After hearing this in brief from the Buddha, the mendicants seek a detailed answer from Mahākaccāna.
an.an10.173: One should understand what is the teaching and what is contrary to the teaching, in detail.
an.an10.174: The various kinds of bad deeds are caused by greed, hate, and delusion.
an.an10.175: Through the teaching one may avoid the various kinds of bad deeds.
an.an10.176: Cunda the smith tells the Buddha of rites of purification practiced by the western brahmins. The Buddha explains purification in his teaching.
an.an10.177: Jāṇussoṇī describes brahmanical memorial rites for the dead, and asks if sharing merit actually benefits dead relatives. The Buddha replies that it might do in some circumstances.
an.an10.211: The ten kinds of bad deeds lead you to hell; the ten good deeds to heaven.
an.an10.216: Those who do the ten kinds of bad deeds are like creepy creatures.
an.an10.217: The Buddha asserts that one’s kamma must be exhausted before making an end of suffering. This statement precedes a long explanation of deeds and their causes.
an.an10.218: The Buddha asserts that one’s kamma must be exhausted before making an end of suffering. This statement precedes a long explanation of deeds and their causes.
an.an10.219: The Buddha asserts that one’s kamma must be exhausted before making an end of suffering. If one develops the heart’s release through love, no bad deeds can persist there.
an.an10.220: The Buddha teaches a brahmin that bad conduct leads to hell, good conduct to heaven.
an.an11.1: Good conduct leads to non-regret, to joy, and so on all the way to liberation.
an.an11.2: A virtuous person need not make a wish; it is natural for the path to flow on.
an.an11.3: The Buddha teaches that ethical conduct is the vital cause of the good qualities that lead to awakening.
an.an11.4: Sāriputta teaches that ethical conduct is the vital cause of the good qualities that lead to awakening.
an.an11.5: Ānanda teaches that ethical conduct is the vital cause of the good qualities that lead to awakening.
an.an11.6: When a mendicant abuses their fellow monastics, eleven disasters follow.
an.an11.7: Ānanda asks the Buddha about a deep state of meditation where all normal perception has ceased, but there is still perception. The Buddha affirms that such a state exists. Ānanda puts the same question to Sāriputta, and gets the same answer.
an.an11.8: Ānanda asks the Buddha about a deep state of meditation where all normal attention has ceased, but there is still attention The Buddha affirms that such a state exists.
an.an11.9: The Buddha tells Venerable Sandha to meditate like a trained thoroughbred, not like a wild colt. Doing so, they may attain a deep state.
an.an11.10: Possessing various sets of qualities, a mendicant is best among gods and men.
an.an11.11: Mahānāma the Sakyan sees that the monks are preparing robes after the rains season. Knowing that the Buddha will soon depart, he asks how they are to live with their busy lives.
an.an11.12: Mahānāma the Sakyan sees that the monks are preparing robes after the rains season. Knowing that the Buddha will soon depart, he asks how they are to live with their busy lives.
an.an11.13: Nandiya the Sakiyan moves to Sāvatthī to be near the Buddha. At the end of the rains, he asks the Buddha’s advice on how to live.
an.an11.14: Venerable Subhūti brings the young monk Saddha to meet the Buddha. The Buddha goes on to teach the manifestations of faith.
an.an11.15: The meditation on love has eleven benefits.
an.an11.16: Asked by a householder to teach a path to freedom, Venerable Ānanda explains no less than eleven meditative states that may serve as doors to the deathless.
an.an11.17: A cowherd with eleven qualities is competent to look after a herd of cattle. Likelwise, a mendicant with eleven qualities can grow in the Dhamma.
an.an11.18: The Buddha is asked by the mendicants about a deep state of meditation where all normal perception has ceased, but there is still perception.
an.an11.19: The Buddha teaches the mendicants about a deep state of meditation where all normal perception has ceased, but there is still perception.
an.an11.20: Sāriputta is asked by the mendicants about a deep state of meditation where all normal perception has ceased, but there is still perception.
an.an11.21: Sāriputta teaches the mendicants about a deep state of meditation where all normal perception has ceased, but there is still perception.

ja.ja1: This discourse regarding Truth was delivered by the Blessed One, while he was dwelling in the Great Monastery at Jetavana near Savatthi. But who, you ask, was it that led up to this tale?
ja.ja2: “Untiring, deep they dug.”—This discourse was delivered by the Blessed One whilst he was dwelling at Savatthi.
ja.ja3: “If in this faith.” This lesson too was taught by the Blessed One while at Savatthi, also about a Brother who gave up persevering.
ja.ja4: “With humblest start.” This story was told by the Master about the Elder named Little Wayman, while in Jivaka’s Mango-grove near Rajagaha.
ja.ja5: “Dost ask how much a peck of rice is worth?”—This was told by the Master, whilst at Jetavana, about the Elder Udayi, called the Dullard.
ja.ja6: “Those only ‘godlike’ call.”—This story was told by the Blessed One while at Jetavana, about a wealthy Brother.
ja.ja7: “Your son am I.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about the story of Vasabha-Khattiya, which will be found in the Twelfth Book in the Bhaddasala-jataka.
ja.ja8: “Their heart’s desire.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about a Brother who gave up persevering. In this Jataka both the Introductory Story and the Story of the Past will be given in the Eleventh Book in connexion with the Samvara-jataka; the incidents are the same both for that Jataka and for this, but the stanzas are different.
ja.ja9: “Lo! these grey hairs.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about the Great Renunciation, which has already been related in the Nidana-Katha.
ja.ja10: “The man who guards not.”—This story was told by the Master while in the Anupiya Mango-grove near the town of Anupiya, about the Elder Bhaddiya (the Happy), who joined the Brotherhood in the company of the six young nobles with whom was Upali. Of these the Elders Bhaddiya, Kimbila, Bhagu, and Upali attained to Arahatship; the Elder Ananda entered the First Path; the Elder Anuruddha gained all-seeing vision; and Devadatta obtained the power of ecstatic self-abstraction. The story of the six young nobles, up to the events at Anupiya, will be related in the Khandahala-jataka.
ja.ja11: “The upright man.”—This story was told by the Master in the Bamboo-grove near Rajagaha about Devadatta. The story of Devadatta will be related, up to the date of the Abhimara-employment, in the Khandahala-jataka; up to the date of his dismissal from the office of Treasurer, in the Cullahamsa-jataka; and, up to the date of his being swallowed up by the earth, in the Sixteenth Book in the Samudda-vanija-jataka.
ja.ja12: “Keep only with the Banyan Deer.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about the mother of the Elder named Prince Kassapa. The daughter, we learn, of a wealthy merchant of Rajagaha was deeply rooted in goodness and scorned all temporal things; she had reached her final existence, and within her breast, like a lamp in a pitcher, glowed her sure hope of winning Arahatship. As soon as she reached knowledge of herself, she took no joy in a worldly life but yearned to renounce the world. With this aim, she said to her mother and father, “My dear parents, my heart takes no joy in a worldly life; fain would I embrace the saving doctrine of the Buddha. Suffer me to take the vows.”
ja.ja13: “Cursed be the dart of love.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about the temptation caused to Brethren by the wives of their mundane life. This will be related in the Indriya-jataka in the Eighth Book. Said the Blessed One to the Brother, “Brother, it was because of this very woman that in bygone days you met your death and were roasted over glowing embers.” The Brethren asked the Blessed One to explain this. The Blessed One made clear what had been concealed from them by re-birth.
ja.ja14: “There’s nothing worse.” This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about the Elder Tissa, called Direct-alms the Less. Tradition says that, while the Master was dwelling at the Bamboo-grove near Rajagaha, the scion of a wealthy house, Prince Tissa by name, coming one day to the Bamboo-grove and there hearing a discourse from the Master, wished to join the Brotherhood, but, being refused because his parents would not give their consent, obtained their consent by following Rattha-pala’s example and refusing food for seven days, and finally took the vows with the Master.
ja.ja15: “For when a deer.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about an unruly Brother. Tradition says that this Brother was unruly and would not heed admonition. Accordingly, the Master asked him, saying, “Is it true, as they say, that you are unruly and will not heed admonition?”
ja.ja16: “In all three postures.”—This story was told by the Master while dwelling do the Badarika Monastery in Kosambi, about the Elder Rahula whose heart was set on observing the rules of the Brotherhood.
ja.ja17: “In light or dark.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about two Brethren who had joined the Brotherhood in their old age. Tradition says that they were living in a forest-dwelling in the Kosala country, and that one was named the Elder Dark and the other the Elder Light. Now one day Light said to Dark, “Sir, at what time does what is called cold appear?” “It appears in the dark half of the month.” And one day Dark said to Light, “Sir, at what time does what is called cold appear?” “It appears in the light half of the month.”
ja.ja18: “If folk but knew.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about Feasts for the Dead. For at this time the folk were putting to death goats, sheep, and other animals, and offering them up as what is called a Feast for the Dead, for the sake of their departed kinsmen. Finding them thus engaged, the Brethren asked the Master, saying, “Just now, sir, the folk are taking the lives of many living creatures and offering them up as what is called a Feast for the Dead. Can it be, sir, that there is any good in this?”
ja.ja19: “Take thought of life hereafter.” This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about the offering of a sacrifice under vow to gods. Tradition says that in those days folk when going a journey on business, used to slay living creatures and offer them as a sacrifice to gods, and set out on their way, after making this vow,—“If we come safely back with a profit, we will give you another sacrifice.” And when they did come safely back with a profit, the Idea that this was all due to gods made them slay a number of living creatures and offer them up as a sacrifice to obtain a release from their vow.
ja.ja20: “I found the footprints.” This story was told by the Master whilst journeying on an alms-pilgrimage through Kosala, when he had come to the village of Nalaka-pana (Cane-drink) and was dwelling at Ketaka-vana near the Pool of Nalaka-pana, about cane-sticks. In those days the Brethren, after bathing in the Pool of Nalaka-pana, made the novices get them cane-sticks for needle-cases, but, finding them hollow throughout, went to the Master and said, “Sir, we had cane-sticks got in order to provide needle-cases; and from top to bottom they are quite hollow. Now how can that be?”
ja.ja21: “The antelope knows well.”—This story was told by the Master while at the Bamboo-grove about Devadatta. For once when the Brethren were gathered together in the Hall of Truth, they sat talking reproachfully of Devadatta, saying, “Sirs, with a view to destroy the Buddha Devadatta hired bowmen, hurled down a rock, and let loose the elephant Dhana-palaka; in every way he goes about to slay the Lord of Wisdom.” Entering and seating himself on the seat prepared for him, the Master asked, saying, “Sirs, what is the theme you are discussing here in conclave?” “Sir,” was the reply, “we were discussing the wickedness of Devadatta, saying that he was always going about to slay you.” Said the Master, “It is not only in these present days, Brethren, that Devadatta goes about seeking to slay me; he went about with the like intent in bygone days also,—but was unable to slay me.” And so saying, he told this story of the past.
ja.ja22: “The dogs that in the royal palace grow.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about acting for the good of kinsfolk, as will be related in the Twelfth Book in the Bhaddasala-jataka. It was to drive home that lesson that he told this story of the past.
ja.ja23: “Though prostrate now.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about a Brother who gave up persevering. For it was then that the Master addressed that Brother and said, “Brethren, in bygone days the wise and good persevered even amid hostile surroundings, and, even when they were wounded, still did not give in.” And, so saying, he told this story of the past.
ja.ja24: “No matter when or where.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana about another Brother who gave up persevering. But, in this case, he addressed that Brother and said, “Brethren, in bygone days the wise and good still persevered even when wounded.” And, so saying, he told this story of the past.
ja.ja25: “Change thou the spot.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about an ex-goldsmith, who had become a Brother and was co-resident with the Captain of the Faith (Sariputta).
ja.ja26: “Through hearing first.”—This story was told by the Master while at the Bamboo-grove, about Devadatta, who, having secured the adherence of Prince Ajata-sattu, had attained both gain and honour. Prince Ajata-sattu had a Monastery built for Devadatta at Gaya-sisa, and every day brought to him five hundred kettles of perfumed three-year-old rice flavoured with all the choicest flavourings. All this gain and honour brought Devadatta a great following, with whom Devadatta lived on, without ever stirring out of his Monastery.
ja.ja27: “No morsel can he eat.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about a lay-disciple and an aged Elder.
ja.ja28: “Speak only words of kindness.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about the bitter words spoken by the Six. For, in those days the six, when they disagreed with respectable Brethren, used to taunt, revile and jeer them, and load them with the ten kinds of abuse. This the Brethren reported to the Blessed One, who sent for the Six and asked whether this charge was true. On their admitting its truth, he rebuked them, saying, “Brethren, hard words gall even animals: in bygone days an animal made a man who had used harsh language to him lose a thousand pieces.” And, so saying, he told this story of the past.
ja.ja29: “With heavy loads.”—This story was told by the Master while at Jetavana, about the Double Miracle, which, together with the Descent from Heaven, will be related in the Thirteenth Book, in the Sarabhamiga-jataka.
