pli-tv-bi-pm.pli-tv-bi-pm-pc161: A nun who picks up anything considered valuable must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm.pli-tv-bi-pm-pc162: A nun who makes a needle-case of bone, ivory, or horn must destroy it and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm.pli-tv-bi-pm-pc163: A nun who makes a bed with long legs must shorten them and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm.pli-tv-bi-pm-pc164: A nun who makes a bed with luxurious upholstery must remove the upholstery and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm.pli-tv-bi-pm-pc165: A nun who makes a bandage that is too large must cut it down and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm.pli-tv-bi-pm-pc166: A nun who makes a robe that is too large must cut it down and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm.pli-tv-bi-pm-pd: The rules in this category are known in Pali as pāṭidesanīya, “entailing acknowledgement.” There are eight such rules for the nuns. These rules, together with all the other rules apart from those entailing expulsion and suspension, are classed as light offenses, lahukāpatti. For light offenses there is no penalty apart from confession. What distinguishes these rules from the pācittiyas is the manner of confession, which is done using a unique formula. These eight rules for the nuns are equivalent to a single rule for the monks (bhikkhu pācittiya 39). In summary they say that a nun who asks for special food must acknowledge the offense.
pli-tv-bi-pm.pli-tv-bi-pm-sk: The rules in this category are known in Pali as sekhiya, “involving training.” There are seventy-five such rules, and they are the same both for the nuns and the monks. These rules, together with all the other rules apart from those entailing expulsion and suspension, are classed as light offenses, lahukāpatti. For light offenses there is no penalty apart from confession. What distinguishes these rules from the other light offenses is that there is no transgression unless the offender is acting out of disrespect for the rule. The sekhiyas are rules of etiquette and as such are often tightly bound to the norms that prevailed in ancient India. Because of temporal and geographical separation from the society in which these rules were established, many of these rules are now obsolete. The rules are too short to merit individual treatment here.
pli-tv-bi-pm.pli-tv-bi-pm-as: The rules in this category are known in Pali as adhikaraṇasamathadhamma, “principles for the settling of legal issues.” There are seven such principles, and they are the same both for the nuns and the monks. These principles are not rules in the ordinary sense and as such fall outside of the classification into serious and light offenses. Instead, they set out the proper methods for dealing with legal issues. The monastic code and its analysis include only a brief expression of each of these principles, with the detailed exposition on how to apply them found in the Samathakkhandhaka. The legal issues to be settled through these principles fall into four categories: disputes, accusations, offenses, and proceedings. These categories include all legal issues that may arise within a monastic institution. The last of the four, proceedings, include monastic procedures such as ordination and the keeping of the observance day, the uposatha.
pli-tv-bi-pm.pli-tv-bi-pm-as1: A legal issue can only be resolved if all those concerned are present during the process. In addition the procedure must comply with all aspects of monastic law.
pli-tv-bi-pm.pli-tv-bi-pm-as2: If a nun is known for her clarity of memory, any accusations against her may be settled through that nun declaring her innocence based on her memory of the relevant events.
pli-tv-bi-pm.pli-tv-bi-pm-as3: A nun who is insane is not responsible for her own offenses. Any offenses she may have committed while insane can be cleared through a declaration of past insanity.
pli-tv-bi-pm.pli-tv-bi-pm-as4: All offenses, except those entailing expulsion, should be cleared by making amends in the appropriate manner.
pli-tv-bi-pm.pli-tv-bi-pm-as5: A dispute that drags on without resolution may be settled through majority vote.
pli-tv-bi-pm.pli-tv-bi-pm-as6: A nun who is intractable in regard to the offenses she has committed may be subject to an act of censure.
pli-tv-bi-pm.pli-tv-bi-pm-as7: If a dispute involves a number of offenses on both sides, and the Order considers that dealing with all the offenses in the usual manner is likely to lead to harshness or schism, then the Order may decide to do a procedure whereby all the offenses are cleared. Offenses that cannot be cleared in this way are those entailing expulsion and suspension, as well as any offenses that involve lay people.
pli-tv-bi-pm.pli-tv-bi-vb:
The bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga (“the analysis of the nuns’ rules”) contains the monastic code for nuns, the bhikkhunī-pātimokkha, embedded in explanatory material. The bhikkhunī-vibhaṅga is divided into seven chapters, each dealing with a separate class of rules, grouped according to the offense incurred in breaking them, with the exception of the adhikaraṇasamathadhamma (“the principles for resolving legal issues”), which are principles to be applied rather than rules in the strict sense.

Each rule together with its explanatory material forms an independent unit, a sub-chapter. These units begin with one or more origin stories, which tell the circumstances that led the Buddha to lay down a particular rule. The rule is then stated, followed by a word commentary that analyzes every significant word contained in the rule. After the word commentary follows a permutation series in which a variety of different scenarios are evaluated and offenses assigned as appropriate. At the end comes a non-offense clause, stating important exceptions to the rule, sometimes followed by individual case studies, in which the Buddha decides the offense incurred in ambiguous cases.
pli-tv-bi-pm.pli-tv-bi-vb-pj: The rules in this category are known in Pali as pārājika. The exact meaning of the Pali word is disputed, but there is no doubt that it refers to expulsion from the monastic Order. There are eight such rules for the nuns, four of which are shared with the monks. Anyone who breaches any of these rules immediately loses her status as a nun. She is expelled from the Order and ineligible for re-ordination for the rest of her life. The pārājikas, together with the next category of rules, the saṅghādisesas, are collectively known as serious offenses, garukāpatti. These rules are the most fundamental ones for the proper living of the monastic life.

pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pj1: A nun who voluntarily has sexual intercourse is expelled.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pj2: A nun who steals anything of value is expelled.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pj3: A nun who kills a human being is expelled.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pj4: A nun who falsely claims a profound spiritual attainment is expelled.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pj5: A lustful nun who agrees to a lustful man touching her anywhere below the collar bone and above the knees is expelled.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pj6: A nun who does not take any action when she knows that another nun has committed an offense entailing expulsion is expelled. This is the first among a large of rules in which the notorious nun Thullanandā was the original offender. Either Thullanandā was an exceptionally bad nun or she is a literary stand-in for the real offenders.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pj7: A nun who persistently sides with a monk who has been legitimately ejected is expelled.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pj8: A nun who agrees to all of eight kinds of flirtatious behavior is expelled. This is the first among a large number of rules that features the notorious group of six nuns. These nuns were possibly affiliated with the group of six monks, or they are modelled on them.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-ss: The rules in this category are known in Pali as saṅghādisesa. The exact meaning of the Pali word is disputed, but according to the commentary it means that the Order (saṅgha) is required at the beginning (ādi) and for the rest (sesa) of the procedure. There are seventeen such rules for the nuns, seven of which are shared with the monks. Anyone who breaches any of these rules is to be suspended from the monastic Order. The offender must go through a process of rehabilitation called mānatta, “trial period,” lasting half a month. During the rehabilitation period the offending nun loses her normal status and is required to follow a number of special provisions, such as not staying in the same room as a regular nun and not going anywhere by herself. When the rehabilitation process has been completed, an Order of twenty nuns is required to formally rehabilitate the offender. She then regains her full status as a nun. The saṅghādisesas and the pārājikas are collectively known as serious offenses, garukāpatti. After the pārājikas, the saṅghādisesas are the most fundamental rules for the proper living of the monastic life.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-ss1: A nun who uses litigation inappropriately is to be suspended.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-ss2: A nun who ordains a female criminal sentenced to death is to be suspended.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-ss3: A nun who walks alone in an uninhabited area or spends the night by herself is to be suspended.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-ss4: A nun who, without permission, reinstates another nun who has been legitimately ejected is to be suspended.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-ss5: A lustful nun who receives food from a lustful man is to be suspended.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-ss6: A nun who encourages another nun to receive food from a lustful man is to be suspended.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-ss7: A nun who acts as a go-between for a relationship between a man and a woman is to be suspended.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-ss8: A nun who in anger falsely accuses another nun of an offense entailing expulsion is to be suspended.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-ss9: A nun who in anger uses a ploy to falsely accuse another nun of an offense entailing expulsion is to be suspended.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-ss10: A nun who persistently says that she will renounce Buddhism and join another religion is to be suspended.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-ss11: A nun who persistently says that the other nuns are biased because a legal issue has not been decided to her liking is to be suspended.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-ss12: Nuns who are persistently notorious for inappropriate socialization, who create difficulties for the Order, and who hide each other offenses are suspended.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-ss13: A nun who persistently encourages other nuns to act in contravention of the previous rule is to be suspended.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-ss14: A nun who tries to cause a schism in the Order is to be suspended.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-ss15: A nun who supports another nun who is trying to cause a schism in the Order is to be suspended.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-ss16: A nun who refuses to be corrected about breaches of the monastic code is to be suspended.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-ss17: A nun who causes the lay people in a certain place to lose confidence in the teachings of the Buddha should be banished from that place. If she refuses to accept the banishment, she is to be suspended.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np: The rules in this category are known in Pali as nissaggiya pācittiya, “entailing relinquishment and confession.” There are thirty such rules for the nuns, the same number as for the monks, although only eighteen are held in common. These rules, together with the remaining rules of the monastic code, are classed as light offenses, lahukāpatti. For light offenses there is no penalty apart from confession. For the nissaggiya pācittiyas, however, any item involved in the committing of an offense must be relinquished. Once the offense has been confessed, the item is, with a few exceptions, returned to the offender. The purpose of this process is perhaps to remind the offender to treat the item in the appropriately manner.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np1: A nun who has more than one bowl must relinquish the extra bowl and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np2: A nun who distributes robe-cloth inappropriately must relinquish the robe-cloth and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np3: A nun who takes back a robe given in exchange to another nun must relinquish the robe and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np4: A nun who asks for one thing but after receiving it says she wants something else must relinquish the item and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np5: A nun who gets one thing from a steward but then exchanges it for something else must relinquish the item and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np6: A nun who exchanges away a requisite belonging to the Order that is designated for a specific purpose must relinquish the item and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np7: A nun who asks for a requisite belonging to the Order that is designated for a specific purpose and then exchanges it for something else must relinquish the item and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np8: A nun who exchanges away a collective requisite designated for a specific purpose must relinquish the item and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np9: A nun who asks for a collective requisite designated for a specific purpose and then exchanges it for something else must relinquish the item and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np10: A nun who asks for a personal requisite for a specific purpose and then exchanges it for something else must relinquish the item and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np11: A nun who asks for an expensive, heavy outer-robe must relinquish it and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np12: A nun who asks for an expensive, light outer-robe must relinquish it and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np13: A nun who keeps extra robe-cloth for more than ten day must relinquish the robe-cloth and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np14: A nun who stays apart from any of her five robes for more than one day must relinquish the robe and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np15: A nun may keep extra robe-cloth for a month if she is expecting more. A nun who keeps it beyond that must relinquish the robe-cloth and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np16: A nun who asks a lay person for robe-cloth, except if her robes are lost or destroyed, must relinquish the robe-cloth and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np17: When a nun’s robes are lost or destroyed, she should show moderation in asking for robe-cloth. If she does not, she must relinquish the robe-cloth and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np18: If a lay person wants to buy a robe for a nun, and the nun asks them for a fine robe, she must relinquish the robe and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np19: If two separate lay people want to buy a robe for a nun, and the nun asks them to put their money together to buy her a fine robe, she must relinquish the robe and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np20: When money to be used for a nun’s robe has been placed with a steward in the proper way, that nun may hint to the steward that she needs a robe. If she does not get a robe in this way, but she does get one by acting inappropriately, she must relinquish the robe and confess the offense. This rule also prescribes the procedure through which a lay follower comes to hold money on behalf of a donor who wishes to support a nun.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np21: A nun who receives money must relinquish it and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np22: A nun who receives money through trading must relinquish it and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np23: A nun who barters, except with fellow monastics, must relinquish the item received and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np24: A nun who asks for a new bowl when her existing bowl is still useable must relinquish it and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np25: A nun who keeps tonics for more than seven days must relinquish them and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np26: A nun who gives robe-cloth to another nun, but then takes it back in anger, must relinquish it and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np27: A nun who asks for thread and then has robe-cloth woven with it must relinquish the robe-cloth and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np28: If a lay person is having robe-cloth woven for a nun and that nun makes demands of the weavers, then she must relinquish the robe-cloth and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np29: A nun who stores “an urgent robe” beyond the acceptable time limit must relinquish it and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-np30: A nun who diverts to herself an offering intended for the Order must relinquish the item and confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc: The rules in this category are known in Pali as pācittiya, “entailing confession.” There are one hundred and sixty-six such rules for the nuns, seventy of which are shared with the monks. This is the largest class of rules in the monastic code. These rules, together with all the other rules apart from those entailing expulsion and suspension, are classed as light offenses, lahukāpatti. For light offenses there is no penalty apart from confession.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc1: A nun who eats raw garlic must confess the offense. This rule includes the Suvaṇṇahaṁsa Jātaka tale, “the Golden goose Jātaka,” found in slightly different form in the Jātaka collection.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc2: A nun who removes hair from the armpits or the groin must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc3: A nun who slaps her genitals must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc4: A nun who uses a dildo must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc5: A nun who inserts more than two joints of the fingers into the vagina must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc6: A nun who attends on a monk while he is eating must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc7: A nun who asks for raw grain and then prepares and eats it must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc8: A nun who disposes of feces, urine, or rubbish over a wall must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc9: A nun who disposes of feces, urine, or rubbish on cultivated plants must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc10: A nun who goes to see a show must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc11: A nun who, seeking privacy, stands alone with a man at night must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc12: A nun who, seeking privacy, stands alone with a man in a concealed place must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc13: A nun who, seeking privacy, stands alone with a man out in the open must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc14: A nun who, seeking privacy, stands alone with a man on street must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc15: A nun who leaves a house without informing the owners must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc16: A nun who sits or lies down on a seat in a house without asking the owners for permission must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc17: A nun who spreads out bedding in a house and then sits or lies down without asking the owners for permission must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc18: A nun who criticizes someone without reflection must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc19: A nun who curses herself or another must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc20: A nun who cries and beats herself must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc21: A nun who bathes naked must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc22: A nun who makes a bathing robe that is too large must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc23: A nun who does not sew back together the robe of another nun after unstitching it must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc24: A nun who leaves any of her five robes untouched for five days must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc25: A nun who wears a borrowed robe without the permission of the owner must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc26: A nun who hinders an order of nuns from receiving robe-cloth must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc27: A nun who blocks an appropriate distribution of robe-cloth must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc28: A nun who gives a robe to anyone who is not a Buddhist monastic must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc29: A nun who hinders the distribution of robe-cloth without a proper reason must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc30: A nun who inappropriately blocks the Order from ending the robe-making season must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc31: A nun who lies down on the same bed as another nun must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc32: A nun who shares bedding with another nun must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc33: A nun who intentionally makes another nun ill at ease must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc34: A nun who does not attend on a sick monastic disciple must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc35: A nun who gives a dwelling place to another nun and then throws her out must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc36: A nun who persistently engages in inappropriate socialization with lay people must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc37: A nun who goes wandering without a group of travelers in a dangerous area of her own country must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc38: A nun who goes wandering without a group of travelers in a dangerous area abroad must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc39: A nun who goes wandering during the rainy season must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc40: A nun who does not go wandering after the rainy season must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc41: A nun who goes to see a pleasure house or a pleasure garden must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc42: A nun who uses a large or luxurious seat must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc43: A nun who spins yarn must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc44: A nun who serves a lay person must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc45: A nun who agrees to settle a legal issue but then makes no effort to do so must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc46: A nun who gives food to anyone who is not a Buddhist monastic must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc47: A nun who uses a communal menstruation robe beyond the intended period must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc48: A nun who goes wandering without giving up her lodging must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc49: A nun who studies pointless knowledge must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc50: A nun who teaches pointless knowledge must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc51: A nun who enters a monks’ monastery without permission must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc52: A nun who abuses a monk must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc53: A nun who in anger abuses an order must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc54: A nun who eats after finishing her meal must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc55: A nun who tries to keep her supporters from supporting others must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc56: A nun who spends the rainy season in a monastery without monks must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc57: A nun who does not invite correction from both Orders after the rainy season must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc58: A nun who does not go to the instruction or formal meetings of the Order must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc59: A nun who does not ask the Order of monks every half-month about the observance day and the going for instruction must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc60: A nun who is alone with a man and gets treatment from him on the thigh must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc61: A nun who ordains a pregnant woman must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc62: A nun who ordains a woman who is breastfeeding must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc63: A nun who ordains a trainee nun who has not completed her training must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc64: A nun who ordains a trainee nun without the approval of the Order must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc65: A nun who ordains a married girl less than twelve years old must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc66: A nun who ordains a married girl who has not completed her training must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc67: A nun who ordains a married girl without the approval of the Order must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc68: A nun who ordains a student but does not guide her for two years must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc69: A nun who does not follow her preceptor for two years must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc70: A nun who ordains a student without afterwards taking her away must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc71: A nun who ordains an unmarried girl less than twenty years old must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc72: A nun who ordains an unmarried girl who has not completed her training must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc95: A nun who asks a monk a question without obtaining leave must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc96: A nun who enters an inhabited area without a bust cover must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc97: A nun who lies must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc98: A nun who verbally abuses another nun must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc99: A nun who spreads malicious gossip about another nun must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc100: A nun who teaches an unordained person to learn the word of the Buddha by heart must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc132: A nun who consumes alcohol must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc133: A nun who tickles another nun must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc134: A nun who plays in water must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc135: A nun who is disrespectful when rightly corrected about a breach of the monastic code must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc137: A nun who lights a fire to warm herself must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc138: A nun in the central Ganges plain who bathes more than once a fortnight, except when dirty, must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc139: A nun who wears a new robe without first marking it must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc140: A nun who uses robe-cloth that has been transferred to a fellow monastic must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc141: A nun who hides the requisites of another nun must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc143: A nun who uses water that contains living beings must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc144: A nun who tries to reopen an issue of monastic law that has been properly settled must confess the offense.
pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc145: A nun who travels by arrangement with thieves must confess the offense.

pli-tv-bi-vb.pli-tv-bi-vb-pc149: A nun who uses a ploy as an excuse for not keeping the monastic code must confess the offense.
